questions.text: You are initiating hypertension services at your Primary Health Center (PHC). 50 patients in need of antihypertensive treatment have been transferred from another facility. Among them, 40 were prescribed amlodipine (5mg orally) and 10 were prescribed lisinopril (10mg orally) due to contraindications with amlodipine. Medications are supplied monthly at the PHC, and you are responsible for ordering them. How many tablets do you need to order and what should be the reorder factor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) 1600, rf = 2

 

  • Total number of tablets required for the 50 patients:
  • Amlodipine: 40 patients * 5mg per day * 30 days = 6,000 mg
  • Lisinopril: 10 patients * 10mg per day * 30 days = 3,000 mg
  • Total tablets required:
  • Amlodipine: 6,000 mg / 5mg per tablet = 1,200 tablets
  • Lisinopril: 3,000 mg / 10mg per tablet = 300 tablets
  • Reorder factor (rf) = Total tablets required / Monthly supply
  • rf = 1,500 / 1,600 = 0.9375 (not equal to 2)

 

  • Based on the calculations, none of the options match the required number of tablets and reorder factor. However, from requirement is 1500 tablets and only one option has tablets more than 1500, ie option D, it is the most suitable answer.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

1000, rf=3 (Option A): 1,500 tablets / rf = 1,000 tablets, rf = 1,500 / 1,000 = 1.5 (not equal to 3)

 

1200, rf=2 (Option B): 1,500 tablets / rf = 1,200 tablets, rf = 1,500 / 1,200 = 1.25 (not equal to 2)

 

1400, rf=3 (Option C): 1,500 tablets / rf = 1,400 tablets, rf = 1,500 / 1,400 = 1.07 (not equal to 3)

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect statement regarding the image shown below?

choices.text: Only the roots of this plant are poisonous
Atropine is not specific for aconite poisoning

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Only the roots of this plant are poisonous

 

Explanation:

In plants like Aconitum (commonly known as aconite or monkshood), all parts of the plant, including the roots, leaves, and flowers, are toxic. The plant contains potent alkaloids such as aconitine, which can cause poisoning if ingested.

 

Species

Aconitum napellus, Aconitum ferox

Synonyms

Monk’s hood, mitha zaher, bish, wolf’s bane, women’s bane, devil’s helmet, or blue rocket

Source
  • All parts of the plant are poisonous (Option A)
  • Root and root tubers are the most potent (often mistaken for horseradish root)
  • Grown in Mountainous areas of the northern hemisphere. Eg. Sub Himalayan range (Option D ruled out)

Active Principles

Aconitine, pseudo-aconitine, indaconitine, picraconitine, aconine.

Mechanism of Action

Affects voltage-sensitive sodium channels, stimulates then paralyzes sensory nerves, secretory nerves, CNS, and myocardium.

Symptoms (by system)
  • GIT: Nausea, vomiting, salivation, abdominal pain, diarrhea, burning/tingling of mouth, tongue, throat, followed by numbness.
  • CVS: Hypotension, AV block, bradycardia, chest pain, ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation, slow/feeble pulse. (Option B ruled out)
  • CNS: Vertigo, restlessness, headache, giddiness.
  • MS: Muscle weakness, twitching, spasms.
  • RS: Slow, labored, shallow breathing.
  • Ocular: Alternating pupil dilation/contraction (hippus), diplopia, impaired vision.
  • Others: Subnormal temperature, cold skin, yellow-green vision, tinnitus, paralysis of facial muscles.
  • Death: Respiratory failure or ventricular fibrillation.

Fatal Dose

Root: 1-2 g

Treatment
  • No specific antidote.
  • Gastric lavage with tannic acid/activated charcoal.
  • Inotropic therapy for hypotension, atropine for bradycardia. (Option C ruled out)
  • Ventricular arrhythmia treated with amiodarone, flecainide; cardiopulmonary bypass for refractory cases.

Medico-legal Aspects
  • Ideal homicidal poison: cheap, easily available, small lethal dose, short fatal period, difficult to detect postmortem.
  • Accidental poisoning: mistaken for horseradish

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypothermia

 

Explanation:

Hypothermia occurs when the body's core temperature falls below 36°C (96.8°F), leading to paradoxical undressing. This occurs due to disorientation and mental confusion as the body struggles to regulate temperature, causing the victim to undress, which paradoxically increases heat loss. This behavior can be mistaken for evidence of sexual assault or homicide.

 

Hypothermia

Definition

Core temperature below 36°C (96.8°F)

Signs
  • Disorientation
  • Dulling of consciousness
  • Loss of reflex
  • Fall in respiration, heart rate, and blood pressure
  • Red patches and pallor of the skin
  • Edema of the face
  • Stiffness of neck muscles

Autopsy findings
  • Patches of pink to brownish-pink discoloration
  • Postmortem staining: Pink/bright red
  • Cyanosis or pallor in extremities ("white deaths")
  • Edema of feet and blistering of skin
  • Stomach: Wischnewsky spots-brownish black colored gastric mucosal ulcers
  • Viscera-congested, hemorrhagic

Phenomena seen in hypothermia victims

  • Paradoxical undressing- found undressed due to disorientation which increases heat loss (mistaken for evidence of sexual assault or homicide)
  • ‘Hide and die' syndrome- found in unusual locations resembling an attempt to "hide" or create a protective environment due to mental confusion and a possible hibernation reflex (confused with signs of homicide or robbery)
  • Chilblain (Erythema Pernio)- red, itching skin lesions typically found on extremities due to cold exposure, often accompanied by edema and blistering.

 

Heart stress (Option A) typically refers to conditions that put pressure on the heart, such as heart attacks or heart failure. Paradoxical undressing is not associated with heart stress. It occurs due to hypothermia, where the body loses its ability to regulate temperature properly.

 

Voyeurism (Option B) is a psychological condition where individuals gain sexual pleasure from watching others without their knowledge. It is unrelated to paradoxical undressing, which is a phenomenon occurring due to hypothermia and confusion.


LSD overdose (Option D) can cause severe confusion, hallucinations, and altered perceptions, but it does not typically lead to paradoxical undressing. Hypothermia, not LSD overdose, is the primary cause of this phenomenon.

questions.text: Compared to a pregnant female, a lactating female would require a higher level of nutrient supplementation for which of the following?
questions.solution:
B)  Calcium

 

Explanation:

 

  • Lactating females require higher calcium supplementation compared to pregnant females due to the significant calcium demand for breast milk production. This is crucial for infant bone and teeth development, as well as maintaining maternal muscle and nerve function.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Vitamin A (Option A): While important, the need for vitamin A doesn't necessarily increase during lactation compared to pregnancy.

 

Iron (Option C): Iron requirements typically decrease slightly during lactation as maternal blood volume decreases postpartum.

 

Folic Acid (Option D): Folic acid's importance remains, but the requirement doesn't notably increase during lactation compared to pregnancy.

questions.text: Identify the injury the image below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Abrasion

 

Explanation:

Abrasion:

Abrasion is a superficial injury caused by the removal or damage of the skin's outer layer (epidermis) due to friction or pressure. It is classified into four main types:

Scratch Abrasion (Linear Abrasion)

Grazed Abrasion (Sliding Abrasion)

Mechanism: Caused by tangential (side-to-side) force, producing a long and narrow abrasion.

Features: Linear in nature, with length being more significant than width.

Examples: Fingernail abrasion, thorn abrasion, and pin abrasion.


 

Mechanism: Occurs when skin slides over a rough surface, resulting in superficial scrapes.

Also Known As: Grinding abrasion, gravel rash, brush-burn.

Features: Seen in road traffic accidents or falls, especially on exposed areas like knees or elbows.

Imprint Abrasion (Patterned Abrasion)

Pressure Abrasion (Crushing Abrasion)

Mechanism: Results from compressive force applied perpendicular to the skin, leaving a distinct pattern of the object.

Also Known As Impact abrasion, contact abrasion, patterned abrasion.

Examples: Tyre marks, bite marks

 

Mechanism: Caused by a continuous vertical force applied to the skin, crushing the epidermis.

Features: Deeper skin injuries are often seen with prolonged pressure, potentially leading to necrosis.

Examples: Ligature marks in hanging or strangulation

 

Direction of Force in Abrasion

The direction of force applied in an abrasion can be identified based on specific characteristics of the skin damage. At the end of an abrasion, the skin shows distinct features that help determine the direction of the force, particularly through epithelial tags or aggregated lines.

Characteristics of the end of an abrasion:

 

Multiple Lines
  • Indicate the endpoint of the abrasion.
  • Reflect the direction of the applied force.

Uneven and Longitudinal Lines
  • Show irregularity at the end of the abrasion.
  • Suggest pulling or scraping of the skin.

Heaped-up or Aggregated Lines
  • Also known as Epithelial tags (Terminal tags)
  • Skin tissues dragged opposite to the force direction.
  • Point toward the end of the abrasion, indicating the force direction
  • (e.g., tags heaped at the right end, if the force was left to right).

questions.text: What is the primary method of absorption of inorganic lead in industrial settings that can result in lead poisoning?

choices.text: Ingestion of contaminated food and water

questions.solution:
B) Inhaled lead dust

 

Explanation:

 

  • In industrial settings, the inhalation of lead dust is the primary route of exposure and absorption of inorganic lead. This occurs when lead-containing particles become airborne, usually as a result of industrial processes such as smelting, welding, or battery manufacturing.
  • Workers who breathe in the contaminated air can inhale these lead particles, which can then be absorbed into the bloodstream through the respiratory system.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Absorption through skin (Option A): While it is true that lead can be absorbed through the skin, it is not the most common mode of absorption in industrial settings.

 

Ingestion of contaminated food and water (Option C): Contaminated food and water can cause lead exposure and poisoning, notably in residential or environmental contexts, but it's not the primary route of absorption in industrial settings.

 

Contaminated hands (Option D): While contact with contaminated hands can contribute to lead exposure, it is not the most common mode of absorption in industrial settings.

questions.text: In the hospital ward, the nurse arranges the bins as depicted in the image. Which of the subsequent items should be disposed of in the black bin?
questions.solution:
B) Glove paper cover

 

  • The item that would go into the black bin is a glove paper cover
  • The black bin is typically used for the disposal of general non-recyclable waste. In this case, the glove paper cover is a single-use item that is used to cover and protect gloves before use. Once the gloves are taken out and used, the paper cover becomes non-recyclable waste and should be disposed of in the black bin.

 

 

Colour

Type of waste

Example of waste

Treatment and disposal

Yellow

 
  • Human anatomical waste.
  • Animal anatomical waste.
  • Soiled waste.
  •  Discarded or expired medicine.
  • Microbiology, biotechnology and other clinical laboratory waste.
  • Chemical waste.
  • Chemical liquid waste.

 
  • Placenta.
  • Post-operative body parts.
  • Plaster of Paris (POP).
  • Pathological waste.
  • Cotton waste.
  • Dressing materials.
  • Beddings.
  • Body fluid contaminated paper and cloth.
  • Face mask, cap, shoe cover and head cover.
  • Cytotoxic, expired and discarded medicines.
  • Microbiology and biotechnology lab waste.
  • Blood bag
  • Vacutainers with blood

 
  • Incineration.
  • Plasma pyrolysis.
  • Deep burial.

 

Red

Contaminated waste that is recyclable.
  • Syringe without needles.
  • Fixed needle syringes with their needle cut.
  • IVset.
  • Catheters.
  • Gloves (soiled or unsoiled).
  • Urine bag.
  • Dialysis kit.
  • IVbottles.
  • Tubing's.
  • Bottles.
  • Vacutainers with needle cut.
  • Vacutainers without blood.
  • ELISA plate and vials not containing blood samples.
  • Autoclaving or microwaving/ hydroclaving followed by shredding or

mutilation and waste set to registered recyclers or for energy

recovery/road making.

  • Plastic waste should not be sent to landfill sites.

 

White

 

Waste Sharps
  • Needles
  • Syringes with fixed needles
  • Blades
  • Scalpers
  • Trocar cannula
  • Insulin pen needle

 
  • Puncture proof , Leak proof, Tamper proof containers
  • Autoclaving or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding or mutilation or encapsulation in metal container or cement concrete
  • Or sent for final disposal to iron foundries or sanitary landfill or designated concrete waste sharp pit

 

Blue

 

Glassware or metallic body implants.
  • Includes broken or discarded glass and metallic objects that are contaminated.
  • Glass:
  • Broken glass.
  • Ampoules.
  • Lab slide
  • Metals:
  • Nails.
  • Metallic body implants.
  • Scissors.
  • Artificial pacemakers.

 
  • Cardboard boxes with blue coloured marking or blue coloured puncture- proof and tamper-proof containers.
  • Disinfection (cleaning with detergent and soaking in sodium hypochlorite) or autoclaving or microwaving or hydroclaving and then sent for recycling.

 

 

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Soiled linen bedsheet (Option A): The color of the bin for contaminated linen is yellow.

 

Gloves (Option C): Gloves used in a hospital setting, even if they are used and no longer sterile, should be disposed of in red bins

 

Contaminated gloves (Option D): Similarly, contaminated gloves should be disposed of in red bins.

questions.text:
A teenage girl presented with irregular menstrual cycles and increased facial hair. Her ovaries showed increased volume. Which of the following are used in the first-line treatment?


	Laparoscopic ovarian drilling
	Anti-androgens
	Lifestyle modifications
	Combined oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation: The patient’s irregular menstrual cycles, increased facial hair, and increased ovarian syndrome suggest polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). The primary treatment options include anti-androgens (2), lifestyle changes (3), and combined oral contraceptives (4). If medical treatment does not provide sufficient relief, laparoscopic ovarian drilling (1) may be considered as a surgical intervention.

 

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), also known as Stein-Leventhal syndrome, is a heterogeneous, multisystem endocrinopathy in women of reproductive age with ovarian expression of various metabolic disturbances.

 

Components of PCOS:

  • Increased androgens
  • Ovulatory dysfunction
  • Polycystic ovaries

 

Clinical features:

  • Usually present in young women
  • Central obesity (BMI > 30kg/cm2), waistline> 88cm.
  • Oligomenorrhea, amenorrhoea
  • Infertility
  • Hirsutism
  • Acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance

 

Rotterdam Criteria for diagnosing PCOS: Two of the following three criteria must be present:

  1. Increased androgen levels: Leading to symptoms like hirsutism or acne, or biochemical findings such as high testosterone.
  2. Ovulatory dysfunction: Irregular or absent menstrual cycles (oligomenorrhea/ amenorrhea) due to ovulatory dysfunction.
  3. Ultrasound findings: Ovaries with >12 follicles (2-9mm) and/or ovarian volume ≥10 cm³, showing a "necklace pattern" of cysts arranged peripherally with excessive stromal tissue in the centre producing androgens.

 

Management:

  • Lifestyle Modifications:
    • Weight Loss: Improves hormonal balance and reduces testosterone and insulin levels.
    • Lifestyle Changes (3): Smoking cessation.
  • Pharmacologic Treatment:
    • OCPs (4): Regulate menstruation, treat hirsutism, and improve acne.
    • Anti-androgens (2): Spironolactone and ketoconazole reduce testosterone.
    • Metformin: Improves fertility and lowers insulin and testosterone levels.
    • Dexamethasone: Reduces androgen production. 
  • Infertility Treatment:
    • Clomiphene Citrate: For ovulation induction.
    • Letrozole: For clomiphene-resistant cases.
  • Surgical Treatment:
    • Laparoscopic Ovarian Drilling (1): For infertility or hyperstimulation despite medical therapy. 
  • Surgery is indicated if: 
    • Medical therapy fails
    • Hyperstimulation occurs
    • Infertility persists
    • There are previous pregnancy losses

questions.text: Name the type of skull fracture.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hinge fracture

 

Explanation:

The type of skull fracture shown in the image is Hinge fracture. A Hinge fracture involves a break in the skull that allows part of the skull to rotate or pivot around a point, resembling a hinge. This type of fracture typically occurs due to a localized impact or force, often affecting the base or side of the skull.

Motorcyclist Fracture (Hinge Fracture)

(Option B)

Ring Fracture

(Option D ruled out)
  • Transverse fracture at the skull base, splitting it and creating a "hinge" - nodding face sign.
  • It extends from one petrous ridge across the sella turcica to the other petrous ridge.
  • Encircles the foramen magnum at the skull base.
  • Runs from the sella turcica to the petrous ridges and posterior fossa.
  • It can extend to the middle ear and roof of the nose.

Often caused by side impacts.


 

Caused by:

  • Falls landing on feet/buttocks (force transmitted through the spine).
  • Heavy blows to the top of the skull/ vertex.
  • Twisting of the head on the spine.
  • Blows to the occiput or chin.

Hinge fracture

Ring fracture

 

Depressed Fracture (Option A ruled out)
  • Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain.
  • Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks).
  • The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury.

Variants:

  • Elevated Fracture: One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe.
  • Pond Fracture: Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade.(Option C ruled out)

Depressed fracture

questions.text: A registered medical practitioner is requested by a survivor of sexual violence to examine her. Within what time must the practitioner take a vaginal swab to look for the presence of spermatozoa?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Within 72 hours

 

Explanation:

Timeliness of Evidence Collection:

  • Recovery of trace evidence diminishes over time.
  • Sperm detection:
    • Motile sperm: up to 12 hours in the vagina.
    • Non-motile sperm: up to 72 hours.

 

Within 36 hours (Option B), Within 5 days (Option C), & Within 48 hours (Option D) are all incorrect options. Sperm can remain in the vagina for up to 72 hours, but the motility of sperm decreases over time. Non-motile sperm can still be detected within this time frame, making it crucial to collect evidence within 72 hours for accurate results.

questions.text:
During the visit to the outpatient department, a female patient aged 18 years was examined. The genital examination disclosed the following observations. These observations suggest:

1. Labia majora - separated

2. Labia minora - flabby

3. Fourchette tear present

4. Roomy vagina seen with intact hymen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) False virgin

 

Explanation:

Category

True Virgin

(Option A ruled out)

False Virgin

Genital Signs
  • Intact, rigid, inelastic hymen; admits only a fingertip, causing pain.
  • Thick, fleshy labia majora that close the vaginal orifice; small, pink labia minora covered by labia majora.
  • Narrow vagina with prominent rugae; full finger cannot be admitted.
  • Present fossa navicularis, intact fourchette, narrow vestibule, small clitoris, intact posterior commissure.
  • Intact hymen that may be loose, elastic, or thick; admits two fingers easily.
  • Less fleshy labia majora; vaginal orifice may be visible; enlarged, pigmented labia minora.
  • Roomy vagina with less prominent rugae; full finger can be admitted.
  • Disappearance of fossa navicularis; torn and healed fourchette; wider vestibule; enlarged clitoris; possibly torn posterior commissure.

Extra-Genital Signs

Small, hemispherical, firm breasts; pink areola.

Larger, pendulous, flabby breasts; pigmented areola.

 

Premenstrual stage (Option C) genitalia are underdeveloped, with thick labia majora, small labia minora, and a firm hymen admitting only small instruments. The patient's findings suggest a post-pubertal state, not a premenstrual stage.


Molestation (Option D) may involve bruises, hymenal tears, and disrupted commissures. While a fourchette tear is present, the intact hymen and absence of other trauma make this less likely.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for graphical representation in flow cytometry analysis?
questions.solution:
C) Histogram, dot plot

 

Explanation:

 

  • The graphical representation for flow cytometry analysis is typically done using: Histogram, dot plot

 

  • Flow cytometry analyzes cellular properties like size, granularity, and fluorescence intensity. Data is represented using histograms, showing frequency distribution of parameters like fluorescence intensity, and dot plots, displaying two parameters per cell to identify subpopulations.

 

 

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Bar diagram, dot plot (Option A): While bar diagrams can be used to represent categorical or discrete data, they are not commonly used for flow cytometry analysis..

 

Line diagram, dot plot (Option B): Line diagrams are often used to depict trends over time, but in flow cytometry analysis, where data points represent individual cells and aren't time-dependent, they're not commonly employed.

 

Pie chart, dot plot (Option D): Pie charts display categorical data distribution but aren't suitable for flow cytometry analysis due to its focus on continuous variables and individual cells.

questions.text: Identify the following post mortem change:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Suggillation

 

Explanation:

Livor Mortis

Other Names

Postmortem staining, subcutaneous hypostasis, cadaveric lividity, suggillation, cogitation, vibices, and darkening of death.

Definition

Bluish or purplish-red discoloration caused by the gravitational settling of blood in the toneless capillaries and venules of the dependent parts of the dead body.

Site

Superficial layers of the dermis

Mechanism

Blood in capillaries and venules → Stagnates and sinks in dependent parts due to gravity → Bluish purple discoloration due to deoxy hemoglobin.

Begins

0.5 - 1 hour

Fully Developed

Within 4 hours

Fixation of Livor Mortis

Typically, within 6-12 hours

Confirmation of Fixation

Apply thumb pressure against the skin for a few seconds → Blanching → Livor mortis not fixed.

Primary Lividity

Occurs as lividity reaches maximum intensity between 6 to 12 hours after death.

Secondary Lividity

Shifting of lividity can occur if the body is moved within a few hours after death.

Duration of Persistence

Staining persists until putrefaction begins.

Distribution

Depends on position of the body:

Supine

Appears on the back of neck, entire back, flanks, except areas under pressure (contact pallor).

Prone

Appears on the front part of the body.

Side

Appears on the dependent side.

Head downwards

Appears as a blackened face and neck.

Vertical suspension

Appears on legs and hands (glove and stocking appearance) and external genitalia.

Drowning

Appears on the face, upper chest, hands, lower arms, feet, and calves.

Livor Mortis Absent

  • Excessive blood loss
  • Severe anemia
  • Death from wasting diseases
  • Lobar pneumonia

Medicolegal Importance
  • Helps estimate time of death.
  • Indicates body posture at death.
  • Indicates if the body was moved post-death.
  • Distribution may indicate the cause of death.

Image

Tattooing (Option A) refers to the deposition of gunpowder particles on the skin when fired from a close distance. It creates small punctate marks around the entrance wound and is associated with firearm injuries, not a postmortem change.

 

Putrefaction (Option C) refers to the decomposition of the body caused by bacterial activity, leading to the breakdown of tissues, gas formation, color changes, and a characteristic odor. This process occurs after death but is not the immediate postmortem change indicated in the question.

 

Decomposition (Option D) occurs through autolysis (self-digestion by body enzymes) and putrefaction (bacterial breakdown, primarily by Clostridium perfringens). Putrefaction involves lecithinase breaking down cell membranes, gas formation, and color changes like green discoloration. Timing of decomposition varies with temperature, starting within 12-18 hours in summer.

questions.text: Interpret the following graph (in order from left to right):

choices.text: Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, skewed with outliers
Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers
Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, normal with outliers
Skewed with outliers, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers

 

Explanation:

 

  • 1- Normal Distribution: A whisker and box plot displays a normal distribution with a box from Q1 to Q3, showing the median as a line inside. The whiskers extend 1.5 times the IQR or to the maximum and minimum values within the range, with no outliers beyond them.

 

  • 2- Positively Skewed Distribution: In a positively skewed distribution, most data cluster at the lower end with a long tail towards higher values. The whisker and box plot reflects this by shifting the box towards the lower end, with the median closer. The longer whisker on the higher end accommodates the tail, with any outliers beyond it.

 

  • 3- Negatively Skewed Distribution: In a negatively skewed distribution, most data cluster at the higher end, with a long tail toward lower values. The whisker and box plot reflects this by shifting the box towards the higher end, with the median closer. The longer lower whisker accommodates the tail, with any outliers beyond it.

 

  • 4- Normal Distribution with Outliers: In a normal distribution with outliers, the box and whisker plot resembles a standard distribution, but with outliers plotted beyond the whiskers. These outliers deviate significantly from the majority of the data and may be shown as individual points or special symbols.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Vulval cancer

 

Explanation: The given image shows a discrete growth on the left labia majora of the vulva. The most likely diagnosis is vulvar cancer.
 

Vulval Cancer

Site
  • Labia majora is the most common (60%).
  • Clitoris 2nd most common (15%).
  • Most common in 50-70 years age group

Presentation
  • Exophytic (outward-growing) and ulcerative (open sore) growth.

Symptom
  • Pruritus (most common): Often associated with an itch-scratch cycle.
  • Cancer cachexia (weight loss and muscle wasting).
  • Cancer pain.

Spread
  • Primarily spreads through the lymphatic system.
  • Vulvar lymphatics cross over at the midline, especially within 2 cm of the midline.
  • The inguinofemoral lymph nodes are the most commonly involved group.
  • Lymph node involvement significantly affects prognosis.

Investigations
  • Excisional biopsy (IOC): For lesions < 1 cm in size. Complete lesion removal and histological assessment, including invasion presence and depth.
  • Incisional biopsy: For lesions ≥ 1 cm in size.
  • Wedge biopsy.
  • Keyes punch biopsy.
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy: Assess lymph node involvement, particularly the inguinofemoral nodes.

 

Treatment of Tumor Stages of Vulval Cancer

Stage 1a

  • Wide local excision with a 1-cm margin is performed for the probable cure.

Stage 1b
  • Radical resection of the primary tumor and inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy (LAD).
  • Central lesion: B/L LAD
  • Lateral lesion (> 2 cm from midline): U/L LAD.

Stage II
  • Radical vulvectomy + B/L LAD
  • Positive LN involvement in HPE - Must do pelvic LAD or pelvic LN radiotherapy.

Stage III
  • Radical partial or total vulvectomy and either SLNB or inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy.
  • Postoperative adjuvant radiation (4000-5000 Rads over 5 weeks) directed to both the groins and the pelvis.

Stage IV
  • Treated with chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Chemotherapy: 5-FU, mitomycin C
  • Other agents used are Methotrexate, bleomycin, and trastuzumab.

 

Vulval hematoma (Option C) is a collection of blood in the vulva that appears as a tense swelling with a dusky or purple discoloration, typically resulting from trauma. It does not manifest as a discrete growth, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

Condyloma acuminata (Option B) is caused by HPV types 6 or 11, and presents as verrucous warty lesions. While the growths may appear discrete initially, they often coalesce into a characteristic cauliflower-like appearance, which is different from the solitary growth described here.

Bartholin cysts (Option D) are caused by obstruction of the Bartholin duct, often due to proteinaceous material or inflammation from infection. They present as smooth, cystic swellings located on the posterior labia majora or vestibule. Complications, such as Bartholin abscess, can cause painful swelling requiring incision and drainage, but these do not resemble a discrete growth.

questions.text: Which of the following traits is a feature of the female skull ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mandible Rounded

 

Explanation:

Distinguishing features of male and female skull:

Feature

Male skull

Female skull

General Appearance

Larger, heavier, rugged, marked muscular ridges

Smaller, lighter, walls thinner, smoother

Forehead

Receding, irregular, rough, less rounded

Vertical, round, full, infantile, smooth

Cranial capacity

More capacious (1450–1550 cc)

Less capacious (1300–1350 cc)

Glabella

Prominent

questions.text: Which of the following components are included in the Human Development Index (HDI), as per the World Health Organization (WHO)?

choices.text: Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and standard of living
Infant mortality rate, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate

questions.solution:
A)  Life expectancy at birth, literacy, and standard of living:

 

Explanation:

  • Option A is correct, including life expectancy at birth, literacy, and standard of living.
  • Components of the Human Development Index (HDI) are defined by the UNDP.
  • Life expectancy at birth reflects overall health and mortality rates.
  • Literacy measures ability to read and write, crucial for personal and economic development.
  • Standard of living encompasses material well-being and quality of life.
  • HDI combines these factors to measure human development and well-being globally.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and standard of living (Option B): Incorrectly includes life expectancy at 1 year.

 

Infant mortality rate, literacy and standard of living (Option C): Incorrectly includes infant mortality rate.

 

Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate (Option D): Incorrectly includes life expectancy at 1 year and infant mortality rate.

questions.text: Which of the options below does not constitute a component of case-control studies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A)  Follow-up

 

Explanation:

 

  • Follow-up is not part of case-control studies; they are retrospective and do not involve observing participants over time.
  • Case-control studies involve:
  • Selection of cases and controls.
  • Matching to ensure comparability.
  • Measurement of exposure.
  • Analysis and interpretation of the data.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Matching (Option B): Matching is commonly used in case-control studies to ensure comparability.

 

Strength of association (Option C): Strength of association is assessed in case-control studies.

 

Selection of study subjects (Option D): Selection of study subjects is indeed a step in case-control studies, involving cases and controls.

questions.text: Which antigen is present in the Hepatitis B subunit vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) HbsAg

 

Explanation:

 

  • Hepatitis B subunit vaccine contains the surface antigen of the hepatitis B virus (HBV), which is known as HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen). This antigen is a protein component of the viral envelope and is produced using recombinant DNA technology. It is the major antigen responsible for inducing an immune response against HBV.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

HbeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen) (Option A): This antigen is a marker of active viral replication in individuals infected with hepatitis B virus (HBV). It is not a component of the hepatitis B subunit vaccine.

 

HbcAg (Hepatitis B core antigen) (Option C): This antigen is the inner core protein of the hepatitis B virus. It is not included in the hepatitis B subunit vaccine.

 

HBV DNA (Hepatitis B virus DNA) (Option D): HBV DNA is the genetic material of the hepatitis B virus. It is not a component of the hepatitis B subunit vaccine.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding prevalence and incidence in relation to a newly introduced drug that reduces mortality but does not cure the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D)  Increase in prevalence

 

Explanation:

 

  • Introduction of a drug that decreases mortality but doesn't cure the disease prolongs the duration of the disease for each individual.
  • Prevalence (P) = Incidence (I) × Duration (D).
  • Since the duration of the disease is prolonged, despite decreased mortality, there will be an increase in prevalence.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Decrease in incidence (Option A): The drug doesn't affect the occurrence of new cases, so incidence isn't necessarily impacted.

 

Decrease in prevalence (Option B): The prolonged duration of the disease may increase prevalence despite decreased mortality.

 

Increase in incidence (Option C): The drug doesn't influence new case occurrence, so incidence isn't necessarily impacted.

questions.text: With regards to the pasteurization of milk, which of the following tests is not related?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Iodine test

 

Explanation:

 

  • The iodine test is not directly related to the pasteurization of milk. It is a test used to detect the presence of starch in a substance. It involves adding iodine solution to the sample, and if starch is present, the solution will turn blue-black.

 

Incorrect Choices:

 

  • Phosphatase test (Option A): The phosphatase test is indeed related to the pasteurization of milk. Phosphatase is an enzyme naturally present in raw milk but is inactivated during the pasteurization process. By measuring the activity of phosphatase in milk, it can be determined if proper pasteurization has occurred. Therefore, this option is incorrect as the phosphatase test is directly related to pasteurization.

 

  • Standard plate count (Option C): The standard plate count is also related to the pasteurization of milk. It is a test used to determine the total number of viable microorganisms present in milk. By assessing the microbial load, the effectiveness of pasteurization in reducing bacterial contamination can be evaluated. This option is incorrect as the standard plate count is directly associated with assessing the pasteurization process.

 

  • Methylene blue reduction test (Option D): The methylene blue reduction test is used to assess the bacteriological quality of milk and the efficiency of pasteurization. It evaluates the reduction of methylene blue dye by the metabolic activity of microorganisms in milk. This test helps determine if pasteurization has effectively inhibited bacterial growth. Therefore, this option is incorrect as the methylene blue reduction test is directly related to pasteurization.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the relationship between prevalence, incidence, and the introduction of a new drug that reduces mortality but does not provide a cure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option D) Increase in prevalence

 

Explanation: 

  • Prevalence refers to the proportion of individuals in a population who have a particular disease or condition at a specific point in time. If the new drug decreases mortality but does not cure the disease, it means that individuals with the disease are living longer.
  • As a result, the duration of the disease for each individual is prolonged, which may lead to an accumulation of cases over time. This accumulation of cases could potentially result in an increase in the prevalence of the disease. Although the drug may decrease mortality, it does not prevent new cases from occurring, leading to a higher number of individuals with the disease in the population.
  • Therefore, the correct statement is that there would be an increase in prevalence (Option D) due to the prolonged duration of the disease despite the decrease in mortality.

 

Incorrect Choices:

 

  • Decrease in incidence (Option a): Incidence refers to the number of new cases of a disease that occur in a population over a specific period of time. The introduction of a new drug that decreases mortality but does not cure the disease does not directly impact the occurrence of new cases. The drug may improve the survival rate of individuals already diagnosed with the disease, but it does not influence the number of new cases being diagnosed. Therefore, the incidence of the disease would not necessarily decrease as a result of this drug.

 

  • Decrease in prevalence (Option B): Since the drug does not cure the disease but only decreases mortality, it means that individuals with the disease are living longer. However, the prevalence of the disease is influenced by both the number of new cases and the duration of the disease. If the drug does not impact the number of new cases, the overall prevalence of the disease may not decrease.

 

  • Increase in incidence (Option C): Similar to option A, the introduction of a new drug that decreases mortality but does not cure the disease does not directly impact the occurrence of new cases. The drug may improve the survival rate of individuals already diagnosed with the disease, but it does not affect the likelihood of new cases developing. Therefore, the incidence of the disease would not necessarily increase due to the introduction of this drug.

questions.text: Identify the condition
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Oculomotor nerve palsy

 

Explanation:

Given image is suggestive of Paralytic Strabismus of a patient with down and out left eye with ptosis on primary gaze with inability to elevate, adduct completely is suggestive of Oculomotor (Third) nerve palsy.

Features of third nerve palsy

  • Ptosis: Due to paralysis of the LPS (levator palpebrae superioris) muscle
  • The eyeball is deviated down and outwards (due to actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles).
  • The pupil is fixed and dilated (due to paralysis of the sphincter pupillae muscle)
  • Ocular movements are restricted
  • Accommodation is completely lost (due to paralysis of the ciliary muscle)
  • Crossed diplopia is elicited by raising the eyelid.
  • Absence of Both direct and consensual reflexes in the affected eye
  • These compensatory head postures are motor adaptations used to minimise the effects of double vision
    • Horizontal Diplopia: The patient often tilts the head downward
    • Vertical Diplopia: The head is positioned with the chin either raised or lowered
    • Torsional Diplopia: The head is tilted sideways

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Medial Rectus Palsy (Option A): This condition is characterized by weakness or paralysis of the medial rectus muscle, which controls the eye's inward movement, often leading to an inability to ADDUCT the eye.

 

Trochlear Nerve Palsy (Option B): This pertains to a neurological disorder where damage to the fourth cranial nerve, or trochlear nerve, results in vertical diplopia when the patient looks down and inability to DEPRESS the eye completely .

 

Abducens Nerve Palsy (Option C): This is a disorder marked by the impairment of the sixth cranial nerve, resulting in lateral gaze palsy.

questions.text: A patient is on phenytoin for a seizure disorder. He was prescribed sucralfate four times a day for peptic ulcer. What should be the minimum duration of time between consumption of these drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 120 minutes

 

Explanation:

  • In order to avoid reduced absorption of phenytoin due to its interaction with sucralfate, the two medications should be consumed at least 120 minutes apart from each other.
  • Sucralfate produces a viscous and sticky polymer in an acidic pH of the stomach.
  • It forms a protective layer over the ulcer craters and epithelial cells for up to 6 hours after a single dose.
  • This can hinder the absorption of other drugs; henc,e a minimum gap of 120 minutes must be maintained between ingestion of phenytoin and sucralfate.

 

Ulcer Protective Agents

 

Bismuth

Sucralfate

Properties

Water-soluble, but precipitates when pH <5

Basic aluminium salt of sulfated sucrose. Polymerises at pH <4, forming a sticky gel-like consistency.

Mechanism of Action
  • Increases production of gastric mucosal prostaglandin E, mucus, and bicarbonate.
  • Precipitate mucus glycoproteins and coat the ulcer base.
  • Detach and inhibit Helicobacter pylori directly.
  • Precipitates surface proteins at the ulcer base, creating a physical barrier against acid, pepsin, and bile.
  • Does not neutralise acid but delays gastric emptying.
  • Potentially augments gastric mucosal prostaglandin synthesis for additional protection.

Dosage and Administration

120 mg taken half an hour before the three major meals and at bedtime for 4-8 weeks

1 gram taken on an empty stomach one hour before the three major meals and at bedtime for 4-8 weeks

Side Effects
  • Diarrhoea,
  • Headache,
  • Dizziness,
  • Blackening of the tongue, dentures, and stools
  • Constipation
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Dry mouth
  • Nausea

Indications
  • gastritis and non-ulcer dyspepsia associated with H. pylori
  • Occasionally used as part of a triple-drug regimen.

Bile reflux, gastritis, and prophylaxis of stress ulcers.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an off-label use of risperidone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bipolar disorder

 

Explanation:

  • Risperidone is an FDA-approved treatment for Bipolar disorder.
  • Bipolar disorder is a mental health condition characterized by episodes of mania and depression.
  • Mania is a state of elevated mood, energy, and activity levels and may include symptoms such as grandiosity, reduced need for sleep, racing thoughts, and increased risk-taking behavior.
  • Depression is a mood disorder characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, loss of interest or pleasure in activities, and impairments in daily functioning.

 

Risperidone

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic medication that is approved by the FDA for the treatment of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder (both manic and mixed episodes)

MOA

Antagonism at D2 and 5 HT2 receptors

Also binds alpha 1 and 2 receptor, and the H1 receptor

Uses

FDA approved

  • Long-term management of psychosis and schizophrenia
  • Maintenance therapy in mania bipolar disorder
  • Management of irritability in autism spectrum disorder

 

Off label uses

  • Management of psychosis in delirium and dementia (Option B)
  • Obsessive-compulsive disorders (Option A)
  • PTSD (Option C)

Adverse effects
  • Hyperprolactinemia
  • Cardiovascular accident
  • Extrapyramidal side effects

questions.text: If the dosage of a drug following first-order kinetics is doubled, how would it affect the half-life and plasma concentration?

choices.text: Half-life doubles, and plasma concentration remains the same
Half-life remains the sam,e and plasma concentration doubles
Half-life and plasma concentration remain the same

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Half-life remains the same ,and plasma concentration doubles

 

Explanation:

If the dose of a drug following first-order kinetics is doubled, the half-like remains the same while the plasma concentration doubles.

 

 

First-order kinetics

Zero-order kinetics

Description

A constant fraction of the drug is eliminated per unit of time.

A constant amount of the drug is eliminated per unit of time.

Rate of clearance

Constant

More at lower concentrations and less at higher concentrations.

Half-life

Constant

Less at lower concentrations and more at higher concentrations.

Rate of elimination

Proportional to its plasma concentration.

Independent of plasma concentration.

Examples

Most of the drugs.

Alcohol, aspirin, theophylline, tolbutamide, and warfarin.

 

 

 

  • In first-order kinetics, doubling the dose of a drug leads to a doubling of its plasma concentration. However, the drug's half-life remains unchanged.
  • The half-life represents the time taken for the plasma concentration of the drug to decrease by half.
  • In this scenario, the rate of elimination increases proportionally with the increased dose, balancing the elevated plasma concentration.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases does not involve the use of antimicrobial combinations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Uncomplicated gonorrhea

 

Explanation:

  • According to CDC, uncomplicated gonorrhea is managed by a single drug therapy of IM injection of 500 mg of Ceftriaxone rather than the previously used dual therapy of ceftriaxone and azithromycin.
  • However, monotherapy should be given when concurrent chlamydia infection is ruled out; if not, presumptive treatment of chlamydia is also done by using oral Doxycyclin 100mg for 7 days.

 

Tuberculosis (Option B) is a bacterial infection that is typically treated with a combination of antibiotics. This is because TB bacteria can develop resistance to single antibiotics if used alone. The standard treatment for active TB includes a combination of isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol, taken for several months.

Intra-abdominal infections (Option C) are treated using antimicrobial combinations as the infection may be caused by a variety of bacteria. The combination of antibiotics used depends on the type of infection and the bacteria causing it. For example, in cases of complicated intra-abdominal infections, a combination of piperacillin-tazobactam plus metronidazole or cefotaxime plus metronidazole may be used.

Malaria (Option D) is treated with antimicrobial combinations, especially in areas where drug resistance is high. This is because using a single antimalarial drug can lead to the development of drug-resistant strains of the malaria parasite. Examples of antimalarial combinations include atovaquone-proguanil, artemether-lumefantrine, and mefloquine-artesunate.

questions.text: The dose at which dopamine acts on beta-1 receptors is _________?
questions.solution:

Stimulated D1 and D2 receptors, which increased blood flow to the renal and mesenteric vessels

2-5 mcg/kg/min

Dopamine acts on cardiac beta-1 receptors, which increases myocardial contractility. It is also used during cardiogenic shock.

5-15 mcg/kg/min

Dopamine acts on alpha-1 receptors to increase peripheral vascular resistance.

questions.text: A patient with a history of ischemic stroke was started on clopidogrel. However, she had another stroke after 6 months. Which of the following could be responsible for the failure of clopidogrel in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Reduced activity of CYP2C19

 

Explanation: 

Clopidogrel is a prodrug that requires activation by CYP2C19 to become an active antiplatelet medication thus, reduced activity of the CYP2C19 is most likely the reason for the failure of clopidogrel in this patien.t

 

Clopidogrel

Clopidogrel is a prodrug that requires activation by CYP2C19 to become an active antiplatelet drug.

Activation 
  • CYP2C19 is an enzyme found in the liver and is responsible for converting clopidogrel into its active form.
  • Certain genetic polymorphisms or drug interactions can lead to reduced activity of CYP2C19, and the activation of clopidogrel may be reduced

Uses 
  • Post Myocardial infarction
  • Post cerebrovascular accidents
  • Peripheral arterial diseases
  • Acute coronary syndrome

Adverse effects
  • Risk of bleeding if used with anticoagulants or antiplatelets
  • Rare - thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura

 

 

Enzyme

Substrate

CYP2D6

SSRIs, Opiates, Beta-blockers, tricyclic antidepressants

CYP1A1/2

Theophylline, Paracetamol, caffeine

CYP2E1

Alcohol, halothane, Paracetamol

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with epilepsy was put on Retigabine. Now phenytoin is being added. Which of the following changes should be made to Retigabine?

choices.text: Stop retigabine and start on Carbamazepine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Increase the dose

 

Explanation:

The dose of Retigabine should be increased when Phenytoin is added to the regimen because Phenytoin can decrease the plasma concentration of Retigabine via enzyme induction, which results in increased clearance of Retigabine.

 

Phenytoin induces CYP2C8/9 and CYP3A4/,5 which increases the metabolism of Retigabine.

  • Retigabine is a Potassium channel opener that enhances transmembrane potassium currents  mediated by KNCQ ion channels
  • It is metabolised by glucuronidation and acetylation
  • It has a t1/2 of 7-11 hours
  • Required thrice daily dosing
  • If given along with enzyme induces, its dose should be increased
  • Adverse effects
  • Urinary retention
  • Retinal abnormalities and Blue pigmentation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the selection of essential drugs?

choices.text: An adequate safety profile needs to be established
Cost to benefit has to be considered
Fixed drug combination is preferred over single drugs

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fixed drug combination is preferred over single drugs

 

Explanation:

During the selection of essential drugs, there is no preference for fixed drug combinations over single drugs.

 

WHO criteria forthe  selection of essential medicines are:

  • Adequate data on the safety and efficacy of the drug must be available
  • The drug should be available in a form where its quality and stability during storage is assured
  • Choice of drugs depends on
  • Patterns of prevalent diseases
  • Financial resources
  • Availability of trained personnel and facilities
  • Genetics, demography and environmental factors are also considered
  • Cost-to-benefit ratio
  • Pharmacokinetics of the drug
  • Local manufacturing and storage facilities
  • Essential drugs should preferably be a single compound.
  • The selection of essential drugs is a continuous process, and changes must be made with the development of public health and the availability of better drugs.

questions.text: Which of the following steps does Vancomycin act on?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 4

 

Explanation:

Vancomycin binds to the D-alanyl-D-alanine portion of peptidoglycan, which inhibits transglycosylase enzyme and reduces further elongation of peptidoglycan and cross-linking during the formation of the cell wall and this step is demonstrated by the 4th step in the above image.

 

Vancomycin 

MOA

Cell wall synthesis inhibitor

Binds to the D-alanyl-D-alanine portion of peptidoglycan, which inhibits transglycosylase enzyme and reduces further elongation of peptidoglycan and cross-linking during

Uses

Bactericidal agent against Gram +ve bacteria

  • Pseudomembranous colitis(oral)
  • MRSA
  • E. faecalis
  • Enterococcal endocarditis (Alternative therapy)

Resistance

Seen in enterococci - due to alteration in its binding side where D-ala is replaced by D-lactate

Adverse effects
  • Nephrotoxicity
  • Ototoxicity
  • Red man syndrome
  • Phlebitis

 

 

Step 1 (Option A) is inhibited by Fosfomycin via inhibition of enolpyruvyl transferase enzyme, which is involved in the synthesis of peptidoglycan precursors. This will prevent the formation of UDP-N-acetyl muramic acid, precursor of N-acetyl muramic acid

 

Step 2 (Option B) is inhibited by Cycloserine, which inhibits the formation of peptidoglycan cross-links by interfering with the synthesis of peptidoglycan. This will inhibit alanine racemase that converts L-alanine to D-alanine.

 

Step 3 (Option C) is inhibited by Bacitracin, which blocks the dephosphorylation of the lipid carrier and prevents the recycling of the carrier required for peptidoglycan synthesis.

questions.text:
The table given below gives the AUC of Drug B alone and that of Drug B when given along with Drug A. If the p-value is < 0.01, which of the following statements is true?

 


	
		
			
			Drugs
			
			
			Area under curve
			
		
		
			
			B
			
			
			570 seconds +/- 127 seconds
			
		
		
			
			B + A
			
			
			820 seconds +/- 124 seconds

choices.text: Drug A decreases intestinal absorption of Drug B
Drug A reduces the first-pass metabolism of Drug B
Drug A increases the metabolism of Drug B
Drug A increases renal elimination of Drug B

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Drug A reduces the first-pass metabolism of Drug B

 

Explanation: B

  • Based on the values given in the table and the p-value, Drug A reduces the first-pass metabolism of Drug B.
  • The area under the plot of plasma concentration of a drug vs time is known as the area under the curve (AUC). It can be used as a measure of the bioavailability of a drug and to calculate the clearance rate from the body.
  • The null hypothesis for the above question is that Drug A does not increase the AUC for Drug B, and for this to be tru, thee p-value should be > 0.05.
  • For the above drugs, since the p-value is <0.01, the null hypothesis is rejected, which means that Drug A has increased the AUC for Drug B.
  • Bioavailability of a drug: Percentage of the administered dose the that reaches its site of action. If the drug is metabolized largely in the liver and the intestine, the bioavailability is substantially reduced, and this is called first-pass metabolism
  • However, if the intestinal absorption of the drug is increased, the bioavailability will also increase.

 

So based on this, Drug A has either increased the intestinal absorption of Drug B, or it has reduced first-pass metabolism of Drug B.

questions.text: Anionic and weakly acidic drugs bind to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Albumin

 

Explanation:

  • Anionic and weakly acidic drugs bind to Albumin.
  • After absorption or injection of the drug into the bloodstream, the drug binds to plasma proteins, especially albumin and alpha-1- acid glycoprotein.
  • Albumin binds to acidic drugs such as Aspirin and Phenytoin (Option A)
  • Alpha-1 acid glycoprotein binds to basic drugs such as lignocaine, quinidine and propranolol (Option D).
  • Binding to plasma protein affects the distribution of the drug in the body.
  • Drugs bound to plasma protein are kept in the bloodstream and cannot cross membranes.
  • Unbound drugs can exit the bloodstream and enter target organs where they provide therapeutic effects, get metabolised and excreted.
  • Several drugs can displace other drugs bound to plasma protein, leading to increased pharmacological effects from the displaced drugs.

 

Globulin (Option B) are of three types - alpha, beta and gamma, and they can bind sex hormones and steroids.

 

Lipoprotein (Option C), like VLDL and LDL, can bind anticancer drugs such as 5-Fluorouracil and Doxorubicin.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of liver cirrhosis presents with abdominal distension and swelling of the lower limbs. What is the preferred diuretic for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Eplerenone

 

Explanation:

For a patient with liver cirrhosis presenting with ascites and peripheral edema, the preferred diuretic is Eplerenone.

 

Eplerenone

MOA

Mineralocorticoid receptor / Aldosterone antagonist resulting in natriuresis and reducing edema

Uses
  • Primary hyperaldosteronism leading to hypertension
  • Edema associated with liver cirrhosis, congestive cardiac failure and CKD
  • Reduced mortality in post-MI patients.

Use in cirrhosis
  • Patients with liver cirrhosis have reduced effective blood volume due to blood accumulation in the splanchnic vessels due to vasodilatation. This results in activation of RAAS and retention of salt and water - Ascites and resistance to loop diuretics.
  • Aldosterone enters the cells in the late DCT and Collecting ducts via diffusion and binds to specific mineralocorticoid receptors in the cellular cytosol, which mediates sodium reabsorption and potassium and H+ secretion into the tubules.
  • Eplerenone competitively blocks this MR receptor, resulting in natriuresis.

Side effects
  • Hyperkalemia
  • No anti-androgenic effects seen

 

Triamterene (Option A) directly inhibits renal epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) in the late distal tubule and collecting duct. It is a potassium-sparing diuretic and is generally used along with other diuretics in the treatment of hypertension and edema, as well as in the management of Liddle syndrome. It is metabolised in the liver hence triamterene toxicity may be enhanced in patients with hepatic disease.

 

Chlorthalidone (Option C) is a thiazide-like diuretic that inhibits the Na+-Cl symporter in the early distal tubule (Early DCT)and increases the excretion of sodium and chloride. Thiazide diuretics may be used for the treatment of hypertension, heart failure, nephrolithiasis due to idiopathic hypercalciuria, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

 

Furosemide (Option D) is a loop diuretic that inhibits Na+-K+-2Cl symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle ,resulting in increased excretion of sodium and chloride. It also has mild carbonic anhydrase inhibitory activity and also increases urinary excretion of bicarbonate and phosphate. Cirrhotic patients are often resistant to loop diuretics due to decreased secretion of the drug into tubular fluid and high aldosterone levels.

questions.text: A patient who was on warfarin therapy for atrial fibrillation is prescribed a Cephalosporin for the treatment of a lower respiratory tract infection. He comes back to the hospital after having developed hemarthrosis. Which of the following cephalosporins is likely to have caused this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cefoperazone

 

Explanation:

  • In a patient taking warfarin, the most likely Cephalosporine to cause hemarthrosis is Cefoperazone.
  • Cephalosporins containing a methylthiotetrazole (NMTT) group can prolong the prothrombin time, which causes clinically significant bleeding in patients already on anticoagulant therapy or having vitamin K deficiency.
  • NMTT cephalosporins inhibit the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase in the liver, which is the key enzyme for vitamin K-dependent carboxylation, which is essential for the biological activation of coagulation factors.
  • NMTT group containing cephalosporins include latamoxef, cefoperazone, cefotetan and cefamandole.
  • Vitamin K epoxide reductase is also the target of anticoagulants like warfarin thus, when a cephalosporin-containing NMTT group is given to a patient taking warfarin, it can lead to clinically significant bleeding such as Hearthrosis.
  • Oral administration of vitamin K can prevent this bleeding.

 

Cephalosporin and its uses

1st gen

2nd gen

3rd gen

4th gen

5th gen

Cephazolin

Cephalexin

Cefadroxil

Cefuroxime

Cefoxitin

Cefaclor

Cefprozil

Cefotaxime

Ceftizoxime

Ceftriaxone

Ceftazidime

Cefpodoxime proxetil

Cefdinir

Ceftibuten

Ceftamet pivoxil

Cefepime

Cefpirome

Ceftaroline

Ceftobiprole

First generation
  • ENT, upper respiratory & cutaneous infections
  • Surgical prophylaxis

Second generation
  • Mixed aerobic-anaerobic infections

 

 

Third generation
  • Ceftriaxone/Cefotaxime: empirical therapy for meningitis
  • Ceftazidime: Pseudomonas meningitis
  • STI : Gonorrhea, chancroid, syphilis
  • Enteric fever
  • Patients with neutropenia

Fourth generation
  • Nosocomial infections (intensive care borne)

 

Fifth generation
  • Penicillin resistant community acquired and hospital-acquired pneumonia by S.pneumoniae
  • Penicillinase-producing S.aureus infections
  • MRSA

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed eye symptom of COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Follicular conjunctivitis

 

Explanation:

Follicular conjunctivitis is the most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19.

 

Ocular manifestations of COVID-19:

Conjunctiva
  • Follicular conjunctivitis (Most common)
  • Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis
  • Pseudomembrane conjunctivitis

Sclera
  • Scleritis/ Episcleritis

Anterior chamber
  • Anterior Uveitis

Posterior segment
  • Acute macular neuroretinopathy
  • Purtscher-like retinopathy
  • Retinal arterial/venous occlusion (central/branched)

Optic nerve
  • Optic neuritis, optic disc edema

Orbit
  • Sinusitis, Preseptal/Orbital cellulitis

Lacrimal
  • Epiphora

Newborns
  • Periorbital edema (Most common manifestation in newborns)

questions.text: A 57-year-old man was brought to the hospital with complaints of dizziness and breathlessness. During the physical examination, his face appears to be discoloured. His current medication includes Amiodarone, Metoprolol, Verapamil, Lisinopril and Amlodipine. Which of the following drugs is responsible for these skin changes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Amiodarone

 

Explanation:

  • The grey-blue discolouration over this patient's face is most likely due to Amiodarone. Long-term treatment with amiodarone is responsible for skin pigmentation.
  • Ultraviolet light reacts with amiodarone and its metabolites to cause local vasodilatation.
  • This increases the diffusion of amiodarone and its metabolites, resulting in their deposition in the tissues and causing pigmentation.
  • It is usually seen in sun-exposed areas ,and elderly men are at an increased risk.
  • Cessation of amiodarone and avoiding exposure to sunlight using sunscreen cream is recommended.

 

Amiodarone

MOA 
  • Prolonged action potential duration and QT interval by blocking delayed rectifier K+ channels.
  • Blocks inactivated Na+ channels, with rapid channel recovery (Decrease phase 0 slope).
  • Partially inhibits myocardial Ca2+ channels, adding to its antiarrhythmic effects.
  • Used to treat both atrial and ventricular fibrillation

Uses

To maintain normal sinus rhythm during atrial fibrillation and prevent recurrent ventricular tachycardia.

Adverse effects
  • Hypotension and Bradycardia (with i.v administration or after drug accumulation)
  • Photosensitivity: Skin pigmentation - Purple colour (purple man syndrome, smurf syndrome)
  • Corneal microdeposits: Reversible upon drug discontinuation.
  • Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis (On long-term use)
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Thyroid Dysfunction: Interfere with thyroid function as it acts as a source of iodine and can potentially lead to goitre, hypothyroidism (Wolf Chaikoff effect), or, in rare cases, hyperthyroidism (Jos-Basedow effect).

Interactions
  • Inhibits CYP3A4, CYP2C9, and P-glycoprotein, leading to potential interactions with drugs metabolized by this system.
  • Increases plasma levels of digoxin and warfarin.
  • Additive AV block with beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers.

questions.text: A breast cancer patient post-chemotherapy developed a low-grade fever with anemia and leukocytopenia (<4000/cm3; DNC: 30). Which of the following antibiotics will not be used in the empirical management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Linezolid

 

Explanation:

Linezolid cannot be used in this patient due to the drug's side effect of causing bone marrow suppressio,n which can worsen the post-chemotherapy bone marrow suppression in this patient.

 

Linezolid

MOA

Protein synthesis inhibitor of the class oxazolidinones

  • Attaches to a site on the bacterial 23S ribosomal RNA of the 50S subunit
  • Prevents the formation of a functional 70S initiation complex.
  • It mainly acts against gram-positive organisms

Uses
  • Skin and skin structure infections by staphylococcus and streptococcus.
  • ﻿﻿Community-acquired pneumonia due to streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • ﻿﻿Nosocomial pneumonia due to staphylococcus aureus.

Adverse effects
  • Inhibits mitochondrial protein synthesis and may lead to
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Optic neuritis
  • Lactic acidosis in patients receiving the drug for longer durations.
  • ﻿﻿Serotonin syndrome when coadministered with adrenergic or serotonergic drugs like SSRIs due to its nonspecific MAO inhibition.
  • Linezolid can cause myelosuppression, which can present as
  • Anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Leukopenia
  • Sometimes pancytopenia.
  • It usually occurs 7-10 days after administration of the drug and is usually reversed on discontinuation of the drug.

 

Cefepime (Option A) is a fourth-generation antipseudomonal cephalosporin. It is useful in enterobacter and pseudomonas infections that are resistant to other cephalosporins and it does not cause myelosuppression.

 

Piperacillin-Tazobactam (Option B) is a combination of piperacillin, which is a ureidopenicillin, and tazobactam, which is a beta-lactamase inhibitor. It is useful in various infection,s including nosocomial infections, intraabdominal infections, pneumonia, and UTI. It does not cause myelosuppression; thus, it can be used with this patient.

 

Meropenem (Option D) belongs to the carbapenem group of beta-lactam antibiotics. They are more active against gram-negative organisms. It does not cause myelosuppression; thus, it can be used with this patient.

questions.text: Which of the following medications should not be administered to a patient with a known case of angle closure glaucoma who has also been diagnosed with major depressive disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Amitriptyline

 

Explanation:

Amitriptyline, a Tricyclic Antidepressant (TCA) should not be administered to a known case of Angle closure glaucoma due to its antagonistic action on M1 (Muscarinic) receptor.

 

Amitriptyline:

  • MOA: Primarily blocks Serotonin (5HT3) and Norepinephrine (NE) reuptake; also has additional blocking action on ɑ1 (adrenergic), H1 (Histamine) and M1 (Muscarinic) receptors.
  • ADRs: Orthostatic hypotension, GI disturbances, seizures, increases risk of suicidal thoughts, sexual dysfunction.
  • Contraindication: Angle closure glaucoma

 

Common drugs contraindicated in Angle closure glaucoma patients:

Anti-Muscarinic
  • Ipratropium bromide, Thiotropium bromide (M1)
  • Toletrodine, Oxybutinin (M3)
  • Scopolamine (M1)

Anti-Histaminics
  • Diphenhydramine, Fexofenadine (H1)
  • Cimetidine, Ranitidine (H2)

Migraine drugs
  • Sumatriptan

Anti-depressants
  • SNRI: Duloxetine and Milnacipram
  • TCA: Amitryptiline

Anti-Epileptics
  • Topiramate, Zonisamide

Antibiotics
  • Trimethoprim-Sulfametoxazole (Cotrimoxazole)

questions.text: Which organism is most likely causing the infection in a 14-day-old neonate with bilateral conjunctivitis and lung infiltrates, as found in a chest X-ray performed at the outpatient department?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chlamydia trachomatis

 

Explanation:

A 14-day-old neonate with Bilateral conjunctivitis and pneumonia-like presentation is suggestive of Chlamydia trachomatis infection. Neonatal conjunctivitis is also known as Ophthalmia neonatorum.

 

Ophthalmia neonatorum:



 

Definition

  • Ophthalmia neonatorum or neonatal conjunctivitis is a mucoid, mucopurulent, or purulent discharge from one or both eyes in the first month of life.
  • Any discharge, even watery, from a baby’s eyes in the first week of life must be viewed under suspicion as tears are not secreted so early in life.






 

Aetiology of ophthalmia neonatorum

Mode of infection:

  • Before birth:
    • Very rare through infected liquor amnii
  • During birth:
    • From an infected birth canal
  • After birth:
    • During the first bath of a newborn
    • Soiled clothes
    • Fingers with infected lochia
 

Source of infection:

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae:
    • Transmitted at the time of delivery
    • Presents between 2-5 days of birth (Option B)
    • The discharge becomes mucopurulent and purulent quickly
    • Thick yellow pus and marked chemosis
    • Cornea seen at the bottom of a crater-like pit in severe cases
 
  • Chlamydia trachomatis:
    • Transmitted at the time of delivery
    • Onset at 5-14 days after birth (Option C)
    • Serotypes D to K are the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries
    • Characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies are seen
    • Less severe inflammation
    • Purulent discharge +
 
  • Other causes:
    • Staphylococci/ Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option A)
    • Gram-negative coliforms
    • Herpes simplex virus
    • Chemical: silver nitrate solution previously used for prophylaxis immediately after birth: erythema, chemosis, lid edema, and discharge within the first 24 hours after birth.
 

Prophylaxis

  • Antenatal measures:
    • Treatment of genital infections and care of mother
    • Surveillance of pregnant women for STDs
  • Natal measures:
    • Aseptic, sterile precautions to be followed during deliveries
    • Clean the infant’s closed lids with sterile cotton soaked in normal saline and dried
  • Post-natal measures:
    • Povidone-iodine 2.5% solution
    • If the mother is under suspicion, 1% tetracycline or 0.5% erythromycin eye ointment is used in the baby immediately after birth and watched for a week.
    • Ceftriaxone 50mg/kg IM or IV single dose for infants born to mothers with untreated gonococcal infection.
  • Crede’s method:
    • Old method using 1% silver nitrate applied to infants' eyes right after birth
    • It is NOT used now as it can cause chemical neonatal conjunctivitis.

Diagnosis

Treatment

Neisseria gonorrhoea

Ceftriaxone IM, gentamicin drops, bacitracin eye ointment

Chemical

Wash eyes, erythromycin ointment, observe

Other bacteria

Neomycin-bacitracin ointment, gentamicin, or tobramycin drops

Herpes simplex virus

Acyclovir 3% eye ointment, systemic acyclovir (systemic involvement)

Chlamydia trachomatis

Erythromycin or chlortetracycline eye ointment, oral erythromycin (systemic infection)

 

Incorrect options:

Streptococci (Option A) and Mycoplasma (Option D): Though they can cause conjunctivitis and pneumonia, it is very rare in the case of a newborn.

questions.text: The chart depicted in the image is ______?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hess chart

 

Explanation:

The image in the question shows Hess chart, used for measuring degree of Malalignment in Squint/Starbismus, but it cannot be used to differentiate between Paralytic and Restrictive squint.

Incorrect options:

Snellen Chart (Option B): This is the traditional eye examination tool used worldwide for assessing Visual acuity.

Pelli-Robson Chart (Option C): This chart is a specific tool used to measure Contrast sensitivity.

ETDRS Chart (Option D): Standing for Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study, (also known as the LogMAR chart) this chart is a standardized tool used for testing visual acuity more precisely than the Snellen chart, particularly useful in research settings and monitoring progression of diseases like diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not likely to be seen in a patient with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Leukemia

 

Explanation:

Leukaemia is not likely to be seen in a patient with Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH).

 

  • It is a rare acquired hematopoietic stem cell disorder characterized by a deficiency of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins on the surface of blood cells, particularly red blood cells.
  • PNH blood cells are deficient in three GPI-linked proteins that regulate complement activity:
  • CD55 (decay-accelerating factor)
  • CD59 (membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis)
  • C8-binding protein.
  • Pathogenesis:
  • It results from acquired mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA), an enzyme that is essential for the synthesis of certain membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins.
  • Clinical features:
  • It causes intravascular hemolysis and anaemia.  (Option D ruled out)
  • Haemoglobinuria (red-brown colour) (most noticeable in early morning urine)
  • Hypoplastic bone marrow failure, aplastic anaemia (Option A ruled out), thrombosis  (Option C ruled out), and myelodysplastic syndrome
  • Management
  • Transfusion
  • Folate supplements
  • Prophylaxis or treatment of thrombosis
  • Anti-complement C5 monoclonal antibody.

questions.text: In cystic fibrosis, which of the following structures is affected in the pancreas?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) B

 

Explanation:

"B" represents the acini, the functional units of the exocrine pancreas that produce and secrete digestive enzymes into the pancreatic ducts, and these are affected in Cystic Fibrosis, an autosomal recessive genetic disorder.

 

Pathogenesis:

  • It is caused by mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene, resulting in a defect in the production or function of the CFTR protein.
  • This leads to thick, sticky mucus forming in various organs, including the pancreas.
  • In the pancreas, the defective CFTR protein affects the secretion of chloride ions and water, dehydrating pancreatic secretions.
  • This thickened mucus obstructs the pancreatic ducts, preventing the proper flow of digestive enzymes from the acini into the duodenum. (Option B)
  • Consequently, there is a reduction in the production and release of pancreatic enzymes, leading to impaired digestion and malabsorption of nutrients.

 

Clinical features:

 

Respiratory system

Gastrointestinal and hepatic

Others
  • Progressive airway obstruction
  • Infective exacerbations of bronchiectasis
  • Respiratory failure
  • Spontaneous pneumothorax
  • Haemoptysis
  • Lobar collapse due to secretions
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Nasal polyps
  • Malabsorption and steatorrhoea
  • Distal intestinal obstruction syndrome
  • Biliary cirrhosis
  • Portal hypertension, varices, and splenomegaly
  • Gallstones
  • Diabetes
  • Delayed puberty,
  • Male infertility
  • Stress incontinence due to repeated forced cough
  • Psychosocial problems
  • Osteoporosis
  • Arthropathy
  • Cutaneous vasculitis

 

A (Option A) is the islets of Langerhans, responsible for the production and secretion of hormones such as insulin and glucagon. It is not the target of cystic fibrosis.

 

C (Option C) is the intralobular duct, which is part of the pancreatic duct system and plays a role in transporting pancreatic enzymes. It is not the target of cystic fibrosis.

 

D (Option D) is the interlobular duct that transports pancreatic secretions and is not the target of cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: The human papillomavirus inactivates the Rb gene by which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) E7

 

Explanation:

  • The human papillomavirus (HPV) inactivates the retinoblastoma (RB) gene primarily through the action of the E7 protein.
  • The E7 protein of high-risk HPV types, such as HPV-16 and HPV-18, promotes cell cycle progression by inactivating the retinoblastoma protein (p105Rb).
  • E7 binds to p105Rb, disrupting its interaction with the E2F transcription factor, which releases E2F to activate genes essential for cell cycle progression and DNA replication.
  • Consequently, the cell cycle becomes dysregulated, and uncontrolled cell proliferation can occur, a hallmark of HPV-associated cancers.
  • High-risk HPV types (HPV 16, 18): High-grade cervical dysplasia and invasive cancer.
  • Low-risk HPV types (HPV 6, 11): Genital warts (condyloma acuminatum and low-grade changes in cervical cells).

 

Oncogenic Activities of E6 Protein

(Option A ruled out)

Oncogenic Activities of E7 Protein

(Option B)
  • Binds to and promotes degradation of p53 → Impairs cell growth and apoptosis regulation.
  • Stimulates expression of TERT (telomerase reverse transcriptase) → Facilitates cellular immortalisation by maintaining telomere length.
  • Disrupts interaction between RB protein and E2F transcription factors
  • Inactivates CDK inhibitors (e.g., p21 and p27).
  • Activates cyclins A and E 

 

 

 

L1 (Option C) protein is the major capsid protein of HPV and plays a role in the virus particle assembly.

 

L2 (Option D) protein is a capsid protein of HPV, which assists in entering the viral DNA into the host cell during infection.

questions.text: Which of the following oil red O stain is used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Frozen section

 

Explanation:

  • Oil Red O stain is commonly used in frozen sections to detect the presence of lipids, particularly neutral lipids such as triglycerides.
  • It is a lipophilic dye that selectively stains lipids within cells or tissues.
  • It binds to the neutral lipid droplets and produces a bright red colour when examined under a microscope.

 

  • This stain is particularly useful in identifying lipid accumulation in various tissues and organs, including adipose tissue, liver, muscle, and atherosclerotic plaques.
  • Frozen sections are typically used for rapid intraoperative diagnosis or for research purposes.

 

Formalin fixation (Option A) refers to the preservation of tissue samples using formaldehyde solutions, leading to the cross-linking of proteins and modification of lipid structures, which may interfere with the staining properties of Oil Red O.

 

Alcohol fixation (Option C) involves the preservation of tissues using alcohol-based solutions, such as ethanol or methanol. It can also alter the structure of lipids, affecting the staining properties of Oil Red O.

 

Glutaraldehyde fixation (Option D) is typically used for electron microscopy studies. It may lead to changes in lipid composition and affect the staining properties of Oil Red O.

questions.text: An electron microscopic picture of a cut section of a nerve fibre is given. Identify the area that will be affected by the most common variant of Guillain-Barre syndrome.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2

 

Explanation:

The myelin sheath labelled "2" is the most common variant affected in Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS).

 

Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS)
