A group of immune-mediated disorders causing acute paralysis, clinically characterized by weakness starting in the distal limbs and quickly progressing to involve proximal muscle function, resulting in "ascending paralysis”.

Variants

Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP)

  • The most common variant is in Europe & North America.
  • Patchy segmental demyelination of spinal cord and peripheral nerves
  • Antibodies seen:
  • IgG Anti GM1
  • IgG Anti GQ1b

 

Axonal Variants

  • Often associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.
  • More prevalent in China and Japan.

 

Miller Fisher Syndrome

  • Best-recognised variant.
  • Associated with anti-GQ1b antibodies.
  • Presents with internal and external ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia

Clinical features

Motor Symptoms:

  • Progressive ascending paralysis (distal to proximal)
  • Areflexia
  • Weakness in legs causing rubbery legs and instability to stand
  • Truncal paralysis, quadriplegia, neck floppiness
  • Bilateral 7th nerve palsy
  • Bulbar palsy
  • Difficulty in handling secretions leading to aspiration pneumonia
  • A leading cause of death due to pulmonary involvement.
  • Diaphragmatic paralysis
  • Ventilatory support is required in 30% of cases.
  • Increased carbon dioxide levels.

 

Sensory Symptoms:

  • Glove-and-stocking distribution paresthesias
  • Proprioception loss
  • Difficulty in climbing stairs
  • Pain in the neck/arm/shoulder is similar to over-exercised muscle
  • Sensory manifestations can occur before or along with motor manifestations.

 

Autonomic Symptoms:

  • Autonomic dysregulation (e.g., orthostatic hypotension, bladder/bowel sparing/transient involvement)
  • Wide fluctuations of blood pressure, arrhythmias, postural hypotension
  • Reduced heart rate and blood pressure, neurogenic shock.

Investigations

Lumbar Puncture

  • CSF protein: 100-1000 mg/dL
  • Elevated CSF protein but normal WBC count (albuminocytologic dissociation)

CSF Study Timing

  • Normal CSF findings (<48 hours)
  • Maximum rise of protein seen by 7 days

Electrodiagnostic Testing

  • Prolonged F-wave latencies
  • Earliest finding in AIDP (Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy)

 

1 (Option A) indicates Schwann cells, which are the supporting cells of the peripheral nervous system and play a crucial role in forming the myelin sheath around the axons. While Schwann cells can be involved in GBS, they are not the primary site of damage in the most common variant, acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy (AIDP).

 

3 (Option C) indicates an axon, whose damage can occur in GBS. It is more commonly associated with variants such as acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN) or acute motor-sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN). In the most common AIDP variant, the primary pathology is focused on the myelin sheath rather than the axon itself.

 

4 (Option D) indicates mesaxon, i.e., the region where the inner and outer layers of the Schwann cell membrane meet. It is involved in the formation of the myelin sheath. Although the mesaxon can be affected in GBS, it is not the primary area of damage in the most common AIDP variant.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient was diagnosed with iron deficiency anaemia. Which of the following is true about the intracellular regulation of iron in the above condition?

choices.text: Ferritin translation is increased by binding IRP to IRE
Ferritin translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE
Transferrin receptor 1 translation is unaffected by binding IRP to IRE
Transferrin receptor 1 translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ferritin translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE

 

Explanation:

In iron deficiency anaemia, ferritin translation is decreased by binding iron regulatory protein to iron response elements.

 

Iron regulatory mechanism:

  • IRP: Binds to IREs in specific mRNAs' untranslated regions (UTRs) to control the translation of proteins involved in iron metabolism.
  • IRE: These are sequences found in the mRNAs of proteins involved in iron metabolism, such as ferritin and transferrin receptor 1
  • Ferritin: Ferritin stores iron inside cells. When iron levels are low, IRPs bind to IREs in the 5' UTR of ferritin mRNA, preventing its translation to conserve iron.
  • Transferrin receptor 1 (TfR1): TfR1 imports iron into cells.
  • When intracellular iron levels are low, IRP binds to the IRE in the ferritin mRNA, preventing its translation.
  • This leads to a decrease in the production of ferritin, which helps conserve iron and prevent its storage when it is limited.

 

Ferritin translation is increased by binding IRP to IRE (Option A): In iron deficiency anaemia, the binding of IRP to the IRE in the mRNA of ferritin leads to a decrease in ferritin translation to conserve iron and prevents its storage when it is limited.

 

Transferrin receptor 1 translation is unaffected by binding IRP to IRE (Option C): In iron deficiency, IRP binds to the IRE in the mRNA of TfR1, stabilizing the mRNA and increasing its translation, resulting in an increased production of TfR1, which enhances the uptake of iron into cells to compensate for the deficiency.

 

Transferrin receptor 1 translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE (Option D): In iron deficiency anaemia, the binding of IRP to the IRE in the mRNA of TfR1 leads to an increased translation of TfR1, facilitating the increased uptake of iron into cells to overcome the deficiency.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with massive splenomegaly, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aplastic anemia

 

Explanation:

Massive splenomegaly, often linked to haematological disorders, is not typically associated with Aplastic Anemia, a bone marrow failure condition characterized by reduced production of blood cells.

 

Aplastic Anemia

It refers to a syndrome of chronic primary hematopoietic failure and attendant pancytopenia.

Cause 

Acquired

  • Idiopathic
  • Acquired stem cell defects
  • Immune-mediated

Chemical agents

  • Dose-related (Alkylating agents, antimetabolites, benzene, chloramphenicol, inorganic arsenicals)
  • Idiosyncratic (Chloramphenicol, phenylbutazone, organic arsenicals, methylphenylethylhydantoin, carbamazepine, penicillamine, gold salts)

Physical agents

  • Whole-body irradiation
  • Viral infections
  • Hepatitis (unknown virus)
  • Cytomegalovirus infections
  • Epstein-Barr virus infections
  • Herpes zoster (varicella zoster)

Inherited

  • Fanconi anemia
  • Telomerase defects

Pathogenesis

The pathogenesis of aplastic anaemia is not fully understood. However, two major etiologies have been invoked:

  • Extrinsic (immune-mediated suppression of marrow progenitors)
  • Intrinsic (abnormality of stem cells)

Clinical features
  • Onset: Insidious.
  • Pancytopenia
  • Anaemia (progressive weakness, pallor, and dyspnea)
  • Thrombocytopenia (petechiae and ecchymoses)
  • Neutropenia (frequent and persistent infections or the sudden onset of chills, fever, and prostration).
  • Splenomegaly is absent (Option B)
  • The red cells are usually slightly macrocytic and normochromic.

Microscopy
  • Hypocellular bone marrow is largely devoid of hematopoietic cells; often, only fat cells, fibrous stroma, and scattered lymphocytes and plasma cells remain.
  • Marrow aspirates often yield little material (a “dry tap”).

 

 

 

Chronic myeloid leukaemia (Option A): Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis often results in significant splenomegaly. Bone marrow findings typically include hypercellularity, an increased myeloid-to-erythroid ratio, and the presence of dwarf megakaryocytes. Additionally, sea-blue histiocytes, also known as pseudo-Gaucher cells, may be observed in the marrow.

 

 

 

Hairy cell leukaemia (Option C) presents with fatigue, recurrent infections, easy bruising, and symptoms related to splenomegaly, such as early satiety and abdominal discomfort, along with pancytopenia. Peripheral smear typically shows "hairy cells" with round, oblong, or reniform nuclei and pale blue cytoplasm. Bone marrow findings often reveal hypocellular or fibrotic marrow with "hairy cells" and a characteristic "fried egg" appearance.

 

 

Lymphoma (Option D) is cancer that originates in the lymphatic system, part of the immune system, and involves the uncontrolled growth of lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell). It can present with splenomegaly. The two main types are Hodgkin lymphoma (HL), characterized by Reed-Sternberg cells, and Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL).

questions.text: A patient with cirrhosis and ascites presented to you. The gross appearance of his liver is shown below. Which of the following is true about it?

choices.text: Dark areas represent necrosis, white areas represent viable liver
Dark areas represent viable liver tissue, white areas represent necrosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dark areas represent necrosis, white areas represent viable liver

 

Explanation:

The scenario of Cirrhosis and ascites, along with the image, shows dark areas indicating necrosis and white areas representing viable liver tissue.

  • It is a chronic liver disease characterized by fibrosis and nodular regeneration of the liver parenchyma.
  • Causes: Chronic alcohol abuse, viral hepatitis, or metabolic disorders.
  • Pathogenesis:
  • Morphology: The liver undergoes significant remodelling, destroying its normal architecture and the formation of fibrous bands. The dark areas indicate necrosis (cellular damage and blood congestion), while the white areas represent viable liver tissue with functional hepatocytes.  (Option B, C, and D ruled out)

 

  • Microscopy: Thick bands of collagen separate rounded cirrhotic nodules (Masson's trichrome stain is commonly used to visualise collagen fibres).

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of dyspnea on exertion for 1 month. Echocardiography showed the presence of mitral stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy. Identify the histopathological finding given below and the probable diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Aschoff body; Rheumatic heart disease

 

Explanation:

  • The given scenario, featuring dyspnea on exertion for one month, mitral stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy, along with histopathological evidence of Aschoff bodies, is consistent with a diagnosis of Rheumatic Heart Disease (RHD).
  • It is caused by an autoimmune reaction following a Group A Streptococcus infection.
  • Predisposing factor: Acute Rheumatic fever typically occurs 2-3 weeks after the onset of Streptococcal pharyngitis (Group A beta-hemolytic Streptococci).
  • Pathogenesis:  Acute rheumatic fever (ARF) results from an immune response to group A streptococcal antigens, particularly the M proteins, which can cross-react with host proteins, including cardiac self-antigens. This molecular mimicry produces antibodies and activates CD4+ T cells that ultimately cause inflammation and tissue damage, particularly in the heart.
  • Histopathological findings: Involve changes in the heart valves due to chronic inflammation and scarring. They include:
  • Aschoff bodies: Consist of areas of chronic inflammation infiltrated with lymphocytes, plasma cells, and activated macrophages or histiocytes known as Anitshkow cells.
  • Anitshkow cells: These are activated macrophages with a characteristic “caterpillar-like appearance” due to the presence of a central, slender and wavy nucleus.
  • Fibrinoid necrosis results from the deposition of fibrin and inflammatory cells and is seen in areas of the valves affected by inflammation.

 

 

Complications of RHD:

  • Valvular stenosis and regurgitation
  • Heart failure
  • Arrhythmias, particularly atrial fibrillation in the setting of mitral stenosis
  • Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH)
  • Recurrence of acute rheumatic fever
  • Cardio-embolic stroke
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Infective endocarditis
  • Ruptured heart valve.

 

Calcification of valve; Mitral stenosis (Option B): Mitral stenosis is a narrowing of the mitral valve opening, caused by valve calcification, which restricts blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle, leading to symptoms such as shortness of breath, fatigue, and heart palpitations.

 

 

 

Granuloma; Sarcoidosis (Option C): Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory condition marked by the development of granulomas. While the exact cause remains unknown, it is thought to result from an abnormal immune response, potentially triggered by genetic and environmental factors. Histologically, it presents with non-caseating granuloma or naked granuloma (lymphocytic collar absent). Asteroid bodies (stellate, pink-staining inclusions in giant cells) are commonly found but not specific.

 

 

Non-caseating granuloma; Tuberculosis (Option D): Tuberculosis is a bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, characterized histologically by a granulomatous inflammatory response with both caseating and non-caseating tubercles.

questions.text: A child presented with bilateral proptosis. From the peripheral smear, he was suspected to have chloroma. What is the next investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bone marrow biopsy

 

Explanation:

  • The next investigation of choice for a child suspected to have Chloroma (also known as Granulocytic Sarcoma or Myeloblastoma) is a bone marrow biopsy.
  • It is a localized extramedullary myeloid tumour composed of immature myeloid cells, which can occur in patients with acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) or myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS).
  • It is not a benign tumour, but it has a greenish colour.
  • Site: Soft tissue involvement in orbit leads to proptosis.
  • Associated with AML M2 and M5.
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Confirms the diagnosis by revealing the presence of abnormal myeloid cells infiltrating the bone marrow. (Option D)

 

 

  • Peripheral smear findings:
  • Myeloblasts.
  • Arbiskov cells: Atypical monocytes/macrophages.
  • Markers: MPO (green colour), CD 43, CD 45 and Lysozyme.

 

 

 

Platelet count (Option A), WBC count (Option B) and Flow cytometry (Option C) might be done but they do not confirm the diagnosis of chloroma.

questions.text: Below is an electron microscopic image of lung tissue. A patient infected with SARS-CoV2 presents with ARDS. The infection would affect and expand in which of the following labelled layers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A

 

Explanation:

In the electron microscopic image of the lung tissue, the structure labelled "A" represents the endothelium, where SARS-CoV-2 infection would impact and cause expansion.

  • It is the virus causing COVID-19.
  • It leads to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
  • Mechanism: The virus can directly infect the endothelial cells that line the blood vessels in the lungs, disrupting the normal function and integrity of the endothelial cells, resulting in increased vascular permeability, inflammation, and the onset of pulmonary edema. (Option B)

 

Layer B (Option A) represents the basal lamina, which offers structural support to the epithelial cells and separates them from the underlying connective tissue. However, it is not the primary site of infection in SARS-CoV-2-related ARDS.

 

Layer D (Option C) represents epithelium that lines the airways and plays a key role in the respiratory system's defence mechanisms. However, it is not the primary target in SARS-CoV-2-related ARDS, where the main pathological changes occur in the endothelium.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the effect of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is correct?


	Decrease in reduced glutathione
	Decrease NADPH
	Decreased lipid peroxidation
	Decreased RBC membrane damage
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1 & 2 are correct

 

Explanation:

1 & 2 statements are correct regarding Glucose-6-phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) Deficiency.

  • It is an X-linked recessive disorder.
  • Pathogenesis:
  1. It is characterized by a deficiency in the G6PD enzyme, which protects red blood cells from oxidative damage.
  2. This reduces the ability to generate NADPH (Statement 2) via the pentose phosphate pathway and impairs glutathione regeneration (Statement 1), exacerbating oxidative stress and hemolysis.
  3. When exposed to oxidative stressors, there is an imbalance between the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and antioxidants that neutralize them.
  4. This leads to oxidative damage to red blood cell membranes and proteins, resulting in hemolysis. (Statement 4)

 

 

 

  • Clinical features:
  1. Episodes of acute hemolytic anaemia triggered by oxidative stressors such as infections, certain medications (e.g., antimalarials, sulfonamides), or ingestion of certain foods (e.g., fava beans).
  2. Fatigue, pallor, jaundice, and dark urine (due to hemoglobinuria).
  • The severity of hemolysis varies depending on the degree of enzyme deficiency and the magnitude of the oxidative insult, with some individuals experiencing life-threatening hemolytic crises.
  • G6PD deficiency causes both intra and extravascular hemolysis.

 

Decreased lipid peroxidation (Statement 3): G6PD deficiency does not directly lead to a reduction in lipid peroxidation. On the contrary, it can increase susceptibility to oxidative stress and the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS). The reduced levels of NADPH and glutathione in G6PD deficiency impair the cell's antioxidant defence mechanisms, resulting in enhanced lipid peroxidation and oxidative damage.

questions.text: A 20-year-old athlete suddenly collapsed while playing football and was taken to the hospital, where he was declared dead. His autopsy image is given below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death?

choices.text: Valvular heart disease due to RHD
Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia
Sudden cardiac death due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
Sudden cardiac death due to atherosclerosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sudden cardiac death due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

 

Explanation:

The autopsy image reveals signs of cardiac hypertrophy, indicating hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) as a likely cause of death, which is a common contributor to Sudden Cardiac Death (SCD) in young athletes due to abnormal thickening of the heart muscle, particularly in the left ventricle.

 

Sudden Cardiac Death (SCD)

Sudden Cardiac Death (SCD) is defined as unexpected death occurring within an hour of symptom onset due to cardiac causes, including unwitnessed deaths in individuals who seemed healthy within the last 24 hours.

Risk Factors
  • Structural Heart Disease: The presence of structural heart issues or inherited arrhythmia syndromes significantly increases SCD risk.
  • Major Risk Factors:
  • Coronary Heart Disease (CHD)
  • Heart Failure
  • Diabetes
  • Hypertension
  • Smoking
  • Family History of SCD

 

In Athletes

  • Younger Athletes: The leading causes of SCD are inherited cardiac conditions, particularly Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM). (Option C)
  • Older Athletes: Risks are primarily associated with atherosclerotic coronary artery disease (CAD).

Precipitating Factors
  • SCD and Sudden Cardiac Arrest (SCA) frequently occur at specific times (e.g., mornings, winter months) and in public places.
  • Vigorous exertion, especially in men, can trigger SCD; however, regular exercise may reduce this risk.

Underlying Heart Disease
  • The most common cause of SCD is Ventricular fibrillation
  • Many SCD cases are linked to coronary artery disease (CAD), but non-ischemic cardiomyopathies and other heart conditions also contribute.
  • Common mechanisms leading to SCD include:
  • Acute Myocardial Infarction
  • Bradyarrhythmias
  • Ventricular scars leading to arrhythmias

 

Commotio Cordis

  • Commotio cordis is a specific cause of SCD, often resulting from an impact to the left chest by a hard object, such as a baseball, during sports. This can induce ventricular fibrillation and cardiac arrest in an otherwise structurally normal heart.

 

Valvular heart disease due to RHD (Option A): The autopsy image shows no significant abnormalities in the heart valves, excluding valvular heart disease as the cause of death. RHD, which results from untreated or inadequately treated streptococcal infections, leads to inflammation and scarring of the heart valves. However, typical signs of RHD, such as thickened or damaged valves, are not observed in this image.

 

Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia (Option B): Sudden cardiac death (SCD) is an unexpected and rapid loss of heart function, typically caused by a life-threatening arrhythmia. In athletes, the most frequent cause of SCD is hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), which is characterized by abnormal thickening of the heart muscle.

 

Sudden cardiac death due to atherosclerosis (Option D): Atherosclerosis involves the accumulation of plaques in the arteries, which narrows and restricts blood flow. Although atherosclerosis can lead to heart attacks and sudden cardiac death, the autopsy image shows no signs of significant plaque buildup or obstruction in the coronary arteries.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presented with intussusception and was taken up for surgery. He was found to have multiple polyps. The resected section was sent for histopathology, and the whole mount image of the specimen is given below. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hamartomatous polyp

 

Explanation:

  • The histopathological image reveals a Hamartomatous Polyps, characterized by an arborizing pattern of connective tissue, smooth muscle, glands, and lamina propria.
  • They are non-neoplastic growths resulting from the disorganized overgrowth of normal tissues within an organ.
  • These polyps are often associated with genetic syndromes, including:

 

Features

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS)

Juvenile polyposis syndrome (JPS)

Inheritance pattern

Autosomal dominant disorder

Autosomal dominant inheritance

Age

Presents around 11 years of age

Primarily affects children under 5 years old.

Features
  • Caused by a loss of function mutation in the STK11 gene 
  • Characterized by:
  • Gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps, especially in the small intestine
  • Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation (macules on lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, and extremities).
  • Polyps are large, pedunculated, and lobulated.
  • Can be sporadic or syndromic.
  • Sporadic: Single polyps.
  • Syndromic: 3-100 polyps.
  • Linked to mutations in the SMAD4 and BMPR1A genes, part of the TGF-β signalling pathway.
  • Pedunculated polyp, which is usually less than 3 cm in diameter.
  • Extra-intestinal manifestations include congenital malformations and digital clubbing. 
Microscopy

An arborizing pattern of smooth muscle and glands lined by normal epithelium.

Contains cystic spaces filled with mucin and inflammatory debris.

 

 

Tubulovillous adenoma (Option A) is a premalignant lesion featuring both tubular and villous components, with the potential to progress to adenocarcinoma. However, the image does not display the typical characteristics of a tubulovillous adenoma, such as dysplasia or dysplastic cells within the epithelial lining.

 

 

 

Adenocarcinoma (Option C) is a malignant tumour that originates from the glandular cells of an organ and is characterized by invasive growth and the presence of dysplastic cells. However, the image does not reveal features typical of adenocarcinoma, such as tissue infiltration or cytological atypia.

 

 

 

Hyperplastic polyps (Option D) are non-neoplastic growths marked by an increase in the number of cells in the epithelial layer of an organ. They are typically small, sessile, and have a smooth surface. However, the image does not resemble the usual appearance of hyperplastic polyps, which are generally smaller and more uniform in size.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in treating sideroblastic anaemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vitamin B6

 

Explanation:

The treatment of Sideroblastic Anemia involves the use of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine).

 

Sideroblastic Anemia

It is a condition characterized by defective heme synthesis in the bone marrow, leading to the accumulation of iron within the mitochondria of red blood cell precursors (sideroblasts).

Causes
  • Congenital causes:  Due to enzyme deficiencies like ALA synthase, ferrochelatase, etc.
  • Acquired causes
  • Vitamin B6 deficiency
  • Drugs like isoniazid and chloramphenicol
  • Lead and alcohol poisoning

Pathogenesis
  • Vitamin B6 is crucial for the proper function of enzymes in heme synthesis.
  • As a cofactor for aminolevulinic acid synthase, it aids in the first step of heme production.
  • Ensuring sufficient vitamin B6 restores enzyme activity, supports heme synthesis, and helps alleviate symptoms of sideroblastic anaemia.

Microscopy

Peripheral Smear: Pappenheimer bodies

  • Multiple basophilic iron aggregates
  • Stain blue with Perl's/ Prussian blue
  • Seen in  sideroblastic anaemia, lead poisoning, or hemochromatosis

 

 

Bone Marrow: Ringed Sideroblasts

  • Blue granules form a full or partial ring
  • Blasts have a nucleus
  • Iron is present in mitochondria in the perinuclear region.
  • Stain blue on Perl's/Prussian blue.
  • Seen with Sideroblastic anemia and Myelodysplastic syndrome.
  • Associated with SF3B1 mutation

 

 

 

Vitamin B1 (Option C), or thiamine, plays a key role in carbohydrate metabolism and nerve function. Its deficiency causes conditions like Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and Beriberi, but it is not linked to sideroblastic anaemia.

Vitamin B12 (Option A) deficiency causes megaloblastic anaemia and neurological symptoms. It results from poor diet, malabsorption, or lack of intrinsic factors. In sideroblastic anaemia, vitamin B6 is used instead of vitamin B12 because it helps correct the heme synthesis defect, while B12 is not involved in this process.

 

Iron (Option D) deficiency presents with symptoms like pale skin, shortness of breath, dizziness or lightheadedness, brittle nails, headaches, restless legs syndrome, etc. In sideroblastic anaemia, treatment focuses on addressing the underlying cause, as the main issue is impaired heme synthesis. Iron supplementation is generally ineffective and may worsen the condition by increasing iron accumulation in tissues.

questions.text: The vacutainer tube shown in the given image contains the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Clot activator

 

Explanation:

The vacutainer tube shown in the image contains a clot activator, which is a substance designed to accelerate the blood clotting process. It promotes quicker coagulation of the blood sample. This type of tube is typically used to collect serum samples for various laboratory tests.

 

Colour Anti-coagulants Uses

Purple/Lavender

EDTA (Ca2+ chelating anticoagulant)

(Option A ruled out)

 CBC, Peripheral Smear, ESR, HbA1c

Light Blue

Trisodium Citrate  (Ca2+ chelating anticoagulant)

(Option B ruled out)

 ESR, PT, aPTT

Red

No anti-coagulant is added.

Clot activator without gel

(Option D)

 Serum studies (Proteins, enzymes, hormones)

Yellow

 Clot activator/Gel separator Serum studies (Proteins, enzymes, hormones)

Grey

 Sodium Fluoride

Blood Glucose

 

Green

Heparin

(Option C ruled out)

 ABG, Osmotic fragility, flow cytometry, immunophenotyping

questions.text:
Which of the following mediators is involved in the early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity?


	Mast cell
	Histamine
	Neutrophils
	Prostaglandins
	Leukotrienes
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

Explanation:

The mediators involved in the early phase of Type 1 Hypersensitivity include mast cells, histamine, prostaglandins, and leukotrienes.

 

Mast cells

Histamine

Prostaglandins

Leukotrienes

Primary effector cells.

Activated by allergens cross-linking with IgE antibodies.

Released by mast cells.

Causes vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction, and mucus production.

They are lipid mediators released by mast cells.

Contribute to vasodilation, vascular permeability, and bronchoconstriction.

A group of lipid mediators released by mast cells.

Promote bronchoconstriction, increased vascular permeability, and the recruitment of other inflammatory cells.

 

  • It involves an immediate (early) and a late-phase reaction. 

 

 

Early phase reaction

Late phase reaction

Onset

Immediate (within minutes of allergen exposure).

Delayed (several hours after exposure) and can last for days.

Cells involved

Mast cells, basophils.

Eosinophils, T lymphocytes.

Cellular events

Activation of mast cells and basophils.

Recruitment and activation of leukocytes, especially eosinophils.

Mediators

Histamine, leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4), prostaglandins (PGD2) and Platelet-activating factor (PAF). 

Cytokines (e.g., IL-4, IL-5, TNF), chemokines (e.g., eotaxin)

Initiating event

Exposure to allergen triggers cross-linking of IgE on mast cells/basophils.

Recurrent inflammation, sustained by recruited leukocytes.

Effect on tissues

Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction.

Sustained inflammation and tissue damage due to leukocyte infiltration.

Clinical manifestations

Allergic rhinitis (hay fever), urticaria (hives), Angioedema bronchoconstriction.

Allergic asthma exacerbation, persistent inflammation, and tissue damage.

Therapeutic Approach

Antihistamines for symptomatic relief.

Adrenaline in anaphylactic shock

Broad-spectrum anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., steroids) to suppress inflammation and prevent tissue damage.

questions.text: Which of the statements below accurately describes congenital CMV infection?

choices.text: About 20-30% of the infections are symptomatic
Triad of SNHL, periventricular calcification and enamel hypoplasia
Most children asymptomatic at birth can develop conductive hearing loss later in life
If the mother is lgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop an infection

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) If the mother is lgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop an infection.



Explanation:

IgG antibodies can cross the placenta and provide passive immunity to infants. In the case of congenital CMV infection, if the mother was previously infected and is IgG positive, she would provide passive immunity to the fetus thus making it unlikely for the fetus to develop an infection.


 

Congenital CMV infection can be described as follows:

 

Human cytomegalovirus (CMV)

Mode of Transmission
  • Bodily fluids: saliva, urine, blood, vaginal fluids, breast milk
  • Community exposure: Daycare centres
  • Perinatal exposure: During birth
  • Breastfeeding

Risk of Transmission
  • 30% of women with primary CMV infection during pregnancy transmit the virus to the fetus.
  • In-utero infections also occur in previously immune women but at a reduced rate

Transmission by Gestational Age

Transmission rates are higher following a primary infection, with the risk increasing as gestational age advances.

Clinical Features of congenital CMV infection
  • Asymptomatic Infection (90% of infected newborns): No signs at birth; detected through newborn screening.
  • Symptomatic Infection (10% of infected newborns (vs Option A)):
    • Jaundice (direct bilirubin >2 mg/dL)
    • Petechiae (small, red, or purple spots on the skin) giving a blueberry muffin appearance
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Microcephaly
    • Intrauterine growth restriction
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Purpura (3% infants) (larger areas of bleeding under the skin)
  • Less Common Findings:
    • Hearing loss (M/c long-term consequence; may develop later).
  • Lab findings align with the clinical presentation: Direct hyperbilirubinemia, ￪ ALT, thrombocytopenia, and Head CT abnormalities


Triad of SNHL, periventricular calcification and enamel hypoplasia (seen in congenital syphilis) (Option C) is not seen in congenital CMV infection. It presents with jaundice, petechiae (blueberry muffin rash), microcephaly, SNHL, chorioretinitis, periventricular calcification, and hepatosplenomegaly.


Most children asymptomatic at birth can develop conductive hearing loss later in life (Option D): This is a false statement since this pattern is seen in late-onset congenital syphilis.

questions.text: Which of the following is given as a part of the therapy for a child with severe COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Corticosteroids

Explanation:

In case of severe COVID, where SpO2 < 90%, due to inflammatory damage to alveoli, the corticosteroid is administered to reduce inflammation and improve oxygenation.


 

Treatment Protocols for COVID-19

 

 

Mild Disease
  • Home Management & Hydration
  • Medications: Use paracetamol for fever and nasal saline drops for congestion.
  • Avoid antibiotics and multivitamins (no proven benefit).
  • Monitoring: Watch for red flag signs like rapid breathing, oxygen saturation below 95%, persistent fever, lethargy, or poor feeding.
 

Moderate Disease
  • Admit to Covid ward
  • SpO2 > 94: Hydration, paracetamol and antimicrobials
  • SpO2 < 94: Oxygen, IV Steroids, Remdesivir, Antimicrobials
 

Severe/Critical

  • Covid - 19 ICU / HDU ward
  • Oxygen, CPAP, Invasive ventilation if required
  • IV corticosteroids, Remdesivir (controversial) , Enoxaparin, Antimicrobials
  • Manage Shock, ARDS, AKI, and Myocarditis as per protocol

 

  • Steroids: Administer IV dexamethasone at 0.15 mg/kg (max 6 mg) once daily for 5-14 days.
  • Remdesivir should be administered only in a hospital setting.
  • Enoxaparin:
    • For <2 months: 1.5 mg/kg/dose every 12 hours.
    • For >2 months: 1 mg/kg/dose every 12 hours.


Ivermectin (Option B) was earlier thought to have antiviral properties, but evidence shows there is no decrease in mortality and hospital stay. Hence it is not recommended to be used for COVID-19.


There is controversy in the use of Remdesivir (Option C) between guidelines given by IAP and MoHFW. As per IAP, Remdesivir can be used at more than 1 month of age, for moderate to severe COVID-19 disease in hospital settings. However, as per MOHFW, remdesivir is not recommended in children. There is a lack of sufficient evidence on safety and efficacy concerning Remdesivir in children below 18 years of age.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and vesicular lesions on the upper and lower limbs. Neck stiffness was present. Similar lesions were present on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. CSF analysis revealed normal glucose levels and elevated lymphocytes and protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease


Explanation:

The given clinical presentation and images are suggestive of Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth Disease (HFMD) caused by the Coxsackie A16 virus.

 

The fever and neck stiffness with CSF examination showing normal glucose level and elevated protein and lymphocytes is suggestive of viral meningitis.

Hand Foot Mouth Disease (HFMD)

Causative organism

Coxsackie A16 virus and Enterovirus A71

Age group

<5 years

Clinical features
  • Low-grade fever, feeling of being unwell, and sore throat are commonly observed.
  • Characterized by papulovesicular skin rash commonly on buttocks, knees, elbows, around the mouth, and genital area.
  • Ulcers/blisters are also seen in the oral cavity, mostly on the posterior aspect
 

Management 
  • Resolves on its own in 5-7 days, till then symptomatic and conservative treatment is given.
  • Isolation of affected children at home and promotion of hand hygiene to prevent disease spread is important.

Bacterial meningitis with sepsis (Option A) presents with cutaneous signs like petechiae, purpura or erythema and not with maculopapular lesions.


Herpes simplex gingivostomatitis and meningoencephalitis (Option C): Herpes gingivostomatitis is a very painful condition that presents with sudden onset of pain in the mouth, drooling, refusal to eat or drink, and fever. The oral lesions begin as hyperemia of the mucosa to rapidly spreading vesicles that ulcerate and eventually rupture. Herpes meningoencephalitis is an acute necrotizing infection and presents with fever, headache, nuchal rigidity, vomiting, etc. This is not the given clinical scenario.


Tuberculous meningitis (Option D) is a serious condition that can be fatal, and the child occasionally has a history of TB. The rupture of the tubercles (Rich’s foci) in the brain leads to this condition and may present with acute hydrocephalus, seizures, and cerebral oedema. These do not align with the clinical scenario given.

questions.text:
Which of the following can lead to neonatal seizures?

 

1. Hypocalcemia

2. Hyponatremia

3. Hypomagnesemia

4. Hypoglycemia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 2, 3, and 4


Explanation:

Neonatal seizures can be caused due to metabolic disturbances that include hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hyponatremia.

 

Hypoglycemia:

  • Seen in small neonates and neonates born to diabetic or pre-diabetic mothers.
  • This causes neurologic disturbances, and their severity depends on the duration of hypoglycemia.

 

Hypocalcemia:

  • This is seen in two peaks.
  • First peak: Seen in low-birthweight babies in the first 2-3 days of life.
  • Second peak: Seen later in neonatal life, usually in large, full-term babies.
  • The cause of hypocalcemia (second peak) is the consumption of milk that has higher amounts of phosphorus and magnesium than calcium hindering its absorption.

 

Hyponatremia:

  • Often causes seizures.
  • It can be caused:
    • Secondary to abnormal antidiuretic hormone secretion
    • Due to water intoxication

 

Hypomagnesemia:

  • It is often found in association with hypocalcemia.


Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: At what age does a child reach half of their adult height?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 20-24 months

Explanation:

Generally, a child's height at age 2 (20-24 months) years is half of their predicted adult height.

This milestone is often used as a reference point in paediatrics to estimate the future growth potential of the child.

 

  • Normal length at birth: 50cm.
  • In the first year, there is an increase of 25cm, so at 1 year, the height is 75cm.
  • In the second year, there is an increase of 10-15cm, so at 2 years, the height is 85-90cm.
  • There is a steady increase of 6cm/year till 12 years.

 

  • Height doubles by 4 years
  • Height triples by 12 years
  • Half of adult height in a normal child (80-85cm) is achieved by 2 years (18-24 months).

 

AGE

LENGTH/ HEIGHT

At birth

50 cm

By 3 months

60 cm

By 9 months (Option C)

70 cm

By 1 year (Option A)

75 cm

At 2 years

90 cm

At 4-4.5 years (Option D)

100 cm

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient from Bihar presented with normoanesthetic hypopigmented lesion as shown below. He had a history of fever for a long duration in his childhood. No thickened nerves were present. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Post kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis

 

Explanation:

The patient is from Bihar, an endemic region for visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar).

The image shows multiple hypopigmented macules over the back, characteristic of PKDL.

History of prolonged fever in childhood suggests prior kala-azar infection, which is a prerequisite for developing PKDL.

No thickened nerves rule out leprosy.

 

Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis (PKDL):

  • PKDL is a chronic dermal complication of visceral leishmaniasis caused by Leishmania donovani.
  • Endemic in India, Nepal, and Sudan, especially in Bihar, West Bengal, and Uttar Pradesh.

Clinical Features:

  • Occurs months to years after treated visceral leishmaniasis.
  • Hypopigmented macules, erythematous papules, or nodules on the face, trunk, and extremities.
  • No loss of sensation or thickened nerves (differentiating from leprosy).
  • Histopathology: Presence of Leishman-Donovan (LD) bodies.

Diagnosis:

  • Slit-skin smear or skin biopsy showing Leishmania donovani bodies.
  • PCR or rK39 serology can confirm diagnosis.

Management:

  • First-line treatment: Miltefosine for 12 weeks.
  • Alternatives: Liposomal amphotericin B or paromomycin.

Tuberculoid leprosy (Option A) is incorrect because it presents with single or few hypopigmented macules with loss of sensation. Thickened peripheral nerves are a hallmark feature, which is absent in this case.

Lepromatous leprosy (Option B) is incorrect because it presents with multiple ill-defined hypopigmented macules with symmetric distribution. Thickened nerves and sensation loss are typical, but they are absent in this patient.

Mycosis fungoides (Option C) is incorrect because it presents as erythematous scaly plaques rather than hypopigmented macules. It is a form of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, which is not related to prior fever or endemic infections.

questions.text: A young girl presents with leukotriosis and lesions as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Segmental vitiligo

 

Explanation:

The presence of leukotrichia (white hair) along with depigmented patches suggests vitiligo, as leukotrichia is uncommon in congenital disorders like piebaldism or nevus depigmentosus.

Segmental vitiligo affects one side of the body and follows a dermatomal or unilateral pattern.

It occurs early in life, progresses rapidly, and then stabilises, unlike generalised vitiligo, which progresses over time.

 

Focal Vitiligo (Option A) is incorrect because focal vitiligo presents as small, isolated patches but does not follow a segmental/dermatomal distribution. It often progresses into generalised vitiligo, unlike segmental vitiligo, which remains localized.

Piebaldism (Option C) is incorrect because it is a congenital disorder (present from birth) due to c-KIT gene mutations. Typically associated with a white forelock (poliosis) and symmetrical patches, not segmental.

Nevus Depigmentosus (Option D) is incorrect because it is a stable hypopigmented patch present from birth. Unlike vitiligo, it does not progress or show leukotrichia.

questions.text: What is the appropriate next course of action for a child who exhibits itchy scalp lesions and hair loss, as depicted in the image provided?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) KOH mount

 

Explanation:

The image depicts a scaly, inflamed, well-demarcated lesion on the scalp with hair loss, suggestive of Tinea Capitis (scalp ringworm).

KOH (potassium hydroxide) mount is the gold standard for diagnosing superficial fungal infections, including Tinea Capitis, by detecting fungal hyphae in hair shafts and skin scrapings.

 

Tinea Capitis:

  • Caused by: Trichophyton and Microsporum species.
  • Common in children, especially in warm, humid climates.
  • Types:
    • Non-inflammatory: Scaly patches with broken hairs.
    • Inflammatory (Kerion): Painful, boggy swelling with pustules and crusting (as seen in the image).

Diagnosis:

  • KOH Mount: Detects fungal hyphae in hair shafts and skin scrapings.
  • Fungal Culture: Confirms the fungal species.
  • Wood’s Lamp Examination: Fluorescence in Microsporum infections.

Management:

  • Systemic antifungals (Griseofulvin or Terbinafine) for 6–8 weeks (topical antifungals alone are ineffective).
  • Antifungal shampoos (ketoconazole or selenium sulfide) reduce fungal shedding.
  • Kerion cases may need corticosteroids to reduce inflammation.

Slit Skin Mount (Option B) is incorrect because it is used for leprosy diagnosis by identifying acid-fast bacilli from skin lesions, which is not relevant in this case.

Gram Staining (Option C) is incorrect because it is useful for diagnosing bacterial infections (e.g., impetigo, folliculitis) but not fungal infections like Tinea Capitis.

Biopsy (Option D) is incorrect because skin biopsy is rarely needed for diagnosing Tinea Capitis and is usually reserved for atypical or unclear cases.

questions.text: A child presented with itchy plaques over the neck, the bilateral popliteal and cubital fossa. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Atopic dermatitis

 

Explanation:

The image shows lichenified, scaly, and hyperpigmented plaques over the popliteal fossae (behind the knees).

The history of itching and involvement of flexural areas (neck, popliteal, and cubital fossae) is highly characteristic of Atopic Dermatitis (Eczema).

 

Atopic Dermatitis:

  • Common in children, associated with atopy (asthma, allergic rhinitis, eczema).
  • Hallmark features:
    • Chronic pruritus and inflammation.
    • Flexural involvement in children and adults.
    • Lichenification due to chronic scratching.
    • Infants: More likely to have cheeks, trunk, and extensor limb involvement.
  • Exacerbating factors: Irritants, allergens, weather changes, infections.

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical diagnosis based on chronic relapsing course and typical distribution.
  • No specific lab test required.
  • Elevated IgE levels may be seen but are not diagnostic.

Management:

  1. Moisturisation (Emollients) – cornerstone of therapy.
  2. Topical corticosteroids – for flare-ups (mild to moderate strength).
  3. Antihistamines – for pruritus relief.
  4. Avoid triggers (harsh soaps, allergens, irritants).
  5. Severe cases: Topical calcineurin inhibitors (Tacrolimus), systemic immunosuppressants if needed.

Dermatitis Herpetiformis (Option B) is incorrect because it presents as intensely itchy, grouped vesicles on extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, buttocks), not flexural areas. Strongly associated with coeliac disease.

Pemphigus Vegetans (Option C) is incorrect because a rare variant of pemphigus, characterised by moist, verrucous plaques in intertriginous areas (axilla, groin), unlike the dry, lichenified lesions seen here.

Psoriasis (Option D) is incorrect because psoriasis in children often affects extensor surfaces (knees, elbows), not flexures. Lesions are well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales, unlike the ill-defined, lichenified plaques seen here.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a child who has displayed symptomless lesions on the forearm and shaft of the penis, as depicted in the image of the forearm lesions below?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Lichen nitidus

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows multiple, tiny, discrete, dome-shaped, shiny papules on the forearm.

The history of symptomless lesions on the forearm and shaft of the penis is characteristic of Lichen Nitidus.

 

Lichen Nitidus:

  • Rare chronic inflammatory disorder.
  • Presents as multiple, asymptomatic, tiny, uniform, skin-coloured to hypopigmented, dome-shaped papules.
  • Common sites:
    • Forearms
    • Dorsum of hands
    • Shaft of the penis (pathognomonic location)
    • Trunk
  • Aetiology: Unknown, but associated with atopic dermatitis, Crohn’s disease, and lichen planus.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical; biopsy if needed shows lymphocytic infiltrate in a "claw clutching a ball" pattern.

Management:

  • No treatment required if asymptomatic.
  • If symptomatic, topical steroids, emollients, or calcineurin inhibitors can be used.
  • Usually self-limiting but may persist for months to years.

Lichen Planus (Option A) is incorrect because Lichen planus presents as violaceous, flat-topped, pruritic papules with Wickham’s striae. Usually involves flexor wrists, oral mucosa, and lower back but not commonly the shaft of the penis.

Scrofuloderma (Option C) is incorrect because it is a tuberculous skin infection that presents as cold abscesses and sinus tracts overlying lymph nodes or bones, not as discrete, shiny papules.

Scabies (Option D) is incorrect because scabies causes intensely pruritic papules, vesicles, and burrows, commonly found in finger webs, axillae, and genital areas. The absence of itching and burrows makes scabies unlikely.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a young man who has presented with painful lesions depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Herpes Zoster

 

Explanation:

The image shows a unilateral, dermatomal eruption of grouped vesicles on an erythematous base. The patient has painful lesions, which is a key feature of Herpes Zoster (Shingles). The lesions appear in a band-like distribution, following the sensory nerve dermatome.

 

Herpes Zoster (Shingles):

  • Cause: Reactivation of Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) in the dorsal root ganglion.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Immunosuppression (HIV, malignancies)
    • Elderly individuals
    • Stress and trauma
  • Clinical Features:
    • Painful, grouped vesicles on an erythematous base in a unilateral dermatomal pattern.
    • Pre-eruptive phase (burning, tingling pain) 48–72 hours before rash onset.
    • Thoracic dermatomes are most commonly involved.
    • Postherpetic neuralgia (persistent pain after healing) may develop in older adults.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical, confirmed by Tzanck smear (multinucleated giant cells) or PCR for VZV DNA.
  • Treatment:
    • Antiviral therapy (Acyclovir, Valacyclovir) within 72 hours of rash onset.
    • Analgesics for pain control.
    • Corticosteroids in severe cases.

Molluscum Contagiosum (Option B) is incorrect because Molluscum contagiosum presents as small, umbilicated, pearly white papules, not as vesicular eruptions. It is usually asymptomatic and not painful.

Herpes Simplex (Option C) is incorrect because Herpes simplex virus (HSV) causes clusters of vesicles but does not usually follow a dermatomal distribution. HSV infections typically affect the oral (HSV-1) or genital (HSV-2) regions rather than the thoracic dermatomes.

Lymphangioma Circumscriptum (Option D) is incorrect because lymphangioma circumscriptum is a benign lymphatic malformation, presenting as clusters of small, translucent vesicles ("frog spawn" appearance). It is not painful and does not appear in a dermatomal pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes Korsakoff syndrome?

choices.text: Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia
Loss of long-term memory but intact personality
Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory
Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory
 

Explanation:

  • Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic condition caused by severe thiamine deficiency, often due to alcohol misuse, and is characterised by anterograde amnesia and loss of recent memory.
  • It often results from untreated Wernicke encephalopathy.
  • It presents with the following symptoms
    • Impaired mental syndrome - recent memory
    • Anterograde amnesia
    • Confabulation



Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia (Option A)This classical triad is seen in Wernicke’s encephalopathy, an acute symptom of thiamine deficiency. It is treated with a high dose of parenteral thiamine.

 

Loss of long-term memory but intact personality (Option B) Korsakoff syndrome is characterised by severe anterograde amnesia and loss of recent memory. Some may present with retrograde amnesia. However, anterograde amnesia is more commonly observed.

 

Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall (Option D) is not seen with Korsakoff syndrome. It affects explicit memories, not implicit memory.

questions.text:
Match the following
 


	
		
			
			A. Depression
			
			
			1. The feeling goes away as soon as you leave the hospital
			
		
		
			
			B. Suicide
			
			
			2. State of emotional and physical exhaustion caused by prolonged stress, relieved after relaxation
			
		
		
			
			C. Burnout
			
			
			3. Difficult to diagnose due to shell of physician’s pride
			
		
		
			
			D. Overworking
			
			
			4. Women physicians, substance abuse, relationship troubles
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

Explanation:

Depression in doctors is often difficult to diagnose because many may avoid seeking medical help due to the fear of personal and professional judgment. Rates of depression are high among doctors, and if left untreated, it significantly increases the risk of suicide.

 

Suicide risk is higher among female physicians. Risk factors for suicide include:

  • Personal factors: Underlying psychiatric disorders, relationship troubles, stress, and trauma.
  • Structural factors: Increased managerialism, excessive paperwork, rushed patient interactions, limited time off, and work pressure.
  • Endemic factors: Exposure to trauma and patient deaths.

 

Burnout, classified as an occupational phenomenon in ICD-11, results from chronic workplace stress that is not adequately managed. It has three dimensions:

  1. Emotional exhaustion or energy depletion.
  2. Negative attitudes or cynicism related to the job or increased mental distance from work.
  3. Decreased professional efficacy.


Overworking can go away as soon as the doctor leaves the hospital and takes rest.

questions.text:
Match the following


	
		
			
			A. Twilight state
			
			
			1. Subnormal intelligence
			
		
		
			
			B. Oneiroid state
			
			
			2. Impaired level of consciousness
			
		
		
			
			C. Oligophrenia
			
			
			3. Persecution
			
		
		
			
			D. Paranoid ideation
			
			
			4. Oneirophrenia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

Explanation:

Terms

Definition

Twilight state
  • It refers to a state of disturbed consciousness along with hallucinations.

Oneiroid state or oneirophrenia
  • Dream-like delusional derangement of consciousness in which the patient is not fully oriented in time and place.
  • A characteristic feature of this state - is the presence of kaleidoscopic quality of the dream-like experiences where reality, illusions, and hallucinations are merged into one.
  • Associated with catatonic disturbances.

Oligophrenia
  • It refers to a group of mental states characterised by subnormal levels of intellectual activity.
  • Either congenital or acquired during early infancy.
  • Associated with other cognitive disturbances, affective disorders, and volitional disorders.

Paranoid ideation
  • Refers to thinking that is dominated by persecutory, suspicious, or grandiose content.
  • Thought content is less than that for delusions.
  • Paranoid delusions refer to persecutory delusions and delusions of grandeur, control, and reference.

questions.text: A young male who is shy and prefers social isolation appears to be emotionally cold and resides alone. There is no history of hallucinations or delusions. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Schizoid personality disorder


Explanation:

  • The patient likely has Schizoid personality disorder, characterised by social detachment and emotional coldness.
  • Individuals with this disorder have little interest in social relationships, prefer solitary activities, and appear emotionally distant.
  • They tend to avoid close interactions and lack a desire for social engagement.

 

Cluster A Personality Disorders

Characterised by odd and aloof behaviour, prone to develop psychosis.

Disorder

Key Features

Diagnosis

Treatment

Paranoid Personality Disorder (Option A)
  • Pervasive distrust and suspiciousness of others
  • Hostility, irritability, anger
  • Difficulty with trust and intimacy
  • Cynical view of the world
  • No fixed delusions (vs. delusional disorder)
  • No hallucinations or formal thought disorder (vs. schizophrenia)
  • No tumultuous relationships (vs. borderline personality disorder)
  • No history of antisocial behaviour (vs. antisocial personality disorder)
  • Psychotherapy: Straightforward and honest therapist, avoid warmth or deep interpretation
  • Group therapy: Helpful for some, but poorly tolerated
  • Behavior therapy: Social skills training may feel intrusive

Schizoid Personality Disorder

(Option B)
  • Lifelong social withdrawal
  • Eccentric, isolated, and lonely
  • Introverted with a bland affect
  • No psychotic symptoms (vs. schizophrenia, delusional disorder)
  • More withdrawn and aloof (vs. paranoid personality disorder)
  • No dysphoric loneliness
  • Fewer past relationships, possible autistic reverie
  • No desire for social interaction (vs. avoidant personality disorder)
  • Psychotherapy: Build trust, encourage expression
  • Group therapy: May benefit, initial silence likely
  • Pharmacotherapy: Limited evidence, medications for specific symptoms (e.g., emotional detachment)

Schizotypal Personality Disorder

  • Social difficulties
  • Eccentric behaviour and thinking (“magical thinking”)
  • Peculiar speech, superstitious beliefs, perceptual illusions
  • Odd behaviour, thinking, and perception (vs. schizoid and avoidant personality disorders)
  • Differentiated from autism by the severity of language disorder
  • Lacks psychosis, or it's brief (vs. schizophrenia)
  • No odd behaviour (vs. paranoid personality disorder)
  • Psychotherapy: Sensitive approach to avoid ridicule
  • Antipsychotics: Manage illusions and odd ideas
  • Antidepressants: Used for depressive symptoms


 

Antisocial personality disorder (Option C) is characterised by a disregard for the rights of others and a lack of empathy. Individuals with this disorder often engage in impulsive and irresponsible behaviour, have difficulties conforming to social norms, and may exhibit a pattern of deceit and manipulation.

 

Emotionally unstable personality disorder (Option D,) also known as borderline personality disorder, is characterised by a pervasive pattern of instability in mood, self-image, and interpersonal relationships. Individuals with this disorder often experience intense and rapidly shifting emotions, engage in impulsive behaviour, and have difficulties maintaining stable relationships.

questions.text: Among the following, what is the most common symptom of adult obsessive-compulsive disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pathological doubt

Explanation:

  • The most common symptom of adult obsessive-compulsive disorder is pathological doubt.
  • Individuals with OCD experience persistent, irrational doubts, leading to repetitive checking behaviours or seeking reassurance to alleviate anxiety.
  • This symptom is a core feature of OCD and contributes to ritualistic behaviours.

 

Clinical presentation of OCD

Contamination is the most common presentation.

  • An obsession with contamination followed by washing and avoiding the presumably contaminated object.

Pathological doubt is the second most common presentation

  • Obsession of doubt, usually followed by compulsion of checking.

Intrusive/forbidden thoughts are the third most common presentation.

  • Obsessed with intrusive thoughts of aggressive or sexual acts without a compulsion.

Symmetry/ordering is the fourth most common presentation.

  • The patient needs symmetry/precision, which results in the compulsion of slowness.

 

Aggressive symptoms (Option A) can occur in some cases of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), but they are not the most common. Intrusive thoughts or images of harm or violence, along with compulsions to reduce these thoughts, may be present in certain individuals, but they are less prevalent than other symptoms.

 

Need for symmetry (Option B), is a common symptom of OCD, where individuals feel compelled to arrange objects symmetrically, follow strict routines, or repeatedly check for order. However, it is not the most prevalent symptom in adult OCD.

 

Sexual symptoms (Option D) are not the most common in OCD. Sexual obsessions may cause distress, prompting individuals to engage in repetitive behaviours or mental rituals to suppress or neutralise these thoughts.

questions.text: What does the given image represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypnogram

Explanation:

  • The above image represents a Hypnogram, a graphical representation of sleep stages over a period of time.
  • It shows the different stages of sleep, such as wakefulness, rapid eye movement (REM) sleep, and various stages of non-REM sleep.
  • It typically displays the amount of time spent in each stage over the course of the night, providing insights into sleep architecture.
  • This helps clinicians evaluate sleep quality and diagnose sleep disorders.
  • It typically reflects:
    • Sequence and duration of various sleep stages (N1, N2, N3, and REM) throughout the night.
    • The cyclic nature of sleep shows transitions between stages over time and the relative amount of time spent in each stage.

 

Electroencephalogram (EEG) (Option B) is a test that measures the electrical activity of the brain using electrodes placed on the scalp. It is used to record and analyze brain wave patterns and can provide information about brain function and abnormalities.

 

Polysomnogram (Option C) is a comprehensive sleep study that involves monitoring various physiological parameters during sleep. It typically includes the recording of brain activity (EEG), eye movements (electrooculogram), muscle activity (electromyogram), heart rate and rhythm (electrocardiogram), respiratory airflow and effort, and oxygen saturation levels. A polysomnogram is used to diagnose sleep disorders and evaluate sleep quality.

 

Epworth sleep assessment (Option D) is a questionnaire used to assess an individual's daytime sleepiness or propensity to fall asleep in various situations. It does not involve monitoring physiological parameters or providing a visual representation like the other options mentioned.

questions.text: Abrupt stoppage of which of the following drugs causes irritability, rebound anxiety, and insomnia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Venlafaxine

Explanation:

Abrupt stoppage of Venlafaxine causes irritability, rebound anxiety, and insomnia.

 

Venlafaxine

MOA
  • Inhibits reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine (SNRI).
  • Weak inhibition of dopamine reuptake.

Uses

  • Major depressive disorder (MDD)
  • Generalised anxiety disorder (GAD)
  • Social anxiety disorder (SAD)
  • Panic disorder

Side effects

  • Nausea, headache, dry mouth, dizziness, sweating, constipation, insomnia.
  • Cardiovascular: Increased blood pressure (dose-dependent).
  • Neurological: Tremors, agitation.
  • Sexual dysfunction: Decreased libido, delayed ejaculation.
  • Withdrawal Symptoms: Irritability, rebound anxiety, insomnia

 

Valproate (Option A), Fluoxetine (Option B), and Olanzapine (Option D) have long half-life, making discontinuation effects less severe or delayed.

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is the least probable in a patient prescribed with escitalopram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Sialorrhea

 

Explanation:

  • Sialorrhea (excessive salivation) is less likely to occur with escitalopram (SSRI).
  • Dry mouth (xerostomia) is a more frequent side effect of escitalopram.

 

SSRI’s:

Definition

Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) are a class of drugs primarily used to treat depression and other mental health conditions. They increase serotonin levels in the brain, which helps regulate mood, emotion, and sleep.

Common SSRIs
  • Sertraline
  • Fluoxetine
  • Paroxetine
  • Citalopram
  • Escitalopram
  • Vilazodone (SPARI- Serotonin Partial Agonist and Reuptake Inhibitor)
  • Fluvoxamine (mainly for OCD)

Side Effects

Gastrointestinal

  • Nausea (most common) (Option A)
  • Diarrhea
  • Anorexia
  • Dry mouth
  • Weight gain
  • Constipation (especially with paroxetine)

CNS

  • Anxiety
  • Insomnia
  • Sedation
  • Vivid dreams (Option B)
  • Emotional blunting
  • Seizures (rare)
  • Extrapyramidal symptoms

Sexual Dysfunction

(most common side effect in long-term use)
  • Decreased libido
  • Delayed ejaculation
  • Inhibited orgasm (Option C)

Haematological

  • Impaired platelet aggregation
  • Increased risk of GI bleeding (especially with NSAIDs)

Miscellaneous

  • Hyponatremia
  • Allergic rashes
  • Hyperprolactinemia (leading to galactorrhea or menstrual irregularities)

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV patient presented with fever, cough and haemoptysis. His sputum sample showed acid-fast bacilli. What is the appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Start ART and then ATT after 2 weeks
Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks

Explanation: The appropriate management in an HIV patient with tuberculosis (TB) is to start antitubercular therapy (ATT) first and then initiate antiretroviral therapy (ART) after 2-8 weeks of ATT to avoid the risk of immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS).

 

HIV and TB Co-infection:

  • Increased Risk: People with HIV are 18-26 times more likely to develop active TB than those without HIV.
  • HIV weakens the immune system, reducing CD4 T-cell counts, which are essential for controlling TB infection. This allows TB to progress from latent to active disease.
  • The underlying mechanism of IRIS is due to an imbalance between anti-inflammatory cytokines and pro-inflammatory cytokines that occurs rapidly after the recovery of immune function in HIV patients initiated on HAART.
  • Screening and Diagnosis:
    • Testing for Both Conditions: Patients with TB should be tested for HIV, and vice versa, given the high co-infection rate.
    • Diagnostic Challenges: TB symptoms can overlap with other opportunistic infections in HIV patients. Tests like sputum culture, X-rays, and newer rapid molecular tests (GeneXpert) help in diagnosing TB in HIV-positive patients.
  • Treatment of Co-Infection:
    • Anti-TB Therapy: This involves the standard TB drug regimen, usually with a 6-month course. Treatment may extend for cases of drug-resistant TB.
    • Instead of Rifampicin, Rifabutin is preferred in patients receiving protease inhibitors due to its property of being a less potent inducer of CYP3A4.
    • Antiretroviral Therapy (ART): Initiating ART is crucial for improving immune function. ART is typically started 2-8 weeks after beginning TB treatment to prevent immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS), depending on CD4 count and clinical status.
    • Drug Interactions: TB drugs, like rifampicin, can interact with ART drugs, requiring careful selection of the ART regimen to minimize side effects and maintain effectiveness.

questions.text: A patient presented with sinusitis, ulcerative lesions on the nasopharynx, nodular lesions with cavitations of the lung, and renal failure. Which of the following is the most useful investigation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Test for ANCA

Explanation: The clinical scenario of sinusitis, ulcerative lesions on the nasopharynx (upper respiratory tract), nodular lesions with cavitation in the lungs (lower respiratory tract), and renal failure strongly suggests granulomatosis with polyangiitis. The most useful investigation in this case is a test for ANCA.

 

Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA):

  • GPA is a vasculitic disorder characterized by granulomatous inflammation of the upper and lower respiratory tracts, small vessel vasculitis, and pauci-immune glomerulonephritis.
  • Pathology and Pathogenesis:
    • Hallmarks: Necrotizing vasculitis and granuloma formation in affected organs.
    • Organs involved:
      • Lungs: Nodular cavitary infiltrates; necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis.
      • Kidneys: Pauci-immune glomerulonephritis with minimal immune complex deposition.
      • Upper airway: Granulomatous inflammation, necrosis, nasal septal perforation, and saddle nose deformity.
      • Immune imbalance: Predominantly Th1-mediated cytokine response with elevated IFN-γ, TNF-α, and IL-12.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Respiratory tract: Paranasal sinus pain, nasal discharge (purulent/bloody), subglottic stenosis, cough, hemoptysis, and dyspnea.
    • Renal: Proteinuria, hematuria, red blood cell casts, and progressive renal failure.
    • Skin: Palpable purpura, ulcers, or nodules with vasculitis.
    • Ocular: Conjunctivitis, episcleritis, retro-orbital masses, and proptosis.
    • Neurological: Mononeuritis multiplex, cranial neuritis, or cerebral vasculitis.
    • Systemic symptoms: Malaise, fever, weight loss, arthralgia, and fatigue.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Biopsy:
      • Lung biopsy: High diagnostic yield, showing granulomatous vasculitis.
      • Renal biopsy: Pauci-immune glomerulonephritis.
    • Serology: Antiproteinase-3 ANCA positivity (~90%).
  • Treatment:
    • Induction Therapy: Glucocorticoids, cyclophosphamide or rituximab
    • Maintenance Therapy: Azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil or methotrexate

Biopsy to show granuloma (Option B): While granulomas may be seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), their absence does not exclude the diagnosis. Biopsy findings are supportive but not definitive, and testing for ANCA is less invasive and provides earlier diagnostic information.

AFB staining of sputum (Option C) is primarily used for diagnosing tuberculosis, which does not match the clinical presentation of combined upper and lower respiratory tract involvement with renal failure seen in GPA.

BAL (Bronchoalveolar Lavage) (Option D) can help evaluate lung involvement and detect inflammatory cells but is not specific for GPA. ANCA testing is more specific and less invasive for confirming the diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with palpitations and shortness of breath. His medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and coronary artery disease. On examination, irregularly irregular heartbeats are noted. An electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals irregularly irregular rhythm, no P waves, and absence of an isoelectric baseline. His blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg, heart rate 130 bpm, and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. Given the patient's clinical presentation and history, which of the following treatment options should be considered as a first-line approach for managing this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Metoprolol

Explanation: The clinical scenario of a patient with a history of hypertension, diabetes, and coronary artery disease, irregularly irregular heartbeats on examination, along with an ECG showing irregularly irregular rhythm, no P waves, and absence of an isoelectric baseline, points towards a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. The first-line approach for managing this case is beta blockers, such as metoprolol, to achieve rate control.

Atrial Fibrillation

Features
  • Characterized by abnormal automatic firing and multiple re-entry circuits.
  • Atria beat rapidly and ineffectively; ventricles activated irregularly
  • Produces an "irregularly irregular" pulse
  • Palpitations, syncope, and breathlessness can be present
  • Asymptomatic AF: Can present as systemic embolism and stroke

ECG Features
  • QRS Complexes: Irregular but normal
  • P Waves: Absent; baseline may show irregular fibrillation waves
  • Ventricular Rate:
    • Fast at onset (120-160 beats/min)
    • Slower in chronic AF due to medication effects and AV nodal fatigue

Management

Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation

  • First-line Therapy: Beta-blockers are effective in patients with CAD, hypertension, and heart failure. 
  • Class Ic Drugs: Propafenone or flecainide to prevent episodes (not for patients with CAD or LV dysfunction).
  • Class III Drugs:
    • Amiodarone: Most effective but with significant side effects; used when other treatments fail. (Option A)
    • Dronedarone: Alternative to amiodarone; contraindicated in heart failure.
  • Rate Control: Digoxin and verapamil for AV node conduction slowing, but not for AF prevention. 
  • Catheter Ablation: Considered for patients with drug-resistant AF; prevents AF in ~75% of cases but may have complications.

Persistent Atrial Fibrillation

  • Rhythm Control:
    • Cardioversion: Electrical or pharmacological (e.g., intravenous flecainide or amiodarone).
    • Timing: Immediate if AF <48 hours in unstable patients. (Option C)
    • Anticoagulation is required if AF ≥48 hours to prevent thromboembolic events. (Option D)
    • Prophylactic Amiodarone: To reduce recurrence risk.
  • Rate Control:
    • Medications: Digoxin, β-blockers, or rate-limiting calcium antagonists (verapamil, diltiazem).
    • Combination Therapy: Digoxin with β-blockers; avoid combining calcium antagonists with β-blockers.
    • Pace and Ablate: Permanent pacemaker with AV nodal block for symptomatic AF.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a major diagnostic criterion for neuromyelitis optica?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Focal epilepsy

Explanation: Focal epilepsy is not a major diagnostic criterion for neuromyelitis optica.

 

Neuromyelitis optica (NMO):

  • An inflammatory central nervous system syndrome distinct from multiple sclerosis (MS) that is associated with serum aquaporin-4 immunoglobulin G antibodies (AQP4-IgG).
  • Diagnostic criteria:
    • Clinical events: At least one of the following:
      • Optic neuritis (Option D)
      • Transverse myelitis (requires LETM MRI lesion) (Option B)
      • Area postrema syndrome (requires associated medullary MRI lesion) (Option A)

questions.text: Which of the following does not show both hyperkinetic and hypokinetic movements?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Huntington’s chorea

Explanation: Huntington’s chorea predominantly manifests with hyperkinetic movements, such as chorea.

 

Huntington’s Disease (HD):

  • A progressive, fatal, autosomal dominant disorder.
  • Characterized by motor, behavioral, oculomotor, and cognitive dysfunction.
  • Onset typically between 25-45 years.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Affects the striatum, progressing to involve the cerebral cortex.
    • Caused by >40 CAG repeats in the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Early-stage: Focal or segmental chorea.
    • Late-stage: Dystonia, rigidity, bradykinesia, and myoclonus.
    • Behavioral changes: Depression, aggression, psychosis, and suicidal tendencies.
    • Cognitive impairment leading to dementia.
    • Non-neurological features: Diabetes mellitus and hypothalamic dysfunction.

Parkinson’s disease (Option A) is characterized by both hyperkinetic movements such as resting tremor and hypokinetic features like rigidity, stiffness, and bradykinesia.

 

Wilson’s disease (Option B) results from basal ganglia damage, leading to hyperkinetic features such as dystonia and tremor, and hypokinetic features like parkinsonism with bradykinesia. Additionally, it can cause incoordination, dysarthria, dysphagia, and in advanced stages, a characteristic wing-beating (flapping) tremor.
 

Neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation (Option C) presents with a combination of hyperkinetic movements, including dystonia, and hypokinetic features, such as parkinsonism, along with spasticity.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Liddle syndrome

Explanation: Liddle syndrome is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension.
