Gordon syndrome (Option D) (also known as pseudohypoaldosteronism type II) is a rare autosomal dominant disorder that presents with hypertension, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis, rather than the hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A patient came with hypoxemia and a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient. What can be the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypoventilation

Explanation: Hypoventilation causes hypoxemia by reducing both alveolar and arterial oxygen levels equally, resulting in a normal alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient.

 

Alveolar-Arterial Oxygen Gradient (A-a Gradient):

  • The A-a gradient measures the difference between the oxygen concentration in the alveoli (PAO2) and the oxygen concentration in the arterial system (PaO2).
  • Helps narrow the differential diagnosis for hypoxemia.
  • A-a Gradient Formula:
    A-a Gradient = PAO2 – PaO2
    (PAO2 = Alveolar oxygen tension, PaO2 = Arterial oxygen tension).
  • Hypoventilation and A-a Gradient:
  • Hypoventilation occurs when there is inadequate ventilation of the lungs, leading to decreased oxygen levels in the arterial system.
  • Causes of Hypoventilation:
    • CNS depression.
    • Neuromuscular diseases (e.g., myasthenia gravis).
    • Poor chest elasticity (e.g., kyphoscoliosis).
    • Vertebral fractures and other factors.
  • Hypoventilation affects both arterial oxygen tension (PaO₂) and alveolar oxygen tension (AₐO₂), resulting in decreased oxygen levels in both the respiratory and circulatory systems.
  • The A-a gradient (the difference between alveolar and arterial oxygen tensions) remains normal in hypoventilation because both PaO₂ and AₐO₂ decrease in proportion.

 

Right to left shunt (Option A): In a right-to-left shunt, oxygenated blood bypasses the alveoli, mixing with deoxygenated blood and causing hypoxemia. This leads to an increased A-a gradient, as diffusion between capillaries and alveoli remains unaffected, but the lack of oxygenation of the shunted blood worsens the oxygenation process.

Ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch (Option B) leads to a disparity between ventilation and perfusion in the lungs, resulting in an increased A-a gradient. This is because some areas of the lung are either under-ventilated or under-perfused, impairing the gas exchange process and increasing the gradient.

Alveolar membrane damage (Option D), seen in conditions like ARDS or pulmonary fibrosis, impairs the diffusion of oxygen across the alveolar-capillary barrier. This causes an increased A-a gradient as oxygen fails to transfer efficiently from the alveoli into the bloodstream, leading to hypoxemia.

questions.text:
All are true regarding heart failure except:

HFpEF- Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction; HFrPF- Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction

choices.text: Regardless of ejection fraction and the type of heart failure, the 5-year mortality rate is around 50%
Non-cardiovascular death is more in HFrEF-30-40% as compared to HFpEF-15%
Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors cause cough in 15% and angioedema in 1%
Atrial fibrillation is common in elderly and is the cause of stroke in quarter of the stroke cases

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Non-cardiovascular death is more in HFrEF-30-40% as compared to HFpEF-15%

Explanation: Non-cardiovascular death is more common in HFpEF (62%) than in HFrEF (35%), making option B incorrect.

 

Classification of Heart Failure by Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction:

Type of Heart Failure

Definition

Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF)

LVEF ≤40%

Heart failure with improved ejection fraction (HFimpEF)

Previous LVEF ≤40% and a follow-up LVEF >40%

Heart failure with mildly reduced ejection fraction (HFmrEF)

LVEF 41%–49%

Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF)

LVEF ≥50%
  • HFrEF has the highest rates of cardiac death compared to other heart failure categories.
  • Noncardiac causes account for a significant proportion of deaths, with 62% in HFpEF, 54% in HFmrEF, and 35% in HFrEF.

Regardless of ejection fraction and the type of heart failure, the 5-year mortality rate is around 50% (Option A): The 5-year mortality rate for heart failure patients, regardless of ejection fraction, is approximately 50%. The development of symptomatic heart failure carries a poor prognosis, with around 30-40% of patients dying within 1 year of diagnosis, and 60-70% dying within 5 years, which is correct.

Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors cause cough in 15% and angioedema in 1% (Option C): ACE inhibitors are known to cause a cough in 15% of patients and rarely cause rashes or angioedema in 1% due to the accumulation of bradykinin and substance P, which is true.

Atrial fibrillation is common in elderly and is the cause of stroke in quarter of the stroke cases (Option D): Atrial fibrillation is common in elderly patients, with more than 95% of patients being over 60 years old. It increases the risk of stroke by five-fold and is responsible for around 25% of strokes, which is accurate.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of neck swelling. She gives a history of weight loss and palpitations. On examination, she has exophthalmos and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. What are the essential investigations that should be done for the patient?


	Thyroid scan
	Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC)
	Thyroid function tests
	Ultrasound of neck
	Anti-thyroid antibody
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1,3,4 and 5 only

Explanation: The clinical scenario of a female with neck swelling, weight loss, palpitations, exophthalmos, and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland suggests a diagnosis of Grave’s disease. The essential investigations for this patient include thyroid function tests (TFT), ultrasound of the neck, thyroid scan, and anti-thyroid antibodies. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is not essential in this case.

 

Grave’s Disease:

  • Onset typically between 20-50 years; rare before adolescence but occurs in the elderly.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Combination of genetics (e.g., HLA-DR, CTLA-4) and environmental factors (e.g., stress, iodine intake).
    • Associated with thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSIs), which activate the TSH receptor.
  • Clinical Manifestations:
  • Weight loss (despite increased appetite), or rarely, weight gain.
  • Hyperactivity, nervousness, fatigue, tremors, heat intolerance, sweating.
  • Cardiovascular: Sinus tachycardia, atrial fibrillation (in older patients), palpitation.
  • Neurological: Hyperreflexia, muscle weakness, rare chorea.
  • Skin: Warm, moist skin; palmar erythema, alopecia, hyperpigmentation.
  • GI: Increased stool frequency, diarrhea.
  • Bone: Osteopenia, mild hypercalcemia.
  • Specific to Grave’s disease:
    • Diffuse thyroid enlargement (thrill/bruit may be present).
    • Ophthalmopathy:
      • Proptosis, diplopia, and optic neuropathy.
    • Dermopathy (pretibial myxedema):
      • Indurated, pink-purple plaques with "orange-skin" appearance.
    • Acropachy (clubbing), rare.
  • Investigation:
  • TSH and Thyroid Hormones: (3)
    • Grave’s disease shows suppressed TSH levels with elevated total and unbound thyroid hormone levels.
    • T3 toxicosis (elevated T3 with normal T4) occurs in 2-5% of cases or more in areas with borderline iodine intake.
    • T4 toxicosis (elevated T4 with normal T3) can be seen with iodine-induced hyperthyroidism.
  • Antibody Testing: (5)
    • TPO antibodies or TRAb testing is useful for unclear cases but not routinely needed.
  • Associated Abnormalities:
    • Elevated bilirubin, liver enzymes, and ferritin.
    • Microcytic anemia and thrombocytopenia may occur.
  • Radionuclide scan and uptake (1) (e.g., 99mTc, 123I) differentiate Grave’s disease from thyroiditis, ectopic thyroid tissue, factitious thyrotoxicosis, toxic adenoma, or multinodular goiter.
  • Color-Flow Doppler Ultrasonography (4): Differentiates hyperthyroidism (increased blood flow) from destructive thyroiditis.
  • Treatment:
    • Antithyroid drugs: Propylthiouracil (provide symptomatic relief)
    • Radioiodine treatment (I131): Mainly used in elderly patients with surgical comorbidities or recurrence after surgery.

Thyroidectomy: Treatment of choice, especially when other methods fail or are contraindicated.

questions.text: True about electroencephalogram (EEG) is all except:

choices.text: 1-5% of the population can have epileptiform discharges
Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy
Doing EEG is mandatory for diagnosis of seizures
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves on EEG

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Doing EEG is mandatory for diagnosis of seizures

Explanation:

Doing EEG is not mandatory for diagnosis of seizures.

 

Electroencephalography (EEG):

  • Records electrical activity in the brain using electrodes placed on the scalp.
  • It is a dynamic test, EEG frequencies and distribution vary based on factors like brain maturation, age, alertness, and medication.
  • NICE Guidelines: Emphasize not relying solely on EEG for diagnosis. It should be used to:
    • Define seizure type and syndrome.
    • Guide treatment and prognosis.
  • EEG is critical when:
    • Non-convulsive status epilepticus is suspected.
    • Continuous Spike Wave in Slow Wave Sleep (CSWS) is suspected.
  • Avoid in Certain Cases:
    • EEG should not be requested for children with autistic regression.
    • EEG is not needed in developmentally/neurologically normal children with simple or complex febrile seizures.
  • Repeat EEG: Once a seizure type or syndrome has been diagnosed, repeat EEGs have limited value for monitoring treatment or deciding on drug withdrawal.

 

1-5% of the population can have epileptiform discharges (Option A): This statement is correct. These discharges are not specific to epilepsy, and even in known epilepsy cases, routine interictal EEG can be normal in 60% of cases. Therefore, EEG cannot establish the diagnosis of epilepsy in many individuals.

Scalp EEG may be useful in localizing frontal focal seizures (Option B): However, it is often misleading or normal, particularly when seizures arise from areas distant from the scalp, such as the inferior frontal or medial temporal lobe. In such cases, the EEG may not localize the seizures or may show non-specific activity.

Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PMLE) shows triphasic and slow waves on EEG (Option D): EEG in PMLE typically shows slow background activity and triphasic and slow waves, predominantly in the frontal regions.

questions.text:
In a PHC, which of the following initial screening tests are used to diagnose diabetes?


	HbA1c >6.5
	Fasting blood sugar >126mg/dl
	Random blood sugar >200mg/dl
	2-hour post glucose load blood sugar
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2 and 4

Explanation: The initial screening for diabetes in a PHC typically involves fasting blood sugar levels >126 mg/dL and a 2-hour post-glucose load blood sugar.

 

The diagnosis of diabetes can be established using any of the following criteria:

  • Fasting Plasma Glucose (FPG): ≥ 126 mg/dL (2) after an overnight fast. The result should be confirmed by repeating the test.
  • Random Plasma Glucose (RPG) (3): > 200 mg/dL, done only if the patient presents with symptoms of diabetes such as polyuria, polydipsia, ketoacidosis, or unexplained weight loss.
  • Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) (4): A two-hour plasma glucose level ≥ 200 mg/dL after a 75-gram oral glucose challenge. For children, the test uses 1.75 gm/kg body weight.

 

HbA1c >6.5 (Option 1): HbA1c estimation is not typically used in primary health centers (PHC) in India due to limited resources, and it is usually only available in tertiary centers.

questions.text:
In atrial fibrillation, choose the correct statements:


	Novel oral anticoagulants (NOACs) used in the treatment of moderate to severe MS
	Anticoagulants should be given in patients with ischemic stroke due to atrial fibrillation
	NOACs are contraindicated in prosthetic valves
	All patients with atrial fibrillation who are not candidates for cardiac surgery can be started on beta-blockers
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2 and 3 correct

Explanation:

The correct statements are 2 and 3.

Atrial Fibrillation

Features
  • Characterized by abnormal automatic firing and multiple re-entry circuits.
  • Atria beat rapidly and ineffectively; ventricles activated irregularly
  • Produces an "irregularly irregular" pulse
  • Palpitations, syncope, and breathlessness can be present
  • Asymptomatic AF: Can present as systemic embolism and stroke

ECG Features
  • QRS Complexes: Irregular but normal
  • P Waves: Absent; baseline may show irregular fibrillation waves
  • Ventricular Rate:
    • Fast at onset (120-160 beats/min)
    • Slower in chronic AF due to medication effects and AV nodal fatigue

Management

Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation:

  • First-line Therapy: Beta-blockers are effective in patients with CAD, hypertension, and heart failure. (4)
  • Class Ic Drugs: Propafenone or flecainide to prevent episodes (not for patients with CAD or LV dysfunction).
  • Class III Drugs:
    • Amiodarone: Most effective but with significant side effects; used when other treatments fail. 
    • Dronedarone: Alternative to amiodarone; contraindicated in heart failure.
  • Rate Control: Digoxin and verapamil for AV node conduction slowing, but not for AF prevention. 
  • Catheter Ablation: Considered for patients with drug-resistant AF; prevents AF in ~75% of cases but may have complications.
 

Persistent Atrial Fibrillation:

  • Rhythm Control:
    • Cardioversion: Electrical or pharmacological (e.g., intravenous flecainide or amiodarone).
    • Timing: Immediate if AF <48 hours in unstable patients. 
    • Anticoagulation is required if AF ≥48 hours to prevent thromboembolic events. 
    • Prophylactic Amiodarone: To reduce recurrence risk.
  • Rate Control:
    • Medications: Digoxin, β-blockers, or rate-limiting calcium antagonists (verapamil, diltiazem).
    • Combination Therapy: Digoxin with β-blockers; avoid combining calcium antagonists with β-blockers.
    • Pace and Ablate: Permanent pacemaker with AV nodal block for symptomatic AF.
 

Thromboprophylaxis:

  • Anticoagulation: Required for ischemic stroke prevention due to blood stasis in the left atrium. (2)
    • Warfarin: INR target of 2.0–3.0; start 4 weeks prior to cardioversion.
    • DOACs/NOACs: Rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban, and dabigatran as alternatives to warfarin; no monitoring needed; contraindicated in atrial fibrillation with rheumatic mitral stenosis (1) or mechanical heart valves due to insufficient evidence supporting their safety and efficacy in these conditions. (3)
  • Risk Assessment:
    • CHA2DS2-VASc Score: For stroke risk; anticoagulate if score ≥2. 
    • HAS-BLED Score: For bleeding risk; monitor patients with score ≥3.
  • Aspirin: Not recommended due to low efficacy in preventing embolic stroke.

questions.text:
A 60 year old male patient with critical mitral stenosis presented with atrial fibrillation. He has a history of multiple episodes of transient ischemic attacks. Which of the following are true regarding the prevention of stroke in this patient?


	Only aspirin is given
	Warfarin is given
	Direct oral anticoagulants are not indicated
	Mitral valvotomy should be recommended
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2 and 3

Explanation: The true statements regarding the prevention of stroke in this patient are 2 and 3.

Atrial Fibrillation

Features
  • Characterized by abnormal automatic firing and multiple re-entry circuits.
  • Atria beat rapidly and ineffectively; ventricles activated irregularly
  • Produces an "irregularly irregular" pulse
  • Palpitations, syncope, and breathlessness can be present
  • Asymptomatic AF: Can present as systemic embolism and stroke
ECG Features
  • QRS Complexes: Irregular but normal
  • P Waves: Absent; baseline may show irregular fibrillation waves
  • Ventricular Rate:
    • Fast at onset (120-160 beats/min)
    • Slower in chronic AF due to medication effects and AV nodal fatigue

Management

Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation:

  • First-line Therapy: Beta-blockers are effective in patients with CAD, hypertension, and heart failure. 
  • Class Ic Drugs: Propafenone or flecainide to prevent episodes (not for patients with CAD or LV dysfunction).
  • Class III Drugs:
    • Amiodarone: Most effective but with significant side effects; used when other treatments fail. 
    • Dronedarone: Alternative to amiodarone; contraindicated in heart failure.
  • Rate Control: Digoxin and verapamil for AV node conduction slowing, but not for AF prevention. 
  • Catheter Ablation: Considered for patients with drug-resistant AF; prevents AF in ~75% of cases but may have complications.
 

Persistent Atrial Fibrillation:

  • Rhythm Control:
    • Cardioversion: Electrical or pharmacological (e.g., intravenous flecainide or amiodarone).
    • Timing: Immediate if AF <48 hours in unstable patients. 
    • Anticoagulation is required if AF ≥48 hours to prevent thromboembolic events. 
    • Prophylactic Amiodarone: To reduce recurrence risk.
  • Rate Control:
    • Medications: Digoxin, β-blockers, or rate-limiting calcium antagonists (verapamil, diltiazem).
    • Combination Therapy: Digoxin with β-blockers; avoid combining calcium antagonists with β-blockers.
    • Pace and Ablate: Permanent pacemaker with AV nodal block for symptomatic AF.
 

Thromboprophylaxis:

  • Anticoagulation: Required for ischemic stroke prevention due to blood stasis in the left atrium. 
    • Warfarin: INR target of 2.0–3.0; start 4 weeks prior to cardioversion; recommended in patients with moderate to severe mitral stenosis or mechanical valves. (2)
    • DOACs/NOACs: Rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban, and dabigatran as alternatives to warfarin; no monitoring needed; contraindicated in atrial fibrillation with rheumatic mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves due to insufficient evidence supporting their safety and efficacy in these conditions. (3)
  • Risk Assessment:
    • CHA2DS2-VASc Score: For stroke risk; anticoagulate if score ≥2. 
    • HAS-BLED Score: For bleeding risk; monitor patients with score ≥3.
  • Aspirin: Not recommended due to low efficacy in preventing embolic stroke. (1)

Mitral valvotomy should be recommended (Option 1): Mitral valvotomy is not recommended for stroke prevention in this patient as it is indicated for symptomatic patients with isolated severe mitral stenosis and a valve area < 1.5 cm². It is contraindicated in the presence of left atrial thrombus, which is a common concern in atrial fibrillation.

questions.text:
Which of the following branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery?

1. Superior gluteal artery

2. Inferior gluteal artery

3. Superior vesical artery

4. Middle rectal artery

5. Inferior vesical artery

6. Vaginal artery
questions.solution:
The anterior division of the internal iliac artery gives rise to multiple visceral and parietal branches supplying the pelvic organs, perineum, and lower limb. The correct answer includes all the relevant branches from this division.

Branches of the Internal Iliac Artery:

Division

Branches

Anterior Division (Primarily supplies pelvic organs, perineum, and medial thigh)

Inferior gluteal artery, superior vesical artery, middle rectal artery, inferior vesical artery, vaginal artery, obturator artery, internal pudendal artery, uterine artery

Posterior Division (Primarily supplies the pelvic wall and gluteal region)

Superior gluteal artery, iliolumbar artery, lateral sacral artery

1,2,3,5- (Option A) : Incorrect because superior gluteal artery (1) belongs to the posterior division.

2,3,4,6- (Option B) : Incorrect because it excludes inferior vesical artery (5), which is an anterior division branch.

1,4,5,6- (Option D) : Incorrect because superior gluteal artery (1) belongs to the posterior division.

questions.text: What is the most common complication of the central line insertion below the marked bone?
questions.solution:
The most common complication of central line insertion below the clavicle (subclavian vein approach) is arterial puncture. This occurs when the subclavian artery is inadvertently punctured during the procedure. The subclavian vein lies posterior and inferior to the clavicle, making it prone to accidental arterial injury.

Complications of Central Line Insertion (Subclavian Approach):

Complication

Description

Arterial puncture

The most common complication; can cause hematoma or hemorrhage.

Pneumothorax

Risk due to proximity to the lung apex.

Thrombophlebitis

Less common, but can occur due to catheter irritation.

Chylothorax

Rare, occurs if the thoracic duct (left side) is injured.

Infection (Empyema, Sepsis)

Can occur if strict aseptic precautions are not maintained.

Thrombophlebitis (Option B): Incorrect, because it is less common compared to arterial puncture.

Empyema (Option C): Incorrect, as infection-related complications occur later, not acutely.

Chylothorax (Option D): Incorrect, as it is rare and occurs only on the left side due to thoracic duct injury.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match:
questions.solution:
• 1 (Cilia) – These are hair-like projections on the apical surface of columnar epithelial cells, helping in mucus clearance via coordinated movement. Correct
  • 2 (Goblet cells) – These are unicellular mucus-secreting glands dispersed within the pseudostratified columnar epithelium, aiding in airway moisture and protection. Correct
  • 3 (Nuclei of epithelial cells) – The nuclei are at varying levels, creating a pseudostratified appearance. Correct
  • 4 (Incorrectly matched as Lamina Propria) – This label belongs to the epithelial layer, whereas the lamina propria is the connective tissue layer beneath the basement membrane. Incorrect

Pseudostratified Ciliated Columnar Epithelium (Respiratory Epithelium)

Feature

Description

Location

Found in the trachea, bronchi, and nasal cavity.

Cell Types

Ciliated columnar cells, goblet cells, basal cells, and brush cells.

Function

Mucociliary clearance – Cilia move mucus upward, trapping and removing debris.

Lamina Propria

A loose connective tissue layer beneath the epithelium, not part of the epithelial layer.

Pathological Relevance

Loss of cilia function leads to chronic respiratory infections (e.g., in Kartagener syndrome).

1 - Cilia (Option A): Correct, as cilia are present on the epithelial surface.

2 - Goblet cells (Option C): Correct, as goblet cells are present within the pseudostratified epithelium.

3 - Nuclei of epithelial cells (Option D): Correct, as these belong to pseudostratified columnar epithelium.

questions.text: Which part of this bone is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa?
questions.solution:
The coracoid process (1) is the only palpable part of the scapula in the infraclavicular fossa. It lies deep to the clavicle, but its tip can be felt by pressing below the lateral third of the clavicle.

Palpable Bony Landmarks of the Scapula

Structure

Palpability

Spine of scapula

Easily palpable posteriorly.

Acromion

Most lateral and superior part, prominent.

Coracoid process

Palpable in the infraclavicular fossa, serves as an attachment site.

Inferior angle

Palpable at the lower medial end of the scapula.

Acromion (Option B-2): Incorrect, as it is palpable over the shoulder, not in the infraclavicular fossa.

Lateral angle of scapula (Option C-3): Incorrect, as it is posteriorly palpable, not infraclavicular.

Inferior angle (Option D-4): Incorrect, as it is only palpable at the lower scapular border.

questions.text: The cell marked in the below slide is inhibitory to
questions.solution:
The marked cell is a Purkinje cell, identified by its large cell body and prominent nucleus in the cerebellar cortex. Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use GABA as their neurotransmitter. Their primary function is to inhibit the deep nuclei of the cerebellum, which are responsible for motor coordination and fine-tuning of movements.

Purkinje Cells and Their Inhibitory Role

Feature

Details

Location

Cerebellar cortex (between molecular & granular layers)

Neurotransmitter

GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid)

Function

Inhibitory regulation of deep cerebellar nuclei

Target

Deep nuclei of cerebellum

Significance

Helps coordinate fine motor control by regulating output from deep cerebellar nuclei

Vestibular nuclei (Option B): Incorrect, as Purkinje cells do send some projections here but do not primarily inhibit them.

Inferior olivary nucleus (Option C): Incorrect, as it provides excitatory input to Purkinje cells, but is not their target.

Basal ganglia (Option D): Incorrect, as Purkinje cells have no direct connection to the basal ganglia.

questions.text: Fibers from the marked structure end in which of the following areas of the thalamus?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the mammillary body, which is part of the Papez circuit, responsible for memory processing. The mammillothalamic tract carries fibers from the mammillary bodies to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. The anterior nucleus further relays this information to the cingulate gyrus, playing a crucial role in learning and memory.

Mammillary Bodies and Their Connections

Feature

Details

Structure

Mammillary bodies (part of the hypothalamus)

Pathway

Mammillothalamic tract

Target in Thalamus

Anterior nucleus of the thalamus

Function

Memory processing, part of the Papez circuit

Clinical Significance

Damage leads to memory deficits (e.g., Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome)

Posterior nucleus (Option A): Incorrect, as it is involved in pain perception and thermoregulation, not in the Papez circuit.

Reticular nucleus (Option B): Incorrect, as it regulates thalamocortical activity but does not receive direct input from the mammillary bodies.

Ventral lateral nucleus (Option D): Incorrect, as it is involved in motor relay from the cerebellum and basal ganglia, not memory processing.

questions.text: The para-sagittal section of the abdomen is given below. What is the superior border of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
• The marked structure in the image is the epiploic foramen (of Winslow), which connects the greater sac and the lesser sac (omental bursa).
  • It is an important anatomical passage located posterior to the free edge of the lesser omentum (hepatoduodenal ligament).
  • The superior border of the epiploic foramen is formed by the caudate lobe of the liver.

Epiploic Foramen and Its Anatomical Borders

Feature

Details

Definition

Communication between greater sac and lesser sac

Superior Border

Caudate lobe of the liver

Anterior Border

Hepatoduodenal ligament (portal triad)

Posterior Border

Inferior vena cava

Inferior Border

First part of duodenum

Clinical Importance

Internal hernias, Pringle maneuver in hepatic trauma

  • Clinical Relevance:
    • The epiploic foramen is significant in internal herniation (e.g., herniation of bowel loops into the lesser sac).
    • Surgical importance: It provides access to the portal triad in the Pringle maneuver, used to control hepatic bleeding.

 

Duodenum (Option B): Incorrect because it forms the inferior border, not the superior.

Lesser omentum (Option C): Incorrect because it forms the anterior border, not the superior.

Inferior vena cava (Option D): Incorrect because it forms the posterior border, not the superior.

questions.text: A young child with absent thymus is brought to the OPD with features of hypoparathyroidism and tetany. Which of the following marked areas in the picture is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image represents the development of pharyngeal pouches. The condition described is DiGeorge syndrome, which is caused by defective development of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches, leading to:

  • Absence of thymus → Immunodeficiency (T-cell deficiency)

  • Hypoparathyroidism → Hypocalcemia and tetany

The 3rd pharyngeal pouch (marked as 3) gives rise to:

  • Thymus

  • Inferior parathyroid glands

The 4th pharyngeal pouch gives rise to:

  • Superior parathyroid glands

  • Ultimobranchial body (C-cells of thyroid)

Since DiGeorge syndrome mainly affects the 3rd pouch, the correct answer is Option C (3).

Pharyngeal Pouch Derivatives

Pharyngeal Pouch

Derivatives

1st Pouch

Eustachian tube (Auditory tube)

Middle ear cavity

Mastoid air cells

2nd Pouch

Palatine tonsil (epithelial crypts)

Tonsillar fossa

3rd Pouch

Inferior parathyroid glands

Thymus

4th Pouch

Superior parathyroid glands

Ultimobranchial body (forms C-cells of the thyroid)

DiGeorge Syndrome:

  • Cause: Deletion of 22q11.2, leading to defective neural crest migration

  • CATCH-22

    • Cardiac defects (Tetralogy of Fallot, truncus arteriosus)

    • Abnormal face

    • Thymic aplasia (T-cell immunodeficiency)

    • Cleft palate

    • Hypocalcemia (due to parathyroid agenesis)

    • 22q11.2 deletion

1- (Option A): Incorrect, as the 1st pouch develops into the Eustachian tube and middle ear cavity, unrelated to the thymus or parathyroid.

2- (Option B): Incorrect, as the 2nd pouch forms the palatine tonsils, not affected in DiGeorge syndrome.

4-(Option D): Incorrect, as while the 4th pouch forms the superior parathyroid glands, the major defect in DiGeorge syndrome is due to failure of 3rd pouch development.

questions.text: A 25 year old male presented with symptoms of inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4 th and 5 th digits. He was also not able to hold a piece of paper between his fingers. What is the likely site of injury?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with:

  • Inability to flex the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints of the 4th and 5th digits
  • Weakness in finger adduction, causing difficulty in holding a piece of paper (Froment’s sign positive)

These findings suggest ulnar nerve injury affecting the medial half of flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) and intrinsic hand muscles, which occurs at the level of the medial epicondyle (cubital tunnel syndrome).

Ulnar Nerve Injuries by Site

Site of Injury

Common Causes

Clinical Features

Key Signs

Brachial Plexus (C8-T1 roots)

Trauma, birth injury (Klumpke’s palsy)

Weakness in intrinsic hand muscles, forearm flexors, ± Horner’s syndrome

Claw hand, sensory loss in medial forearm/hand

Cubital Tunnel (Elbow)

Compression at medial epicondyle, prolonged flexion, trauma

Weak grip, hypothenar atrophy, numbness in 4th/5th digits

Positive Tinel’s at elbow, Froment’s sign

Guyon’s Canal (Wrist)

Cyclists, repetitive trauma (handlebar palsy)

Weak finger abduction/adduction, intrinsic muscle weakness

No dorsal hand sensory loss, claw hand more pronounced

Distal Ulnar Nerve (Hand)

Lacerations, trauma

Isolated intrinsic hand weakness, claw hand

Froment’s sign, Wartenberg’s sign

Shaft of Humerus (Option A): Incorrect because it affects the radial nerve, leading to wrist drop but not ulnar nerve dysfunction.

Lateral Epicondyle (Option B): Incorrect because it affects the radial nerve and leads to weak wrist and finger extension (tennis elbow).

Neck of Humerus (Option D): Incorrect because it affects the axillary nerve, leading to deltoid muscle weakness and loss of sensation over the lateral shoulder.

questions.text: At which level does the nerve supply for the marked structure arise?
questions.solution:
• The image is a coronal CT scan of the orbit, highlighting the extraocular muscles, specifically the medial rectus muscles (marked structures).
  • The medial rectus is supplied by the oculomotor nerve (CN III), which originates from the oculomotor nucleus in the midbrain.
  • The oculomotor nucleus receives input from the Red Nucleus, which is involved in coordinating eye movements and muscle tone through the rubro-oculomotor connections.
  • The Red Nucleus is an important structure in the midbrain tegmentum, involved in motor coordination, particularly in controlling extraocular muscles via the rubro-oculomotor pathway. It plays a role in conjugate gaze and eye movement control, making it relevant to the medial rectus function.

Oculomotor Nerve and Its Control

Structure

Function

Oculomotor Nucleus (Midbrain)

Origin of CN III, controls most extraocular muscles

Red Nucleus (Midbrain)

Regulates motor coordination and eye movements via rubro-oculomotor pathways

Edinger-Westphal Nucleus

Provides parasympathetic fibers for pupil constriction and accommodation

Medial Rectus Muscle

Controlled by CN III, responsible for adduction of the eye

Blood Supply

Supplied by paramedian branches of the basilar artery and PCA

Clinical Correlation

Oculomotor nerve palsy causes ptosis, mydriasis, and eye deviation ("down and out")

Subthalamic Nucleus (Option B): Incorrect because it is primarily involved in indirect basal ganglia pathways and has no direct role in extraocular muscle control.

Decussation of Pyramidal Tract (Option C): Incorrect because it primarily relates to corticospinal tract fibers, which control voluntary movements of the limbs, not the eyes.

Olivary Nucleus (Option D): Incorrect because it is part of the olivocerebellar system, which is responsible for motor learning and coordination, rather than direct eye movement control.

questions.text: What is the cause of the relaxation of the intestinal segment following the segment containing the food bolus during peristalsis?
questions.solution:
VIP is the primary neurotransmitter responsible for causing relaxation of the smooth muscle in the segment of the intestine following the food bolus during peristalsis. It promotes relaxation in the distal segment, allowing coordinated propulsion.

 

Peristalsis:

  • Reflex response is initiated by the stretching of the gut wall due to the contents of the lumen.

 

Location:

  • It occurs throughout the gastrointestinal tract, from the esophagus to the rectum.

 

Mechanism:

  • Stretching triggers circular contraction behind the stimulus and relaxation in front of it.
  • The wave of contraction moves in an oral-to-caudal direction.
  • Propels the contents of the lumen forward at rates of 2 to 25 cm/s.

 

Regulation:

  • Peristaltic activity is influenced by autonomic input but occurs independently of extrinsic innervation.
  • Local stretch releases serotonin, activating sensory neurons that stimulate the myenteric plexus.
  • Cholinergic neurons in the myenteric plexus:
    • In retrograde direction: release substance P and acetylcholine, causing contraction behind the bolus.
    • In anterograde direction: activate the neurons releasing nitric oxide (NO) and vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP), causing relaxation ahead of the bolus (Figure below).

 

Functional Integration:

  • Peristalsis is an example of the integrated activity of the enteric nervous system.

Neurotransmitters Involved in Peristalsis

Neurotransmitter

Role

Mechanism

Acetylcholine (ACh) (Option D ruled out)

Stimulates contraction

Acts on muscarinic receptors, increases motility

Substance P (Option B ruled out)

Promotes ascending contraction

Released by mucosal stimulation, enhances orad contraction

Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide (VIP)

Promotes relaxation

Acts on smooth muscle to induce relaxation during peristalsis

Serotonin (5-HT)

Regulates motility and initiates reflex

Released from enterochromaffin cells, activates 5-HT receptors

Nitric Oxide (NO)

Mediates relaxation

Released by inhibitory neurons, assists VIP in relaxation

Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide (CGRP)

Influences sensory signaling

Modulated by serotonin, aids in coordinating reflexes


Dopamine from Adrenergic Fibers (Option C): Dopamine has both inhibitory and excitatory effects, depending on the receptors it acts on. It is not released during peristalsis.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not associated with renal auto-regulation?
questions.solution:
Renal sympathetic system fibers are not involved in the direct autoregulation of GFR. While the sympathetic system can influence renal function during stress, it is not a primary mechanism of renal autoregulation.

Renal Autoregulation:

Mechanism

Description

Function

Time Frame

Contribution

Myogenic Response

Afferent arteriole smooth muscle contracts to pressure.

Constriction of arterioles to maintain RBF and GFR.

Seconds to minutes

~50%

Tubuloglomerular Feedback

Macula densa cells sense NaCl concentration.

Constriction/dilation of afferent arteriole based on NaCl levels.

30-60 seconds

35-50%

Third Regulatory Mechanism

Involves metabolic factors like ATP, ANG II.

Slower response impacting RBF and GFR.

Minutes to hours

<15%

Connecting Tubule Feedback

Feedback from connecting tubule on afferent arteriole tone.

Dilation of afferent arteriole in response to sodium increase.

Variable

Fine-tuning

questions.text: What is the formula used to calculate Stroke Volume (SV) in the context of cardiac physiology?
questions.solution:
• Stroke Volume (SV) refers to the amount of blood ejected by the left ventricle of the heart in a single contraction.
  • The formula to calculate Stroke Volume is based on the difference between the End Diastolic Volume (EDV) and the End-Systolic Volume (ESV) and is around 70 ml.

 

Stroke Volume (SV)

  • Represents the blood ejected from the left ventricle per heartbeat.
  • Determined by the horizontal distance between end-diastolic volume (EDV) and end-systolic volume (ESV).
  • Formula: SV = EDV - ESV.

questions.text: Which lobe is affected by a lesion that results in a deficit in hand-eye coordination?
questions.solution:
Impairment of hand-eye coordination is commonly associated with lesions in the brain’s parietal lobe especially in the Brodmann area 5 and 7.

The parietal lobe integrates visual input from the occipital lobe and motor output from the frontal lobe and acts as an association cortex.. It helps process and integrate sensory inputs to guide motor movements and coordinate hand-eye interactions and is the most important area

Brodmann Areas:

Definition

  • Numbered regions of the cerebral cortex identified by Korbinian Brodmann, based on neuronal structure and arrangement.
  • Linked to sensory processing, motor control, and cognitive functions.

Key Brodmann Areas and Functions

Brodmann Area

Function

1, 2, 3

Primary somatosensory cortex; processes tactile information.

4

Primary motor cortex; controls voluntary movements.

5, 7

Somatosensory association areas; integrate sensory input.

6

Premotor/supplementary motor areas; plan movements.

17

Primary visual cortex; processes visual data.

18, 19

Visual association areas; advanced visual processing.

22

Wernicke's area; facilitates language comprehension.

44, 45

Broca's area; involved in speech production.

Frontal lobe (Option B): The frontal lobe is responsible for motor output and is involved in the hand-eye movements, but the parietal lobe is the most important.

Temporal lobe (Option C): The temporal lobe is mainly associated with auditory processing, memory, and language functions, and lesions in this lobe typically do not cause significant impairments in hand-eye coordination.

Occipital lobe (Option D): The occipital lobe is primarily responsible for visual processing and is involved in the hand-eye movements, but the parietal lobe is the most important

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause a right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve?
questions.solution:
Factors causing a right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve are:

  • Increased temperature
  • Decreased pH
  • Increased PCO2
  • Increased 2,3-DPG
  • Hypoxia

 

Instead, increased HbF causes a left shift of the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve.

 

Oxygen-Haemoglobin Dissociation Curve:

 

The oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve represents the relationship between the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) and the percentage of haemoglobin saturated with oxygen (SaO2).

 

Key Points:

 

  • Sigmoid Shape: Reflects varying Hb affinity for oxygen at different PO2 levels.
  • Steep Phase: Rapid increase in Hb saturation with PO2.
  • Plateau Phase: Minimal change in Hb saturation despite large changes in PO2.

 

Phases:

 

 

Steep phase

Plateau phase

Range

10-60 mm Hg

60-100 mm Hg

Characteristics
  • A rapid increase in Hb saturation.
  • Hb ~90% saturated at PO2 of 60 mm Hg.
  • Curve flattens.
  • Small increases in Hb saturation despite PO2 rise.

Significance
  • Curve flattens.
  • Small increases in Hb saturation despite PO2 rise.
  • It provides a safety buffer.
  • It maintains high Hb saturation (~90%) despite moderate PO2 decreases.
  • It ensures stable oxygen delivery under varying conditions.

P50: P50 is the level of PO2 at which 50% of haemoglobin is saturated with oxygen.

  1. P50 assesses the binding affinity of haemoglobin for oxygen.
  2. In adults at sea level, the normal P50 occurs at a PO2 of 27 mm Hg.
  3. Alteration in the P50 value has a greater impact on the steep phase of the curve.
  4. If P50 is high, it signifies a decrease in Hb's affinity for oxygen, which is seen in the right shift of the oxygen hemoglobin equilibrium curve.
  5. Conversely, if P50 is low, it signifies a shift of the curve to the left, in which Hb's affinity for oxygen increases.

questions.text: What are the chloride equilibrium potentials when the extracellular concentration is 100 mmol/L, and the intracellular concentration is 10 mmol/L?
questions.solution:
Equilibrium Potential Calculation for Chloride (Cl⁻)

Nernst Equation:

Where:

  • E: Equilibrium potential
  • R: Gas constant (8.314 J)
  • T: Temperature (310 K)
  • z: Ion valency (−1-1−1 for Cl⁻)
  • F: Faraday constant (96485 C/mol)
  • [Outside]=100 mmol/L
  • [Inside]=10 mmol/L

≈ -61,54mV

Result:
The equilibrium potential of chloride (Cl⁻) is approximately -60 mV.

  • The Nernst equation calculates the electrical potential difference across a membrane (Nernst potential) that balances the diffusion of a specific ion, preventing further net movement despite a concentration gradient.
  • The Nernst equation calculates the Nernst potential (EMF) for a single, univalent ion (an ion with a +1 or -1 charge) at normal body temperature (37°C)
  • The Nernst potential magnitude depends on the ion concentration ratio across the membrane; larger differences result in higher potentials.
  • Nernst equation calculates the potential for a single ion, although cell membranes are permeable to multiple ions.

 

Applications of the Nernst Equation:

  • Explains how ion concentration differences generate electrical potential across a selectively permeable membrane.
  • Basis for the Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz equation, which calculates membrane potential considering multiple ions and their permeabilities.

questions.text: Which of the following jugular venous pressure (JVP) waves corresponds to the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
• The jugular venous pressure (JVP) reflects the pressure within the right atrium and corresponds to various phases of the cardiac cycle.
  • The C wave of the JVP represents the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle. It occurs during early ventricular systole, as the tricuspid valve bulges into the right atrium due to rising pressure in the right ventricle. This transient bulging causes a slight increase in the JVP.

Jugular Venous Pressure (JVP) Waveform

 

a wave (Option A ruled out)
  • Caused by atrial systole.
  • Atrial contraction results in a temporary halt in venous inflow.
  • Some blood flows back into the veins, causing a rise in venous pressure.

c wave
  • Arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • Pressure is transmitted through the closed and bulging tricuspid valve.

x descent (Option C ruled out)
  • Ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve down

v wave
  • Corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria.
  • Occurs during diastole while the tricuspid valve is still closed.

y descent (Option D ruled out)
  • Opening of tricuspid valve causing emptying of right atrium into ventricle

questions.text:
Which sensory receptors are accountable for tactile discrimination among the options provided?

 


	Merkel disc
	Ruffini end organ
	Pacinian corpuscle
	Meissner’s corpuscle
questions.solution:
Tactile discrimination, which refers to the ability to discern fine details, textures, and shapes through touch, relies on superficial sensory receptors in the skin.

 

Both Merkel discs and Meissner’s corpuscles are involved in tactile discrimination, allowing individuals to sense and distinguish intricate textures and shapes.

 

Specialized mechanoreceptors

 

Superficial

Superficial

Deep

Deep

Discriminatory touch, Stroking

Texture, Edges, Braille

Pressure, Vibration

Sustained pressure

Rapidly adapting

Slowly adapting

Rapidly adapting

Slowly adapting

questions.text: Which of the following ions in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is responsible for the reabsorption of divalent ions?
questions.solution:
• Potassium (K⁺) plays a key role in the reabsorption of divalent ions (e.g., Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺).
  • The Na⁺/K⁺/2Cl⁻ co-transporter (NKCC2) reabsorbs sodium (Na⁺), potassium (K⁺), and chloride (Cl⁻) into the tubular cells.
  • A small amount of potassium leaks back into the tubular lumen through ROMK (Renal Outer Medullary Potassium) channels, creating a positive lumen potential.
  • This positive electrical gradient drives the paracellular reabsorption of divalent ions such as calcium (Ca²⁺) and magnesium (Mg²⁺).

H⁺ (Option A): H⁺ ions are involved in acid-base balance and are secreted into the tubular lumen by the Na⁺/H⁺ exchanger. They are not involved in the reabsorption of divalent ions like calcium (Ca²⁺) and magnesium (Mg²⁺).

HCO₃⁻ (Option B): Bicarbonate is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule and contributes to maintaining acid-base balance.It does not play a role in generating the positive lumen potential required for divalent ion reabsorption in the thick ascending limb.

Na⁺ (Option D): Sodium is reabsorbed via the Na⁺/K⁺/2Cl⁻ co-transporter (NKCC2) in the thick ascending limb. While sodium is essential for maintaining osmotic balance, it does not directly create the positive luminal potential necessary for paracellular reabsorption of divalent ions.

questions.text: The stroke volume depends on end-diastolic volume. This is best represented as?
questions.solution:
• Stroke volume refers to the amount of blood ejected by the ventricle during systole and is influenced by the end-diastolic volume (EDV), which determines the degree of ventricular stretch before contraction.
  • This is explained by the Frank-Starling law of the heart, which states that the force of contraction increases with greater ventricular filling (EDV) due to increased sarcomere stretch.
  • The length–tension relationship describes how the initial length of cardiac muscle fibers (determined by EDV) affects the tension they can generate during contraction, which directly impacts stroke volume.

 

The Frank-Starling law:

It describes the relationship between the volume of blood filling the heart (end-diastolic volume) and the force of contraction during the next heartbeat (stroke volume).

Mechanism:

  • Preload: Increased venous return leads to increased end-diastolic volume.
  • Myocardial Stretch: Greater end-diastolic volume stretches the myocardial fibers.
  • Force of Contraction: The stretched fibers generate a more forceful contraction due to the optimal overlap of actin and myosin filaments (length-tension relationship).

questions.text: A patient presented with severe watery diarrhea resembling that of rice gruel stool. Damage of which structure is likely to have resulted in this diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Rice gruel stools are characteristic of cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae infection. The cholera toxin leads to severe watery diarrhea by disrupting the intestinal epithelial barrier and increasing intestinal chloride secretion.

  • The zona occludens (tight junctions) are crucial for maintaining the integrity of the intestinal epithelial barrier by regulating paracellular permeability and preventing leakage of fluids and electrolytes between epithelial cells.
  • In cholera, the toxin disrupts tight junctions, causing increased permeability and massive loss of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, resulting in the characteristic watery diarrhea.

Gap Junction (Option B): Gap junctions are responsible for cell-to-cell communication via ionic and metabolic coupling. They are not involved in maintaining epithelial barrier function or preventing diarrhea.

Adherens Junction (Option C): These junctions mediate cell-cell adhesion and help maintain tissue architecture. While important for structural integrity, their disruption is less directly linked to diarrhea compared to tight junctions.

Hemidesmosomes (Option D): Hemidesmosomes anchor epithelial cells to the basement membrane and play a role in resisting mechanical stress. They are not involved in regulating intestinal permeability or the development of diarrhea.

questions.text: Methyl-tetrahydro-folic acid gets accumulated in deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
When the body is deficient in vitamin B12, the active form of folate (THF) cannot be produced. Methyl THF, the inactive form, becomes trapped and accumulates. This condition is also referred to as a Functional folate deficiency.

 

Vitamin B12-Dependent Enzymes:

  1. Methyl-malonyl-CoA Mutase:
    • Function: Converts methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.
    • Methyl-malonyl CoA is an intermediate in the breakdown of valine, cholesterol, odd-chain fatty acids, propionate, and carboxylation of propionyl-CoA.
    • Deficiency Impact: Leads to accumulation of methylmalonyl-CoA and increased urinary methylmalonic acid, indicating B12 deficiency status.
    • Methylmalonic acid will be normal in megaloblastic anemia caused by folate deficiency.
  2. Methionine Synthase:
    • Function: Converts homocysteine to methionine.
    • Role: Impairment affects folic acid metabolism, leading to functional folate deficiency.
    • Deficiency Impact: Causes pernicious anaemia and spinal cord degeneration due to failed methylation of arginine in myelin basic protein. This is a result of methionine deficiency in the CNS.

Folate trap:

The 2 Co-enzyme forms of vitamin B-12 are:

Adenosylcobalamin Deficiency:

Function: Coenzyme form of vitamin B12 (Adenosyl B12) essential for energy metabolism in mitochondria.

Deficiency Impact:

  • Impaired Energy Production: Reduces ATP production, causing chronic fatigue, muscle weakness, and weight loss.
  • Neurological Damage: Accumulation of neurotoxic methylmalonic acid impairs fatty acid synthesis for myelin sheath maintenance, resulting in nerve degeneration and neurological disorders.
  • Metabolic Disruptions: Disrupts amino acid and hormone metabolism, leading to broader health issues.
  1. Methylcobalamin Deficiency:

Function: The bioactive form of vitamin B12 (Methyl B12) is crucial for the methylation cycle and methionine synthesis from homocysteine.

 

Deficiency Impact:

  • Elevated Homocysteine Levels: Impairs conversion of homocysteine to methionine, raising homocysteine levels and cardiovascular risk.
  • Neurological Issues: Leads to neuropathy, cognitive decline, and other neurological disorders.
  • Anaemia: Causes megaloblastic anaemia with large, ineffective red blood cells.

B2 (Option A) Vit B2 (riboflavin) deficiency causes corneal vascularization: pink eye due to increasing vascularization cornea, cheilosis: angular stomatitis due to cracks at the corner of mouth, seborrheic dermatitis, and glossitis: magenta tongue.

B1(Option C) Vit B1 (thiamine) deficiency causes dry beriberi: which affects the CNS, and wet beriberi: which affects the CVS. In chronic alcoholics, severe vitamin B1 deficiency causes Wernicke Korsakoff psychosis syndrome: patient experiences encephalopathy and confabulations.


B6 (Option D) Vit B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency causes increased homocysteine levels in blood and urine and excretion of xanthurenic acid in urine.

questions.text: Which of the following molecular analysis methods is used to detect RNA?
questions.solution:
Reverse transcriptase PCR is used to study RNA as well as DNA. It is a quick, automated, and highly sensitive method to study RNA and also detect mutations.

 

RNA with the help of reverse transcriptase enzyme forms complementary DNA (cDNA). This cDNA is amplified using the polymerase enzyme so that multiple copies can be made and studied.

 

Sanger's method (Option A) is a DNA sequencing technique also called the dideoxy nucleotide method. It is the process of selective incorporation of chain-terminating dideoxynucleotide by DNA polymerase during in vitro DNA replication.

 

G banding (Option B) is the karyotype technique best for detecting monosomy and trisomy. With this technique,

  • Cells are arrested in the metaphase stage using colchicine.
  • In metaphase, all the chromosomes lie at the equator so that they can be easily analyzed under the microscope for any change in their number
  • Chromosomes are stained with Giemsa stain to observe a G -banding.


Western blot (Option C) is the antigen-antibody reaction (immunoblotting), used for the detection of protein antigen.

questions.text: Insulin inhibits which of the following lipase enzymes?
questions.solution:
Hormone-sensitive lipase is present in the adipose tissues which breaks down fats stored in the adipose tissue to FA + glycerol during fasting and starvation. Since it breaks fats, it is considered a catabolic enzyme. It is activated by the catabolic hormone like glucagon and inhibited by the anabolic hormone insulin.

 

Peripheral lipolysis:

  • It is a process in which triacylglycerols are hydrolyzed into free fatty acids (FFA) and glycerol.
  • This process is mediated by hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL).
  • This process occurs in adipose tissue
  • The lipase acts on triacylglycerols and converts them into diacylglycerol, the preferred substrate for HSL.

  • The glycerol released from the adipose tissue is transported to the liver and participates in glycolysis or gluconeogenesis.
  • Free fatty acids bind to albumin and are transported to muscles, where they are activated into their CoA derivatives and oxidized in mitochondria for ATP.

Regulation:

  • HSL is activated when phosphorylated with Protein kinase A, which in turn is dependent on cAMP produced in the adipocyte when catecholamines activate adenylyl cyclase.
  • Insulin dephosphorylates HSL and inactivates it.
  • The counter-regulatory hormones of insulin, such as glucagon, epinephrine, and cortisol, stimulate the activity of HSL.

 

Lipoprotein lipase (Option A) is present in the endothelium of blood vessels. It breaks down fats in the blood to FA+ glycerol, which gets absorbed into adipose tissue and gets stored as triglycerides. It is considered an anabolic enzyme. It is activated by insulin and inhibited by glucagon.

 

Pancreatic lipase (Option B) is a primary lipase enzyme that breaks down triglyceride substrates to monoglyceride + free fatty acid for absorption and storage. It is activated by insulin.

 

Gastric lipase (Option C) is present in gastric juice where fats are broken down to triglycerides for absorption and storage. It is activated by the anabolic hormone insulin.

questions.text: What are the main substrate and metabolic fuel used by RBCs during fasting?
questions.solution:
RBCs cannot use fatty acid or ketone bodies as fuel during fasting as they do not have mitochondria where beta-oxidation of fatty acid occurs. Since ketone bodies and free fatty acids are utilized via beta-oxidation which occurs in mitochondria, RBCs cannot utilize them. RBC uses glucose as a substrate for energy production in the fed, fasting, and starvation state.

Ketone body (Option A) are used as a substrate for energy production during starvation phase by vital organs brain and heart primarily. Muscles use FA and ketone bodies for energy during starvation to avoid using proteins as fuel to prevent muscle loss.

Amino acid (Option C) is used by liver as a fuel in starvation state. It is the major source of fuel for the body in a starvation state.

Free fatty acid (Option D) is used as a fuel in fasting state by

  • Heart (uses fatty acid in both fed and fasting state )
  • Liver
  • Muscle
  • Adipose tissue (uses fatty acid in both fasting and starvation state)

questions.text: The enzyme kinetics depicted in the graph is suggestive of
questions.solution:
The graph depicted is of Michaelis Menten's kinetics. Michaelis Menten's kinetics is intended to explain the broad mechanism and rate of enzyme-catalyzed reactions. The Michaelis-Menten equation is widely used to analyze enzyme kinetics and determine important parameters such as Vmax and Km.

Michalis Menten equation:

V = Vmax x S / (Km + S)

Where,

V = Velocity of reaction

Vmax = Maximum velocity of the reaction

S = Substrate concentration

Km = Michaelis constant = Substrate concentration at which the velocity of the reaction is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2)

Allosteric activation (Option A) They are regulatory enzymes /multi-subunit enzymes. The activator shifts the curve to the left while the inhibitor shifts the cure to right

Cooperative binding (Option B) One substrate binding to an enzyme increases the affinity for other substrates for enzymes.

Sigmoid curve (Option D) In the presence of allosteric modifiers the graph of enzyme–catalyzed reaction obtained is a sigmoid / S-shaped graph.

questions.text:
Which of the following diagnostic markers is /are incorrectly paired?

1. Beta glucocerebrosidase - Von Gierke disease

2. Lipase - Acute pancreatitis

3. Ceruloplasmin - Hepatolenticular degeneration

4. High LDH1: LDH2 ratio -  Myocardial infarction
questions.solution:
Von Gierke disease is a glycogen storage disease. The enzyme deficient is glucose 6 phosphatase present in the liver.


 

Glycogen Storage Disease

Enzyme Deficiency

Type 0

Glycogen synthase deficiency

Type I (von Gierke's Disease)

Glucose-6-phosphatase

Type II (Pompe's Disease)

Acid α-glucosidase (acid maltase)

Type III (Cori's Disease)

Debranching enzyme (amylo-1,6-glucosidase)

Type IV (Andersen's Disease)

Branching enzyme

Type V (McArdle's Disease)

Muscle phosphorylase (myophosphorylase)

Type VI (Hers' Disease)

Liver phosphorylase

Type VII (Tarui's Disease)

Phosphofructokinase (muscle type)

Beta glucocerebrosidase is elevated in Gaucher's disease which is a type of sphingolipidosis (Statement 1)

Lipases are elevated in case of acute pancreatitis (Statement 2)

Ceruloplasmin is elevated in case of hepatolenticular degeneration (Statement 3)

Normally LDH2 present in the RBC is higher than LDH1 which is present in the heart. When this ratio is reversed, it is suggestive of myocardial infarction. (Statement 4)

questions.text: Which of the following consumes the highest energy during assimilation?
questions.solution:
Proteins consume the highest energy during assimilation as they have the highest thermogenic effect and require maximum energy.

Carbohydrates (Option B) utilizes less energy for assimilation 5%.

MUFA (Option C) has a single double bond and consumes the least energy to be broken down.

PUFA (Option D) are essential amino acids required by our body and require the least energy to be broken down.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with a defect in collagen maturity?
questions.solution:
Vitamin C plays an important role in collagen synthesis which helps in wound repair and healing. Lack of vitamin C causes Scurvy. Scurvy is associated with defects in collagen maturity.

Vitamin C Deficiency Manifestations:

  • Scurvy: Severe deficiency leads to scurvy, characterized by weakness, fatigue, and swollen gums.
    • Barlow’s Disease: Occurs in infants (6-12 months) if dietary vitamin C is inadequate, leading to similar symptoms.
  • Hemorrhagic Tendency: Abnormal collagen makes capillaries fragile, resulting in easy bruising (petechiae, ecchymoses) and internal bleeding (epistaxis, hematuria).
  • Oral Cavity Issues: Gums become painful and spongy, and teeth may be lost due to delayed wound healing.
  • Bone Weakness: Impaired osteoid formation leads to weak, easily fractured bones and possible joint hemorrhages.
  • Anemia: Causes microcytic, hypochromic anemia due to blood loss, decreased iron absorption, or low tetrahydrofolic acid.

Rickets (Option B) is caused due to the deficiency of vitamin D in children. In adults deficiency of vitamin D causes osteomalacia.

Beriberi (Option C) is caused due to deficiency of vitamin B1. The most common cause of B1 deficiency is alcoholism.

Night blindness (Option D) occurs due to a deficiency of vitamin A. Earliest manifestation of vit A deficiency is night blindness.

questions.text:
Which of the following is the best test for quantitative analysis of an RNA sample?

PCR: polymerase chain reaction

RT PCR: Reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction
questions.solution:
RT-PCR is used to convert RNA into cDNA, and then real-time PCR is performed to quantify the cDNA. Hence, this approach can be suitable for quantitative analysis of RNA.

 

Real-time PCR (Option A) can analyze DNA as it is getting synthesized, enabling us to know if there is a problem in the amplification process.

 

Reverse transcriptase PCR (Option B) is a technique used to amplify RNA by first converting it into complementary DNA (cDNA) using reverse transcriptase enzyme. While RT-PCR is useful for detecting and amplifying RNA, it does not provide direct quantitative analysis. Additional steps, such as gel electrophoresis or hybridization, would be required for quantification.


PCR-restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP) (Option C) is a technique used to detect genetic variations by analyzing the length differences in PCR-amplified DNA fragments after digestion with specific restriction enzymes.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding mitochondrial DNA?


	Higher rate of mutations as compared to the nuclear genome
	Double-stranded circular DNA with about 16,000 base pairs
	A slight change in nucleotide sequence as compared to cellular DNA
	Encodes all electron transport chain proteins
questions.solution:
The mitochondrial DNA is circular ds DNA containing about 16,000 base pairs and 37 genes. Mitochondrial DNA has a high rate of mutations as compared to nuclear DNA due to no introns

(introns prevent mutation). There is no DNA repair mechanism in mitochondria. Thus, 1 and 2 are correct.

 

Mitochondria DNA:

1. Circular ds DNA contains around 16,000 bp, 37 genes (1% of total cellular DNA)

2. ETC requires 67 proteins. 13/67 = 19% of proteins are derived from mitochondrial DNA

3. Mitochondrial DNA is present only in eukaryotes and resembles prokaryotic DNA

4. mtDNA has a high rate of mutation as compared to nuclear DNA due to no introns (introns prevent mutation),No DNA repair enzyme in mitochondria and high OFR production from ETC operation

5. Mitochondria have their own ribosomes to synthesize their proteins

questions.text: A patient with thiamine deficiency develops lactic acidosis. Which of the following enzymes is affected?
questions.solution:
Thiamine (vitamin B1) is an essential coenzyme involved in several metabolic pathways, including the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA through the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC).

 

When deficient, the activity of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is impaired. As a result, there is a buildup of pyruvate. This pyruvate is then diverted to other metabolic pathways, like the conversion to lactic acid (lactate), resulting in lactic acidosis.

 

Thiamine deficiency:

The Aleurone layer of cereals (food grains) is a rich source of thiamine. Therefore, whole wheat flour and unpolished hand-pound rice have better nutritive value than completely polished refined foods.

When the grains are polished, the aleurone layer is usually removed.

Biochemical parameters:

  • Thiamine deficiency affects the enzyme transketolase, which is involved in the pentose phosphate pathway.
    • Measuring transketolase activity in red blood cells is a specific test for thiamine deficiency and can confirm the diagnosis.
    • Erythrocyte transketolase activity is reduced; this is the earliest manifestation seen even before clinical disturbances.

 

Conditions

Biochemical Role of Thiamine

Deficiency Manifestations

Dry Beriberi

Essential for carbohydrate metabolism and nerve function

Peripheral neuritis, sensory disturbances, difficulty walking, and paralysis due to CNS manifestations.

Wet Beriberi

Thiamine is necessary for the PDH complex and low activity causes Lactic acidosis. Lactic acidosis causes vasodilatation and hence cardiovascular manifestations.

Cardiovascular manifestations such as oedema, palpitations, breathlessness, and heart failure.

Maple Syrup Urine Disease

Cofactor for decarboxylation of branched-chain keto acids

Accumulation of branched-chain keto acids leads to convulsions, severe mental retardation, vomiting, acidosis, coma, and death.

Lactic Acidosis

Cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase, converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA

Impaired conversion leads to increased lactate and pyruvate levels, causing lactic acidosis.


 

Pyruvate carboxylase (Option A) is not directly involved in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. Pyruvate carboxylase is responsible for the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate in an anaplerotic reaction that replenishes TCA cycle intermediates. It is not directly affected by thiamine deficiency in the context of lactic acidosis.

 

Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (Option C) is responsible for the conversion of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP), an important step in gluconeogenesis. It is not directly involved in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA and is not typically affected by thiamine deficiency.


Transketolase (Option D) is involved in the non-oxidative phase of the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP), which generates ribose-5-phosphate and other sugars. Transketolase requires thiamine pyrophosphate as a cofactor.

questions.text: Which of the following tests will be positive in the urine of a patient who has undergone prolonged starvation?
questions.solution:
Rothera's test is done for the detection of ketone bodies which

are produced as a result of starvation/fasting. The purple color ring at the junction of 2 liquids is a positive test due to acetoacetate and acetone

Benedict test (Image 1) : Used for the detection of reducing sugars in a complex

  • Simple carbohydrates containing a free ketone or aldehyde functional group can be identified with this test.
  • The test is based on Benedict’s reagent (also known as Benedict’s solution)
  • When exposed to reducing sugars, the reactions undergone by Benedict’s reagent result in the formation of a brick-red precipitate, which indicates a positive Benedict test.

Heat coagulation test (Image 2) is done for the detection of proteins in a sample

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image
questions.solution:
Roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides)

Habitat

Adult worms reside in the small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum) and are the largest nematode parasites in humans.

Morphology
 

Adult Worms: Large, cylindrical, with tapering ends and pale pink color that turns white outside the body.

Male Worms:

  • Smaller than females (15-30 cm long, 2-4 mm thick)
  • A ventrally curved posterior end and two copulatory spicules.

Female Worms:

  • Larger than males
  • Straight, conical posterior end (Option C) & a vulvar groove aiding in mating.

Reproduction

A single female can lay up to 200,000 eggs daily, which are expelled in the feces.

Host

Humans only

Infective Form

Embryonated eggs with L2 larvae.

Transmission

Ingestion of eggs from contaminated soil, food, or water.

Stongyloides Stercoralis (Option A) The female worm is thin, transparent and the male worm is shorter and broader than the female.

Enterobius Vermicularis (Option B) is known as Pinworm. The adults are short, white, fusiform worms with pointed ends, looking like bits of white thread and the female worm is 8-13 mm long and 0.3-0.5 mm thick, its posterior third is drawn into a thin pointed pin-like tail.

Ancylostoma Duodenale (Option C) They are known as hookworms. The male worm is smaller than the female worm. The posterior end of the male is expanded into a copulatory bursa, which consists of three lobes. The female worm is larger. Its hind end is conoid, with a subterminal anus situated ventrally.

questions.text: What is the underlying factor responsible for inducing aplastic crisis in individuals with hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical Manifestations of Parvovirus infections:
 
 
  • Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)
    • Children: "Slapped cheek" facial rash.
    • Adult women: Symmetrical polyarthropathy, often in hand and knee joints.
  • Transient Aplastic Crisis (Option D):
    • Severe acute anemia in patients with pre-existing hemolytic anemia.
  • Pure Red Cell Aplasia:
    • Chronic anemia in immunocompromised individuals due to persistent B19 infection.
  • Non-Immune Hydrops Fetalis:
    • Fatal fetal anemia and death; occurs via transplacental transmission (30% of cases)
    • Highest risk in the second trimester.
  • Papular-Purpuric Gloves and Socks Syndrome:
    • Painful, itchy, and symmetric swelling and erythema of distal hands and feet; may mimic acute meningococcemia.

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • PCR: Highly sensitive, detects viral DNA (VP1, VP2 genes) in serum, tissue, or respiratory secretions.
  • ELISA: Detects IgM antibody (early indicator, elevated 2–3 months) and IgG against VP1 and VP2 antigens.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Detects viral antigens in fetal tissues and bone marrow.
  • Bone marrow cytology shows Giant pro-erythroblasts with multiple cytoplasmic projections that look like "dog ears" or "pseudopodia".

Pox virus (Option A) is a large and complex virus known to cause two major diseases smallpox and molluscum contagiosum.

Epstein-Barr virus (Option B) (EBV) is a member of the herpesvirus family. EBV can cause majorly infectious mononucleosis, gastric carcinoma, Burkitt's lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma:

Adenovirus (Option C) is known to cause various benign diseases like upper and lower respiratory tract infections, gastroenteritis in children, urinary tract infections, and conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A stool sample is collected. The specimen is processed for examination and is labeled at different levels as A, B, C, and D. Identify the level at which parasitic ova will be seen when viewed under a microscope.
questions.solution:
• In the given information where the formol-ether sedimentation technique is mentioned and level D is labeled at the base of the tube, it indicates that parasitic ova will be seen at this level when viewed under a microscope.
  • Formol-ether sedimentation is a commonly used technique for concentrating parasites and ova from stool samples when the egg burden is low. In this technique, the stool sample is mixed with a formalin-ether solution. The high specific gravity of protozoan cysts and helminth eggs compared to water, the eggs sinks to the bottom. Formalin fixes the eggs, larvae, oocysts, and spores so that they are no longer infectious, as well as preserves their morphology. Fecal debris is extracted into the ethyl acetate phase of the solution.
  • The different levels represented by markings are:
  • Level 1: represents the topmost layer of the sample and typically contains ether.
  • Level II: contain some debris.
  • Level III: contains formalin.
  • Level IV: protozoan cyst and eggs.

Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.text: Which specific cell plays a role in type IV/delayed-type hypersensitivity?
questions.solution:
• Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction is cell-mediated, and the characteristic cells called TDTH cells (delayed type of hypersensitivity T cells) are the principal mediators of type IV reactions.
  • The antigen-presenting cells process and present the antigenic peptides along with MHC-II to the helper T cells. TH cells are differentiated to form TDTH cells.

T Helper Subset

Key Cytokines

Major Functions

Role in Immunity

TH1 Cells

• IL-2

• IFN-γ

• TNF-β

• Activate macrophages

• Enhance cell-mediated immunity

• Stimulate cytotoxic T cells

• Protection against intracellular pathogens

• Mediate delayed-type hypersensitivity

TH2 Cells

• IL-4

• IL-5

• IL-6

• IL-10

• IL-13

• Promote B cell proliferation

• Enhance antibody production

• Stimulate IgE class switching

• Promote eosinophil growth

• Protection against extracellular pathogens

• Mediate allergic responses

• Involved in helminth immunity

TH17 Cells

• IL-17

• IL-22

• Recruit neutrophils

• Enhance inflammation

• Promote tissue inflammation

• Protection at mucosal surfaces

• Involved in autoimmune diseases

• Contribute to inflammatory conditions

Macrophage (Option B) In type 4 hypersensitivity reaction, macrophages are activated as an endpoint of the reaction but are mediated through T cell activation.

Dendritic cells (Option C) They are the macrophages found in the epidermis and act as APCs. They have large dendritic projections used for capturing various pathogens.

Neutrophils (Option D) They are primary immune cells and act as first-response cells during acute inflammation. They are not involved in hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following is a xenodiagnostic method?

choices.text: Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient
Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheriae

questions.solution:
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue: This is a xenodiagnostic method. It involves injecting the thorax of Aedes mosquitoes (the vector for dengue virus) with blood from a patient suspected to have dengue. The mosquitoes are then observed for viral replication and transmission, which can help confirm the diagnosis.

Xenodiagnosis:

Xenodiagnosis is a diagnostic technique in which live vectors or organisms are used to detect the presence of an infectious agent in a host. This is particularly useful for detecting pathogens that are difficult to isolate or grow in a laboratory setting.

 

Rabbit ileal loop assay for ETEC (Option A) This method involves introducing a loop of rabbit ileum (part of the small intestine) into the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract and assessing the effects of enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) on the loop.

Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis (Option C) It involves injecting a hamster with a biopsy specimen from the spleen to diagnose leishmaniasis. The hamster serves as a host for the parasite, but it is not a different species used for diagnosis.

Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria (Option D) It involves conducting an intradermal test on guinea pigs to assess the toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The guinea pigs are used as a model to evaluate the effects of the toxin, but they are not a different species used for diagnosis.

questions.text: A man presents with the following lesion after traumatic inoculation. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
Sporotrichosis

Causative agent

Dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

Epidemiology

Common in gardeners, forest workers, and manual labourers.

Route of transmission

Minor trauma or thorn prick.

Clinical features
  • Chronic infection affects cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue.
  • Lesions form at sites of minor trauma or thorn pricks, starting as nodules.
  • Nodules ulcerate and necrose; infection spreads through lymphatic channels.

Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis: Secondary ulcers on lymph nodes; lymphatics become hardened and cord-like.

Systemic dissemination: Can affect bones, joints, and meninges.

Specimens

Aspiration from nodules and biopsy material.

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy:

  • KOH mounts or histopathological sections stained by methenamine silver stain show asteroid bodies (Splendore hoeppli phenomenon)
  • Yeast phase: Cigar-shaped cells.

Culture: Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia; pear-shaped conidia in rosette-like clusters in mycelial phase.

 

Serological tests: Helpful for extracutaneous or systemic infections.

Treatment

 

Medications:

  • Itraconazole
  • Terbinafine
  • Amphotericin B: For disseminated infection

Cryotherapy.

Mycobacterium Scrofulaceum (Option A) is a nontuberculous mycobacterium and is not commonly associated with traumatic skin lesions.

Madurella Mycetomatis (Option C) is a fungus that causes a chronic granulomatous infection known as mycetoma, characterized by swelling and draining sinuses, typically affecting the extremities.

Phialophora Verrucosa (Option D) is a dematiaceous fungus associated with chromoblastomycosis, a chronic subcutaneous fungal infection characterized by slowly developing granulomatous lesions.

questions.text:
Match the following in the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) life cycle:


	
		
			
			1) Accidental Host
			
			
			(a) Ardeid birds 
			
		
		
			
			2) Amplifier
			
			
			(b) Culex mosquitoes 
			
		
		
			
			3) Reservoir
			
			
			(c) Humans 
			
		
		
			
			4) Vector
			
			
			(d) Pigs
questions.solution:
Epidemiological features of Japanese encephalitis

Agent

Japanese Encephalitis Virus (JEV), Group B Arbovirus

Virus Family: Flaviviridae

Transmission Vector

Culex mosquitoes (Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui)
 

Hosts

Pigs (Amplifier Host)

Ardeid Birds: Pond herons, Ducks, Poultry (Maintenance Host)

Man: (Accidental or dead-end host)

  • Do not develop high enough viremia to infect mosquitoes.
  • Primarily children (below 15 years), but all ages susceptible
  • No man-to-man transmission.

Horses: Only animals that can manifest symptoms (Option D).

Environmental Factors

Geographic Distribution:

  • Southeast Asia, East Asia, and the Western Pacific regions.
  • India
    • Endemic: To 21 states but mainly includes Jharkhand, Bihar, West Bengal, Uttar Pradesh, Assam and Haryana
  • Seasonal Distribution:
    • Monsoon and post-monsoon period (varies by region)

Other options are incorrect.

questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis, and the CSF sample was subjected to Gram staining, which appeared in the microscopic image below. Which of the following is true of the organism?
questions.solution:
• The most common bacterium responsible for meningitis are Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, H. influenzae, Listeria, streptococcus agalactiae, and E. coli.
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae is a lanceolate-shaped, gram-positive, capsulated diplococci that is bile soluble.
  • It shows α-hemolysis on blood agar and is a catalase and oxidase-negative organism.
  • It ferments inulin and is optochin sensitive, differentiating from streptococcus viridans

Classification of Streptococcus Based on Hemolysis:

 

Hemolytic Activity
