Example Species

Characteristics

Alpha-hemolytic

S. pneumoniae (Option C)

S. viridans

Partial hemolysis, greenish color

Beta-hemolytic

S. pyogenes

S. agalactiae

Complete hemolysis, clear zone

Gamma-hemolytic

S. bovis

Enterococcus

No hemolysis


 

Lancefield Classification of Beta-hemolytic Streptococci:

  • Based on specific carbohydrate antigens on cell walls
  • Groups: A-H, K-V (excluding I and J)

Lancefield Group

Key Species

Associated Infections

Group A

Streptococcus pyogenes

Strep throat, impetigo, erysipelas, cellulitis, necrotizing fasciitis, rheumatic fever, glomerulonephritis

Group B

Streptococcus agalactiae

Neonatal meningitis, sepsis, infections in immunocompromised adults

Group C

Streptococcus equisimilis

Pharyngitis, endocarditis

Group F

Various Streptococcus species

Rare, "minute streptococci", infections in various body sites

Group G

Various Streptococcus species

Tonsillitis, endocarditis, urinary tract infections

questions.text: A 32-year-old laborer working at a construction site presented with fever and hemoptysis. The sputum sample collected for examination showed the following. The smear will be stained by which of the following sequences?

choices.text: Basic fuschin - tannic acid - methylene blue

questions.solution:
correct answer (D) Carbol fuschin - acid - methylene blue.

The clinical history and the microscopy showing bright red acid-fast bacilliis is suggestive of tuberculosis, and the stain used is Ziehl Nielsen stain.

Ziehl Neelsen stain (Acid Fast stain):

  • Principle: Acid fastness is due to the high content and variety of lipids, fatty acids, and higher alcohols in tubercle bacilli.
  • Primary Stain: Carbol Fuschin (red colour)
  • Mordant: Heat
  • Decolorizing Agent: Acid/Acid-alcohol (commonly sulphuric acid). The concentration of sulfuric acid may vary depending on the acid fastness of the structure to be demonstrated.

 

  • Counterstaining: The smear is counterstained with a contrasting dye such as methylene blue.
  • Result: Acid-fast bacteria retain the fuchsin (red) colour. Non-acid-fast bacteria take the counterstain colour (blue).

COLD ZN Stain (Kinyoun Stain/Gabbet Stain): Modified ZN stain where intermittent heating is not required with increased phenol concentration in carbol fuchsin, used for coccidian parasites.

Gentian violet – Iodine – alcohol - safranin (Option A) This staining method is a gram stain. It is used to differentiate between gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria. The sequence of gram stains is Gentian violet – Iodine – alcohol safranin.

Malachite green - heat – water - safranin (Option B) The staining technique is Schaeffer-Fulton`s method used for staining bacterial endospores.

Basic fuschin - tannic acid - methylene blue (Option C) The staining technique is Leifson and Ryu stain to demostrate flagella.

questions.text: Which of the following components of the fungal cell wall is not seen in mucormycosis?
questions.solution:
• Mucormycosis is caused by fungi belonging to the order Mucorales, such as Rhizopus, Mucor, and Rhizomucor.
  • These fungi have a unique cell wall composition that lacks beta-glucans.
  • Instead, the cell walls of Mucorales fungi are primarily composed of chitin, glucosamine polymers, and other components.

 

β-1,3-D-glucan test used for:

 

β-1,3-D-glucan
  • Polysaccharide cell wall component
  • Routinely used for : Candida, Aspergillus
  • Positive in: PJP, Histoplasma, Fusarium, Scedosporium, dermatophytes, Cocci
  • Negative in: Blastomyces, Mucor, Cryptococcus

Mannoproteins (Option A) It is a type of glycoprotein that helps to protect the cell wall from damage and is found in the fungi cell wall.

Chitin (Option C) is a long, unbranched polysaccharide that provides strength and rigidity to the cell wall and is an important and characteristic feature of all fungal cell walls.

Ergosterol (Option D) is a type of sterol that is found in the cell walls of all fungi.

questions.text: Identify the organism from the life cycle shown in the image given below
questions.solution:
Toxoplasma gondii

Host
  • Definitive host: Cat and other cat species (family Felidae)
  • Intermediate host: Humans and animals like sheep, rodents, pigs etc

Infective stages
  • Sporulated oocyst
  • Tachyzoites
  • Bradyzoites (tissue cyst)

Modes of transmission

Infective form

Blood Transfusion

  

Tachyzoites

Mother to child

Undercooked or raw meat

Sporulated Oocyst

Ingestion of contaminated products

Bradyzoites

 

Cystoisospora (Option A) It has only one host, that is, humans. Here, both the sexual and asexual cycle takes place inside the lumen of the human.

Cryptosporidium (Option B) It has only one host, which is humans. Here both the sexual and asexual cycle takes place inside the lumen of the human.

Plasmodium knowlesi (Option C) The asexual cycle takes place in humans. The sexual cycle takes place inside the mosquito.

questions.text: Which pathogen causes attachment & effacement lesions in the intestinal mucosa, as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
• Enteropathogenic E coli are non-invasive and do not produce enterotoxins.
  • EPEC has two factors:
  • EPEC adherence factor (EAF)
  • The chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island that promotes the tight adherence characteristic of EPEC (attachment and effacement).
  • After attachment, there is a loss of microvilli (effacement) and formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures, causing entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells. This attachment-effacement lesion disrupts the normal absorptive function of the intestinal epithelium and can lead to diarrhea.

 

Types of E. coli

Type of E. coli

Clinical Features

Toxins Produced

Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) (Option A)

Watery diarrhea, Abdominal cramps, Low-grade fever, Nausea and vomiting

Most common cause of traveller's diarrhea

Causes watery diarrhea through

attachment via CFA (colonization factor antigen) and toxin production (heat-labile toxin ↑cAMP, heat-stable toxin ↑cGMP).

Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) (Option B)

Watery diarrhea (especially in infants), Fever, Vomiting, Dehydration

None (mechanism involves attaching and effacing lesions)

Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC)

Bloody diarrhea, Severe abdominal cramps, Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)

Shiga-like toxins/Verocytotoxin

Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC) (Option C)

Watery diarrhea followed by dysentery-like symptoms, Fever, Severe abdominal pain

None (mechanism involves cell invasion and intracellular multiplication)

Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC)

Persistent watery diarrhea (duration > 14 days), Abdominal pain, Nausea, Low-grade fever

Plasmid-encoded toxin (PET)

I"stacked-brick" pattern of bacterial aggregation when adhering to HEp-2 cells.

Diffuse-adhering E. coli (DAEC) (Option D)

Watery diarrhea (usually mild), Abdominal cramps, Low-grade fever

None (mechanism involves diffuse adherence to epithelial cells)

Clinical Features of E. coli Infections

  1. Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)
    • E. coli accounts for a significant majority of UTIs.
    • Approximately 5-7% of pregnant women may have asymptomatic bacteriuria, which can lead to symptomatic infections later.
    • P pili-positive E. coli strains are generally uropathogenic.
  2. Diarrhea
    • Various types of E. coli can lead to different forms of diarrhea, ranging from watery to bloody.
  3. Pyogenic Infections
    • E. coli can cause peritonitis and abscesses.
    • It is also an important cause of neonatal meningitis.
  4. Septicemia
    • Bloodstream invasion can lead to septic shock and systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS).

questions.text: Choose the best description for the structure marked in the CT given below.
questions.solution:
Pneumatization of the superior turbinate refers to the presence of an air cell within the superior turbinate.

Pneumatization of the superior turbinate, also known as superior concha bullosa, is a relatively rare anatomical variation where air cells develop within the superior turbinate.

Symptoms

In most cases, pneumatization of the superior turbinate is asymptomatic and discovered incidentally during imaging studies for other reasons.

  • Nasal obstruction or congestion
  • Headache
  • Sinusitis
  • Smell disorders

Diagnosis

Best diagnosed with a computed tomography (CT) scan of the paranasal sinuses.

 

Agger nasi cell (Option A): The agger nasi is an ethmoidal air cell situated in front of the uncinate process. The degree of pneumatization of this cell determines the thickness of the nasofrontal beak and the position of the superior uncinate process.

 

Onodi cell (Option C): An Onodi cell, also known as a sphenoethmoidal or lateral sphenoid sinus cell, is an anatomical variation where the sphenoid sinus extends laterally to involve the posterior ethmoid sinus.


Haller cell (Option D): A Haller cell is an anterior ethmoid air cell that extends into the floor of the orbit, near the ethmoidal bulla and frontal recess.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image.
questions.solution:
• Adenoid facies, also known as adenoid face or long-face syndrome, refers to a characteristic facial appearance associated with chronic enlargement of the adenoids. Adenoid facies is characterized by specific facial features, which may include:
    • Long and narrow face
    • Open-mouth posture
    • High-arched palate
    • Dental crowding


 

Adenoid Hypertrophy: (Enlargement of the adenoids)

Aetiology
  • Physiological Enlargement: Common in childhood.
  • Chronic Conditions: Recurrent rhinitis, sinusitis, chronic tonsillitis, & allergies.

Clinical Features
  • Nasal Symptoms:
  • Nasal obstruction leading to mouth breathing and feeding difficulties.
  • Nasal discharge due to choanal obstruction and chronic rhinitis.
  • Sinusitis, Epistaxis & voice changes due to nasal obstruction. (Rhinolalia clausa)
  • Aural Symptoms:
  • Tubal obstruction causing retracted tympanic membrane and CHL.
  • Recurrent acute otitis media and chronic suppurative otitis media.
  • Otitis media with effusion due to intermittent eustachian tube obstruction.
  • Adenoid Facies: Characteristic facial appearance with an elongated face, open mouth, crowded upper teeth, and high-arched palate.
 
  • Pulmonary Hypertension: Potential due to long-standing nasal obstruction.
  • Aprosexia: Difficulty concentrating

Clinical Examination
  • External Nose: Check for skin changes indicating frequent nose rubbing.
  • Nasal Assessment: Halogen light otoscope is used for simple anterior rhinoscopy, which examines the nasal cavity but not the adenoids.
  • Adenoid Assessment:
    • Nasendoscopy: For detailed evaluation, a flexible pediatric endoscope with topical anaesthesia is preferred. It provides an accurate assessment of adenoid size in an outpatient setting.
    • Lateral Soft-Tissue Radiograph: This is useful when endoscopy is not tolerated; it correlates well with endoscopic findings.

 

Goldenhar syndrome (Option B): Goldenhar syndrome, also known as oculo-auriculo-vertebral spectrum (OAVS) or hemifacial microsomia, is a rare congenital condition that affects the development of structures on one side of the face. The most prominent feature of Goldenhar syndrome is craniofacial asymmetry. This can involve facial asymmetry, microtia (underdeveloped or absent external ear), and facial clefts such as cleft lip and palate.

 

Horse facies (Option C): Also known as Greek warrior helmet appearance, is seen in Treacher Collins syndrome. It is characterized by a short philtrum, a downturned mouth, Small chin (micrognathia), and Poorly formed ears with small holes (pits) or flaps of skin (tags).


Frog facies (Option D): The term is often used to describe the facial features observed in individuals with juvenile nasal angiofibroma. Broadening of the nasal bridge, swelling of cheek, frog face deformity (in cases of bilateral proptosis).

questions.text: Which of the following is not employed in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation?
questions.solution:
The super supraglottic swallow is not employed in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation because the anatomical structures it targets (vocal folds) are no longer present.

 

Vocal rehabilitation-methods:

After laryngectomy, the patient loses his speech completely. The various methods by which communication can be established are given below:

 

Oesophageal Speech (Option B ruled out)

  • In this, the patient is taught to swallow air and hold it in the upper esophagus and then slowly eject it from the esophagus into the pharynx.
  • The patient can speak 6-10 words before re-swallowing air.
  • The voice is rough but loud and understandable.

 

Artificial Larynx It is used in those who fail to learn oesophageal speech.

1. Electrolarynx:

  • Its vibrating disc is held against the soft tissues of the neck and a low-pitched sound is produced in the hypopharynx which is further modulated into speech by the tongue, lips, teeth, and palate.

2. Transoral pneumatic device

  • It is a transoral device.
  • Here vibrations produced in a rubber diaphragm are carried by a plastic tube into the back of the oral cavity where sound is converted into speech by modulators.
  • This is a pneumatic type of device and uses expired air from the tracheostome to vibrate the diaphragm.

 

Tracheo-Oesophageal Speech (Option A ruled out)

  • Here an attempt is made to carry air from the trachea to the esophagus or hypopharynx by the creation of a skin-lined fistula or by placement of an artificial prosthesis.
  • The vibrating column of air entering the pharynx is then modulated into speech.
  • This technique has the disadvantage of food entering the trachea.
  • These days prostheses (Blom-Singer or Panje) are being used to shunt air from the trachea to the esophagus
  • They have inbuilt valves which work only in one direction thus preventing problems of aspiration.

 

Olfactory Rehabilitation: (Option D ruled out)

After laryngectomy, smell is lost because air no longer passes through the nose. This also means patients can't detect dangerous environmental odours like smoke or gas. To address this, a technique called "polite yawning" can be taught. This involves:

  • Lowering the jaw, floor of mouth, and tongue while keeping lips closed.
  • This creates negative pressure in the mouth and throat, drawing air through the nose.
  • Repeating this maneuver several times can help restore some sense of smell and allow detection of environmental hazards.

questions.text: What would be your diagnosis for a patient who has presented with symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and fullness of ears. The symptoms improve on keeping the right ear up. He had previously been operated on for a safe type of right side chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) six months ago?
questions.solution:
• A perilymphatic fistula (PLF) refers to an abnormal communication between the middle ear and the fluid-filled spaces of the inner ear, known as the cochlea and vestibular system.
  • It can occur as a result of trauma, such as barotrauma or previous ear surgery.
  • The main symptoms associated with a PLF include vertigo (dizziness), tinnitus (ringing in the ears), and sensorineural hearing loss.

Features of Perilymph Fistula:

Feature

Description

Etiology

Can occur after head trauma, barotrauma (e.g., diving), temporal bone anomalies, or ear surgery (e.g., stapedectomy).

Symptoms

Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, vertigo, tinnitus, and sometimes a sense of fullness in the ear.

Complications

Recurrent meningitis (especially in children with temporal bone defects), cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak.

Diagnosis

Often clinical, based on history and symptoms; confirmed through surgical exploration if suspected.

Temporal bone CT: Shows pneumolabyrinth, accumulation of fluid in the middle ear, and/or ossicular chain disruption, but also can often be normal.

Treatment

Surgical closure of the fistula to prevent further complications, such as meningitis; limited improvement in hearing.

Prognosis

Hearing improvement post-surgery is usually limited; however, vertigo symptoms often improve or resolve.

Labyrinthitis (Option B): Labyrinthitis is an inflammation of the labyrinth. It is often caused by a viral or bacterial. infection. The main symptoms of labyrinthitis include vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss, and ear fullness. However, in this case, the patient's history of surgery and the absence of infection-related symptoms make labyrinthitis less likely.

Paget disease (Option C): Paget's disease, also known as osteitis deformans, is a chronic bone disorder characterized by abnormal bone remodeling. It typically affects older individuals and can involve various bones, including the skull. While Paget's disease can cause hearing loss and other symptoms, the presence of vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt, in this case, make it an unlikely diagnosis.

Vestibular schwannoma (Option D): Vestibular schwannoma, also known as acoustic neuroma, is a benign tumor that arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular nerve in the inner ear. It typically presents with symptoms such as unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and imbalance. However, the absence of significant hearing loss and the recent surgery suggest that vestibular schwannoma is less likely in this case.

questions.text: Involvement of Jugular foramen leads to which of the following:

choices.text: Loss of taste from the anterior ⅔ of the tongue
Loss of sensation from the posterior ⅓ of the tongue
Loss of sensation from the anterior ⅔ of the tongue
Loss of tasteand sensation from the anterior ⅔ of the tongue

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Loss of sensation from the posterior ⅓ of the tongue

Explanation:

Damage to the jugular foramen can compress or injure the glossopharyngeal nerve, leading to loss of both taste and sensation from the posterior one-third of the tongue.

  • The tongue is divided into two regions:
    • Anterior two-thirds, innervated by the chorda tympani nerve (Option C)
    • Posterior one-third, supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve, separated by the Sulcus terminalis.
  • Dysfunction in either of these nerves can cause impaired taste perception and loss of taste, as each nerve is responsible for sensation in its respective area.

Development of tongue and nerve innervation

Aspects

Anterior ⅔ of tongue

Posterior ⅓ of tongue

Posterior most of the tongue

Epithelial Development

Two lingual swellings and a tuberculum impar, made from the mesoderm of 1st arch, fuse to form the anterior ⅔ of tongue.

The hypobranchial arch is formed by the mesoderm of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal arches and is further divided into cranial and caudal parts. The cranial part of this arch gives rise to the posterior ⅓.

The Caudal parts derived from the hypobranchial arch develop to the posterior part of the tongue

Taste Sensation

Chorda Tympani

Glossopharyngeal nerve (supplies circumvallate papillae)

(Option B)

Internal laryngeal nerve (Branch of Vagus)

Sensory supply

Lingual nerve

Motor Supply

Except for the palatoglossus muscle, which is innervated by the vagus nerve, all other intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve.

Muscles

All the Tongue muscles develop from Occipital Somites.

questions.text: What is the nerve blocked in the following local anaesthesia technique?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Nasociliary nerve

Explanation: 

  • For the local anesthesia technique depicted in the image, the correct nerve being targeted is the nasociliary nerve. 
  • The nasociliary nerve is a branch of the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V).
  • It provides sensory innervation to the skin of the nose, including the nasal septum and the anterior part of the nasal cavity.
  • It further branches into the anterior ethmoidal nerve, which supplies the anterior part of the nasal cavity and the nasal septum.
  • In procedures such as rhinoseptoplasty, the nasociliary nerve block is effective in anesthetizing the nasal septum and the anterior nasal cavity.

 

Face blocks

 

Most of the facial region is supplied by the Trigeminal nerve and its branches.

Anatomy:

  • Cranial nerve V arises from the brainstem and forms the Gasserian (sensory) ganglion in Meckel’s cave.
  • The three nerve divisions (ophthalmic, maxillary, mandibular) exit the skull separately.

 

Nerve Block

Anatomy

Anesthesia Distribution

Technique

Supraorbital & Supratrochlear (Ophthalmic Nerve)

Supraorbital nerve exits the supraorbital foramen on the superior surface of the orbital rim.

Supratrochlear exits medially at the orbital rim.

Anesthetizes the entire forehead up to the scalp's vertex.

Inject anesthetic subcutaneously above the eyebrow, from midline to the lateral orbit.

Infraorbital (Maxillary Nerve) 

 

Exits infraorbital foramen below the optic rim near the first maxillary premolar.

Provides sensation loss to lower eyelid, medial cheek, side of nose, upper lip.

Retract mucosa, insert needle above the first premolar, and inject 3-5 ml between cheek and gingiva.

Mental (Mandibular Nerve)

 

Mental nerve exits the mental foramen, a branch of the inferior alveolar nerve.

Anesthetizes lower lip, labial mucosa, and gingiva near incisors and canines.

Retract lip, insert needle near first/second premolars, and inject 3-5 ml in the mucosal fold

Inferior Alveolar (Mandibular Nerve) 

Arises from mandibular division of trigeminal (V3); landmarks: Mandibular sulcus, coronoid notch, pterygomandibular raphe.

Anesthetizes all lower teeth, gums, anterior labial and lingual areas.

Insert needle into pterygomandibular raphe, tap bone, withdraw slightly, and inject 2-3 ml.

 

Complications

  • Risks include intravascular or subarachnoid injection, Horner syndrome, and motor block of jaw muscles.
  • Maxillary nerve blocks carry a higher risk of hemorrhage.
  • Facial nerve may be unintentionally blocked during mandibular nerve blocks.

questions.text: You are in the operating room and notice the tracing in yellow colour on this device. What does it indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Capnography
 

Explanation:

The yellow tracing on the device indicates capnography, which monitors CO₂ levels in exhaled air.


 

Capnography and Capnometry difference:

 

 

 

Capnography:

  • Measures CO₂ in the airway
  • Provides breath-to-breath status of ventilation.
  • Detects CO₂ only.

 

 

 

Phase I

Dead Space Ventilation

• Beginning of exhalation

• No CO₂ present

• Air from trachea and pharynx

◦ No gas exchange occurs here

◦ Called dead space ventilation

 

(Option C)

Phase II

Ascending Phase

• CO₂ from alveoli reaches upper airway ,mixes with dead space air

• Causes  rapid rise in CO₂ concentration.

(Option B )

Phase III

Alveolar Plateau 

• Majority of exhaled air is CO₂-rich

• Uniform CO₂ concentration

 

End-Tidal

• Highest CO₂ concentration is the   end-tidal value.

• This is the value you see on the monitor

• Normal EtCO2 is 35 35-45mmHg

• Best reflection of Alveolar CO2

(Option A )

Phase IV

Descending Phase

• Inhalation begins

• CO₂ level drops to zero as oxygen fills the airway.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used for induction of anesthesia, maintenance and can be safely used in endotracheal intubation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sevoflurane

Explanation:

  • Sevoflurane is widely used for both induction and maintenance of anesthesia. It is less pungent than other agents, making it suitable for inhalational induction, and it provides smooth intubation conditions.
  • Its rapid onset and offset properties also make it ideal for both induction and maintenance phases.

 

Sevoflurane

Properties

Sevoflurane is a fluorinated ether with low blood solubility (λb/g 0.65), allowing for rapid induction and emergence.

Its non-pungency makes it suitable for inhalation induction, especially in pediatric patients. It is used with conventional vaporizers.

Uses

Ideal for smooth and rapid inhalation induction, particularly in daycare procedures (4-8% concentration with nitrous oxide and oxygen).

It is commonly used for both pediatric and adult anesthesia.

C/I

Should be avoided in cases of severe hypovolemia, susceptibility to malignant hyperthermia, and intracranial hypertension.

Systemic Effects

Cardiovascular

Mild myocardial depression with slight reduction in systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure. It causes minimal heart rate increase and may prolong the QT interval.

Hepatic

Decreases portal vein flow but increases hepatic artery flow, maintaining overall hepatic perfusion.

Renal

Slightly decreases renal blood flow but has no known association with significant renal toxicity.

Compound A, a degradation product of sevoflurane, is nephrotoxic in animals but has no known adverse effects on humans.

Neuromuscular

Provides adequate muscle relaxation for intubation but is often combined with other agents or muscle relaxants.

Cerebral

Slight increases in cerebral blood flow (CBF) and intracranial pressure. High concentrations may impair CBF autoregulation. Seizures have not been reported.

Respiratory

Depresses respiration and helps reverse bronchospasm. Thus agent of choice in asthmatics.


 

Halothane (Option A):

  • It is primarily used for the maintenance of anesthesia and is not recommended for induction due to its potential for hepatotoxicity and its undesirable side effects.
  • Halothane is also associated with a higher risk of cardiac arrhythmias than other inhalation anesthetics.

 

Desflurane(Option B):

  • is a volatile inhalation anesthetic that is primarily used for the maintenance of anesthesia.
  • It has low blood-gas solubility and a rapid onset and offset, making it suitable for long surgical procedures.
  • However, desflurane has a pungent odor that can cause airway irritation and coughing, making it less suitable for induction and endotracheal intubation.

 

Isoflurane (Option D):

  • is a volatile inhalation anesthetic that is commonly used for the maintenance of anesthesia.
  • It has a good safety profile and provides a smooth anesthetic depth.
  • However, it is not the ideal choice for induction due to its slower onset than sevoflurane

questions.text: During resuscitation, a patient received a 20% intralipid injection. What could have been the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Local anaesthesia toxicity

Explanation:

  • The administration of a 20% intralipid injection is a recognized treatment for local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST).
  • LAST can occur when local anesthetics, such as bupivacaine, are inadvertently injected into the bloodstream during regional anesthesia procedures.
  • This can lead to severe cardiovascular and central nervous system complications.


 

Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST):

 

Clinical Features

CNS effects:

  • Early and less severe.
  • First symptom: circumoral paraesthesia
  • First sign: nystagmus
  • At low plasma concentration: mild sensory disturbances.
  • Increased concentration: CNS excitation, seizure activity.
  • Higher concentration: CNS depression, coma, respiratory depression, arrest.

Cardiac effects:

  • Usually late but severe form of toxicity, may lead to death.
  • Hypotension, dysrhythmias, myocardial depression.
  • Potent agents (bupivacaine, ropivacaine, levobupivacaine) linked to cardiovascular collapse, heart block.

Safety profile

Bupivacaine has more risk to cause LAST than Lidocaine

Most potent highly lipid soluble drugs are more likely to cause

Prevention
  • Risk recognition and dose reduction.
  • Careful aspiration before injection.
  • Incremental administration (3-5 mL) with continuous heart rate monitoring.
  • Use ultrasonographic guidance to confirm anesthetic deposit.
  • Use a vasoactive agent like epinephrine to reduce systemic absorption and serve as an intravascular indicator.

Treatment
  • Recognize LAST (Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity) early and call for help.
  • Airway management: Secure airway, ventilate with 100% oxygen.
  • Administer 20% Lipid Emulsion:
    • Bolus: 12 mL/kg over 2-3 min.
    • Infusion: at 0.25 mL/kg/min-0.5ml/kg/min for 15-20 mins
    • Maximum initial dose: 12 ml/kg
  • Administration of antiepileptics: for seizure control, benzodiazepines such as Lorazepam is preferred.
  • Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: if necessary, monitor the patient at least for initial 2-6 hours following resuscitation.

Asphyxia due to drowning (Option B): Drowning leads to hypoxia and respiratory failure, which are managed through airway management and respiratory support, not lipid emulsion therapy.

 

Electrocution(Option C): can cause cardiac arrhythmias and burns. Treatment focuses on resuscitation, wound care, and monitoring for arrhythmias, not lipid emulsion therapy.


Pulseless electrical activity (Option D): This condition involves a non-perfusing rhythm and requires immediate resuscitation efforts, including CPR and addressing the underlying cause.

questions.text: Which of the following post-bronchodilator pulmonary function test (PFT) results would necessitate a further assessment of lung function in a 50-year-old male patient with grade 3 American Society of Anesthesiology (ASA) status?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) FEV1<0.85 and FEV1/FVC<0.7
 

Explanation:

  • FEV1 below 0.85 liters and FEV1/FVC ratio less than 0.7 indicate significant airflow limitation, suggesting conditions like COPD.
  • In patients with grade 3 ASA, further evaluation, including lung volume measurements or gas diffusion capacity assessment, is needed to determine the severity and type of lung disease.


 

FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC < 0.8(Option A): An FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.8 is normal, usually not needing more assessment. However, an FEV1 under 0.85 liters suggests airflow limitation, possibly requiring further evaluation.


 

FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC < 0.75 (Option B): An FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.75 suggests airflow limitation, while an FEV1 below 0.85 liters indicates reduced air volume expelled in the first second. Despite the exact FEV1/FVC ratio, a low FEV1 necessitates further evaluation.


FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC < 0.75 (Option D): An FEV1 below 0.8 liters suggests significant airflow limitation, warranting further evaluation. However, with an FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.75 within the normal range, immediate additional assessment may not be necessary

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of local anesthetics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Block sodium channels

Explanation:

Local anesthetics function by inhibiting the conduction of nerve impulses, thereby preventing the sensation of pain. They achieve this primarily by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels on nerve cell membranes.

 

Mechanism of action & absorption:

  • Site: acts on nodes of ranvier
  • Blocks transmission of pain impulse from nociceptor to spinal cord.
  • Acts on intracellular side of Na channels at inactivation gate blocking the channel.
  • LA doesn’t affect RMP of nerves.
  • Blocks inactivation gates of Na+ channels → Disrupts depolarisation → No action potential generated → No pain sensation.
  • Highest systemic absorption (routes of administration): IV route >Tracheal > Intercostal > Brachial plexus > Epidural.
  • Form for onset of LA action (to reach target nerve) - Unionized form.
  • Active form at site of block of Na channels- Ionized form.
  • Higher doses will act for longer duration and lower doses for a relatively shorter duration.

 

Duration of onset for different local anesthetics (infiltration anesthesia):

Short Duration
  • Procaine
  • Chloroprocaine

Moderate Duration
  • Lidocaine
  • Prilocaine

Long Duration
  • Bupivacaine
  • Ropivacaine

 

  • Shortest acting- Procaine
  • Longest acting- Dibucaine
  • Fastest onset- Chloroprocaine (low potency so high concentration used) > Lignocaine (pka is near physiological pH)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about open fractures?

 

1. Tibia and phalanges are most commonly involved

2. Usually no co-existing injuries

3. Compartment syndrome does not occur in open fractures

4. Early debridement should be done
questions.solution:
Open Fracture:

Open fractures (compound fractures) occur when a bone breaks and pierces through the skin, creating an open wound. These fractures are more likely to cause infection and complications from exposure of bone and soft tissues to the external environment.

Features Open Fractures:

  • Commonly Affected Bones: Tibia and phalanges
  • Higher Risk of Infection.
  • Co-existing Injuries such as soft tissue damage, nerve or vascular injury, and other fractures.

Management of Open Fractures:

  1. Initial Assessment and Stabilization:
    • Assessment of the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation)
    • Pain management
    • Tetanus prophylaxis
    • Antibiotics: Broad-spectrum antibiotics are administered early to prevent infection (usually within the first hour of injury).
  2. Wound Care and Debridement:
    • Early debridement.
    • Sterile dressing.
    • Tissue coverage.
  3. Fracture Stabilization:
    • External fixation.
    • Internal fixation.

4. Complications:

  • Infection
  • Compartment syndrome


2 and 3 (Option D) As open fractures have external wounds, they can result in soft tissue swelling and subsequent compression of the surrounding nerves and vessels, resulting in compartment syndrome.

questions.text:
Match the following fractures with their respective sites.


	
		
			
			A. Jones fracture

			B. Bennett's fracture

			C. March fracture

			D. Boxer fracture
			
			
			1. 5th metatarsal

			2. 2nd metatarsal

			3. 1st metacarpal

			4. 5th metacarpal
questions.solution:
• Jones fracture is the fracture of the base of 5th metatarsal.
  • Pseudo Jones is the fracture of the tip of the base of the 5th metatarsal.
  • Bennett’s fracture is the intra-articular fracture of the base of 1st metacarpal with subluxation of the trapezio-metacarpal joint.
  • March fracture is a fatigue fracture of the neck of the 2nd metatarsal.
  • Boxer’s fracture, also called Fighters’ fracture is a fracture of the neck of 5th metacarpal

 

Fracture Type

Features

Treatment

Jones fractures
  • Significant adduction force to the foot with a lifted heel (e.g., sudden direction change)
  • Location of injury: 4th/5th metatarsal articulation

March Fracture
  • A stress fracture commonly seen in runners, involving the metatarsals due to repetitive overuse.
  • The patient's gradual onset of pain and tenderness after increased running
  • X-ray shows no obvious fracture, but a faint periosteal reaction is seen.

Bennett fracture
  • Oblique intra-articular fracture (2 part) of the base of the first metacarpal with subluxation of the metacarpal.
  • It is caused by a longitudinal force applied to the thumb.
  • Treatment:
    • Closed reduction and percutaneous K-wire fixation
    • Open reduction and internal fixation

Boxer's fracture
  • Fracture through the neck of the metacarpal (commonly the 5th metacarpal).
  • Cause: Closed fist hits against a hard object
  • Treatment: Mostly conservative

questions.text: A 12-year-old presented with fever and difficulty swallowing. He had swelling in the marked region and was advised to undergo surgery. Post-surgery the gauze continued to soak with blood. Which of the following vessels must have been injured?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Paratonsillar vein

 

Explanation:

The paratonsillar vein is a major venous drainage pathway of the palatine tonsils and is vulnerable to injury during tonsillectomy. Profuse post-tonsillectomy hemorrhage, especially after surgery, commonly results from the rupture of this vein, leading to continuous bleeding.

Vascular Supply of the Tonsils

Vessel

Type

Clinical Relevance

Tonsillar branch of the facial artery

Arterial

Major arterial supply to the tonsils

Ascending pharyngeal artery

Arterial

Secondary supply to the pharynx & tonsils

Paratonsillar vein

Venous

Major drainage vein, commonly injured in tonsillectomy

Retromandibular vein

Venous

Drains the face, not directly involved in tonsillar bleeding

 

Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (Option A): Incorrect because while it supplies the tonsil, arterial bleeding is less common post-tonsillectomy compared to venous bleeding.

Ascending pharyngeal artery (Option B): Incorrect because it primarily supplies the pharynx but is not the major source of post-tonsillectomy hemorrhage.

Retromandibular vein (Option D): Incorrect because it drains the face and has no direct relation to the tonsils.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the correct sequence for the Thomas test:

 

1. Squaring of pelvis

2. Flexion of the hip

3. Look for exaggerated lumbar lordosis

4. Measure actual flexion deformity

5.Make sure that the ischial tuberosity makes contact with the ground.

6. Overcorrection of the normal side
questions.solution:
Steps in Thomas Test:

  1. Position the Patient, look for lumbar lordosis
  2. Flex the Contralateral Hip:
  3. Assess the Involved Hip: While the opposite leg is held in flexion, observe the position of the involved leg (the leg lying flat on the table).
  4. Evaluate Knee Flexion

 

Interpretation:

  • If an opposite leg is flat: Good hip flexibility
  • If the opposite leg lifts off the table, but the hip is flexed: Hip flexor contracture If the opposite leg lifts off and the hip is extended: The hip flexor and extensor contracture
  • Hence the correct sequence of the Thomas test is:
  • Look for exaggerated lumbar lordosis → Flexion of hip → Overcorrection of normal side → Ensure ischial tuberosity touches the ground → Measure actual flexion deformity.


Squaring of the pelvis (Statement 1) is not done in Thomas’ test.

questions.text: What treatment would you provide to a 60-year-old female patient who had a Colles' fracture 8 months ago, has a T score of -2.5, attained menopause at 52 years, and is currently not experiencing any symptoms, when she visits the orthopedics outpatient department?
questions.solution:
The woman is likely to be suffering from osteoporosis. T score of -2.5 indicates osteoporosis.

In postmenopausal women, bisphosphonates like Alendronate are the first management line.

 

Osteoporosis:

  • Disorder with low bone mass and structural defects, increasing fracture risk.
  • Cancellous regions: More porous; cortices: Thinner.
  • Loss of bone strength is mainly due to decreased bone mass and structural connectivity in trabecular bone.
  • Plain radiographs: Not sufficient for diagnosis, though signs like trabecular loss and vertebral compression fractures can suggest osteopenia.

DEXA (Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry):

  • T-score: Standard deviations below the young adult mean.
  • Z-score: Standard deviations below the age-matched mean.
  • WHO T-score interpretation:
    • Osteoporosis: Below -2.5
    • Osteopenia: Between -1.0 and -2.5
    • Normal bone mass: Above -1.0

Drugs used in Osteoporosis:

 

Pharmacological Agent

Mechanism of Action

Bisphosphonates (Alendronate, Risedronate, Ibandronate)

Interfere with osteoclast activity, leading to decreased bone resorption.

Calcitonin

Inhibits osteoclast activity, reducing bone resorption.

Denosumab

It inhibits the RANK ligand, essential for osteoclast formation and function.

Estrogen/Raloxifene

Inhibit osteoclast activity and slow bone loss.

Cinacalcet

Indirectly reduces bone resorption by lowering PTH levels.

Teriparatide

A recombinant form of PTH stimulates osteoblast activity.

Strontium Ranelate

Dual action: It promotes bone formation by stimulating osteoblasts and decreases bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclast activity.

Hormone Replacement Therapy (Option A) Estrogen has been proven to halt the loss of bone mass in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis; however, due to side effects, it is not the first line of management of osteoporosis.

Calcium and Vitamin D (Option C) alone is not found to be beneficial for the treatment of osteoporosis. They can be used along with osteoporosis treatments.

Repeat DEXA scan after 3 Months (Option D) Since there is a clear-cut diagnosis of osteoporosis in this case scenario, along with a history of college fracture 8 months back, alendronate can be started immediately instead of waiting for a repeat DEXA scan after 3 months.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a cast, due to tibia fracture, presented to the emergency department with complaints of intense pain. The cast was removed and on physical examination, passive extension of leg was painful. The dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses were present and there was a loss of sensation over the first web space. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
• The Clinical scenario of pain on passive extension after a trauma is likely to be compartment syndrome.
  • The next step is to measure the pressure in the anterior compartment if there is suspicion of compartment syndrome.
  • Normal pressure at the leg is < 11 mm of Hg.
  • Calf pressure during walking is 200-300 mm Hg.
  • Pressure in compartment syndrome >40 mmHg.

Acute compartment syndrome is caused by ischemia of a closed compartment of the body (most commonly forearm) which leads to increased intra-compartmental pressure.

  • It may be due to a decrease in compartment size or an increase in the volume of the compartment.
  • Prolonged ischemia will lead to myonecrosis stimulating fibrosis resulting in a fibrotic pull of the wrists and fingers.

 

Causes include:

  1. Tight bandages and dressings
  2. Animal bites
  3. Burns
  4. Intensive and excessive exercises
  5. Muscle hypertrophy
  6. Neoplasms
  7. Bleeding into a closed compartment (injury to a vessel, congenital or acquired disorder)
  8. Injections in the forearm
  9. Surgery on the forearm

 

Clinical Features:

Initial Symptoms of Compartment Syndrome (Order of appearance)

  • Pain: The earliest symptom, worsened by passive extension of fingers - Stretch pain
  • Pallor: Skin may appear pale due to reduced blood supply.
  • Pulselessness: Diminished or absent radial pulse.
  • Paresthesia: Numbness or tingling due to nerve compression.
  • Paralysis: Weakness or inability to move fingers, indicating nerve ischemia.

 

Management of ACS:

1. Monitor closely for symptoms of compartment syndrome (Severe pain, swelling, numbness, tingling, muscle weakness).

 

2. Measure Compartment Pressure

  • If pressure is below 20 mm Hg: Conservative management.
  • If pressure is between 20-30 mmHg: Monitor closely for worsening.
  • If pressure is above 30 mm Hg or Delta P is less than 30 mm Hg: Proceed to fasciotomy.

 

3. Conservative Management (If pressure < 20 mm Hg or borderline)

  • Elevate limb to heart level - helps reduce edema and venous congestion without compromising arterial inflow.
  • Remove tight dressings or splints.
  • Monitor pain, swelling, and sensation.
  • Repeat compartment pressure measurements regularly.
  • Optimize blood pressure and hydration.

 

4. Monitor for Progression

  • If symptoms worsen or pressure rises above 30 mm Hg: Proceed to fasciotomy.
  • If symptoms improve: Continue conservative measures and monitoring.

 

5. Fasciotomy (If pressure > 30 mm Hg or worsening clinical signs): Volar Fasciotomy

 

6. Post-Fasciotomy Care - Wound care, physical therapy, and monitoring for complications (e.g., scarring or contractures).

 

Duplex imaging (Option A) may be used in suspected vascular injury or deep vein thrombosis cases.

Re-apply cast (Option B) further complicates the condition. Hence, the cause should be treated initially.

Analgesics (Option D) is used only temporarily for pain relief and cannot be considered the next step to manage this case.

questions.text:
Match the following with their most appropriate mode of management:

 


	
		
			
			1. Osteosarcoma

			2. Simple bone cyst

			3. Giant cell tumor

			4. Osteoid osteoma
			
			
			A. Wide excision

			B. Curettage

			C. Radiofrequency ablation

			D. Intralesional steroid
questions.solution:
Condition

Features and Findings

Treatment

Osteosarcoma
  • A malignant bone tumor, commonly affecting the metaphyses of long bones (e.g., femur, tibia).
  • It most frequently occurs in adolescents and young adults. Symptoms include pain, swelling, and sometimes a palpable mass.
  • X-rays typically show a sunburst appearance with mixed lytic and sclerotic areas.
  • Surgical resection (amputation or limb-sparing surgery), followed by chemotherapy.
  • Radiation therapy is rarely used.

Simple Bone Cyst

  • A benign, fluid-filled cyst, often occurring in the proximal humerus or femur.
  • It is typically asymptomatic
  • On X-ray, it appears as a well-defined, cystic lesion with a thin cortical rim.
  • Often occurs in children and adolescents.
  • Aspiration and steroid injection, or curettage with bone grafting if recurrent fractures occur.
  • Surgical intervention is usually necessary if there is risk of fracture.

Giant Cell Tumor

  • A benign, locally aggressive tumor that typically occurs in the epiphysis of long bones (e.g., distal femur, proximal tibia).
  • It is most common in young adults.
  • Symptoms include pain, swelling, and sometimes joint dysfunction.
  • X-rays show a lytic lesion with a "soap bubble" appearance.
  • Curettage with bone grafting or chemical adjuvants (e.g., phenol). Wide resection for larger or more aggressive tumors..

Osteoid Osteoma
  • A benign bone tumor that most commonly affects the femur or tibia. It typically occurs in adolescents or young adults.
  • Characterized by a small, well-circumscribed lesion with a central nidus on X-ray.
  • Symptoms include localized pain, especially at night, that is relieved by NSAIDs.
  • Surgical excision of the nidus is the standard treatment. Radiofrequency ablation can be used
  • Pain is often well-controlled with NSAIDs until definitive treatment.

questions.text: What condition is caused by nerve injury?
questions.solution:
• The following image shows an ulnar claw due to Ulnar nerve injury or compression.
  • There is hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints of the 4th and 5th digits due to the paralysis of the 3rd and 4th lubricants, which are supplied by the ulnar nerve.

 

Deformities in ulnar nerve injury:

Partial claw hand:
  • Clawing: Hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of interphalangeal joints.
  • Clawing is seen in 2 medial fingers only.
  • Seen in pure ulnar nerve injury.
  • Also known as the true claw hand.

Complete claw hand:
  • Clawing of all 4 fingers.
  • Seen in combined median + ulnar nerve palsy

Tardy ulnar nerve palsy:
  • Slow-onset (over years) ulnar nerve palsy.
  • Seen with cubitus valgus deformity seen in lateral epicondyle humerus fracture.

Other deformities:
  • Wasting of hypothenar muscles & intrinsic muscles of the hand.
  • Hollow inter-metacarpal spaces in hand.

Ulnar paradox:

  • The higher the lesion, the less severe the deformity.
  • Reason: Long finger flexors are paralyzed and loss of finger flexion makes the deformity less obvious.

 

Treatment of Ulnar claw hand:

Static procedure (removal)
  • Zancolli Lasso procedure

Dynamic procedures (tendon transfer)
  • Modified Bunnel technique
  • Brand’s operation
  • Fowler’s operation

 

Radial Nerve (Option B) palsy causes wrist drop due to paralysis of the extensor carpi radialis longus and extensor carpi radialis brevis. Compression of the radial nerve in the radial groove while putting a hand on a chair/clutch causes Saturday night/crutch palsy.

Median Nerve (Option C) palsy causes carpal tunnel syndrome (Compression neuropathy). Paralysis of opponens pollicis muscle causes ‘Ape thumb deformity’. Paralysis of the flexor digitorum superficialis and lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus of the index finger causes ‘Pointing index’.

Posterior Interosseous Nerve (Option D) injury causes loss of finger extension called finger drop. There is no sensory loss. The injury occurs at the head of the radius.

questions.text: In the market, there are several new vaccines being researched, and their effectiveness is being evaluated and displayed in the image provided. Which of the recently developed vaccines demonstrate comparable efficacy to the previous vaccine?
questions.solution:
• Option C is correct because vaccines C, D, and E show comparable efficacy to the previous vaccine.
  • Conclusion based on forest plot, comparing efficacies.
  • Confidence intervals overlap, indicating similar efficacy.

D only (Option A): Only includes plot D, neglecting C and E.

 

D and E (Option B): Only includes plots D and E, neglecting C.

 

A, B, C and D (Option D): Includes plots A and B, which differ significantly from efficacy zone, unlike C, D, and E.

questions.text: Side effects of Pituitary irradiation?
questions.solution:
Pituitary irradiation, commonly used in the treatment of pituitary adenomas or certain hormonal disorders, can lead to various side effects due to the proximity of critical structures in the brain.

  1. Hypopituitarism:
    • This is the most common long-term side effect. Radiation can damage the normal pituitary tissue, leading to deficiencies in pituitary hormones (e.g., growth hormone, thyroid-stimulating hormone, or gonadotropins).
  2. Increased risk of cerebrovascular accident (CVA):
    • Radiation exposure to nearby vascular structures, such as the carotid arteries, can lead to vascular damage and increase the risk of strokes or transient ischemic attacks over time.
  3. Optic nerve damage:
    • Radiation can damage the optic nerves or the optic chiasm, leading to visual deficits such as visual field loss or, in severe cases, blindness.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with vague abdominal pain. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Angiomyolipoma is a benign renal tumour composed of fat, blood vessels, and smooth muscle. On CT, it is characterised by fat density (-10 to -100 Hounsfield units) within the lesion, which is a hallmark feature.

 

It is most commonly seen in middle-aged individuals and is associated with tuberous sclerosis in some cases.

Angiomyolipoma in both kidneys (arrows) in computer tomography. The tumours are hypodense (dark) due to fat content.

 

RCC (Renal Cell Carcinoma) (option A): RCC typically presents as an enhancing mass on CT without significant fat density. It may show irregular enhancement due to necrosis but does not have fat as a primary feature.

 

Renal Oncocytoma (option B): Renal oncocytoma is a benign tumour and appears as a homogeneously enhancing mass on CT but does not exhibit fat density.

 

Renal Cyst (option D): Renal cysts appear as well-defined, non-enhancing lesions with water density (0-20 Hounsfield units) on CT, without fat.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who has had 2 children through normal delivery presents with a dull aching pain over the abdomen, with irregular menses. Per vaginal examination revealed a mass felt through the posterior fornix. A USG showed a clear ovarian cyst of size 5 x 5 cm. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Follow up after 6 weeks

 

Explanation: A clear ovarian cyst measuring 5 x 5 cm in a reproductive-age woman is likely a functional ovarian cyst. The recommended management is observation with a follow-up ultrasound after 6 weeks to monitor for resolution.

 

Functional Ovarian Cysts:

  • Arise from ovarian follicles during follicle maturation and ovulation.
  • Types:
    • Single Cysts: Most common, often a single follicular or corpus luteum cyst.
    • Multiple Cysts: Can occur in conditions like:
      • Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
      • Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)
      • FSH-secreting pituitary adenomas
  • Features:
    • Functional cysts are typically 3–7 cm, and those larger than 10 cm or persistent for more than 3 months may require further investigation for malignancy.
    • Related to hormonal variations.
    • Filled with clear fluid (unless hemorrhage occurs).
    • Benign, often asymptomatic
    • Typically resolve on their own
  • Management:
    • Observation: Most cysts resolve spontaneously within 4-6 months.
      • Follow-up: Regular ultrasound after 6-12 weeks to monitor persistent or enlarging cysts.
      • Symptomatic Treatment: Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) may be prescribed for pain or irregular menses.
  • Surgery: Indicated for cysts larger than 10 cm, persistent, or symptomatic (e.g., pain, torsion).

 

Measure CA 125 levels (Option A): Elevated CA 125 can indicate ovarian cancer but is often raised in benign conditions like menstruation, endometriosis, or pelvic inflammatory disease. It is primarily useful in postmenopausal women with suspected malignancy.

 

Laparoscopy (Option B): Immediate surgery is unnecessary for a likely functional cyst. Laparoscopy is considered if the cyst persists, grows, or causes acute symptoms like torsion or rupture.


CT pelvis (Option C): A transvaginal ultrasound is the preferred imaging for ovarian cysts. CT is reserved for detecting and staging suspected ovarian neoplasms, which is not indicated here.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the quadruple screening test?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Inhibin B

 

Explanation: Inhibin B is not a component of the quadruple screening test.

 

Quadruple Marker

Down’s Syndrome

Edward’s Syndrome

Patau’s Syndrome

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) (Option C)

↓

↓

↓

Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) (Option A)

↑

↓

↓

Unconjugated Estriol (uE3) (Option B)

↓

↓

↓

Inhibin A

↑

-

↑

Note: Inhibin A is not calculated for Edward’s Syndrome.

questions.text: What fixative is used for a pap smear?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) 95% ethanol

 

Explanation: The most common fixative used in pap smear is 95% ethanol.

 

Pap smear

Site
  • Transformation zone of the cervix, where the squamous epithelium (ectocervix) and columnar epithelium (endocervix) meet.
  • This is the most common site for cervical cancer to develop.

Instruments
  • Ayre spatula collects cells from the ectocervix
  • Cervical broom (also called a cytobrush) from the transition zone
  • Endocervical brush from endocervix

Procedure
  • Conventional Pap smear:
    • Step 1: Insert a posterior vaginal wall retractor or speculum to expose the cervix for clear visibility and access.
    • Step 2: Use a small brush or spatula to collect cervical cells by gently rotating the instrument.
    • Step 3: Smear the collected cells onto a microscope slide, ensuring preservation of cell structure.
    • Step 4: Fix the smear with a fixative (95% ethyl alcohol) to preserve the cells for subsequent lab analysis.
  • Liquid-based cytology: Cells are collected and then rinsed into a liquid fixative vial. This is considered more sensitive than the conventional Pap smear as it provides a more uniform distribution of cells.

Considerations
  • Sensitivity: A single Pap test has a sensitivity of 47-62% for detecting high-grade cervical lesions.
  • HPV co-testing: Combining the Pap smear with HPV DNA testing significantly improves screening accuracy.
  • Colposcopy: Colposcopy, with biopsy if indicated, is the gold standard for evaluating abnormal Pap results.

Indications
  • Cervical cancer screening: Routine screening for women aged 21-65 years, with the frequency and type of testing varying based on age and risk factors.
  • Evaluation of abnormal vaginal bleeding: While not a primary diagnostic tool, a Pap smear is performed as part of the workup, along with other tests.

Timing & Frequency
  • Age 21-29: Cytology (Pap smear) every 3 years.
  • Age 30-65: Co-testing (Pap smear + HPV testing) every 5 years.
  • >65: No further screening if they have had 3 consecutive negative cytology results or 2 consecutive negative co-test results and no history of high-grade precancerous lesions.
  • H/o of CIN 2 or higher: Annual screening for 20 years.
  • More frequent screening in HIV and Immunocompromised patients.

Contraindications

Avoided during menstruation. (Relative C/I)

questions.text: What should be the minimum percentage for normal sperm morphology in a seminal fluid analysis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 4%

 

Explanation: 4% is the minimum percentage of sperm with normal morphology considered acceptable.

 

Semen Analysis and Normal Values:

  • First investigation for infertility in males.
  • Performed after 1 year of unprotected intercourse without conception or earlier if there are known risk factors for infertility.
  • Abstain: 2-7 days.
  • Analysis: Within 1 hour on the liquefied semen (takes 20-30 min).

 

Parameters

Normal (Normozoospermia)

(WHO 2021 Guidelines)

Volume

> 1.4 ml

pH

7.2-8.0

Concentration

At least 16 million/ ml

Total count

39 million/ejaculate

Total Motility

42% or more

Progressive motility

30% or more

Morphology (most important)

4% or more

Pus cells (WBC)

1-2 million/ml

Viability

54% or more

 

Note:

  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia (OATZ) means all parameters are subnormal, as seen in varicocele and smoking.

The most important parameters in sperm analysis are Morphology > Motility > Concentration.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presented with amenorrhoea. On examination, she had normal genitalia & normal breast development. Her tests reveal a 5 alpha-reductase deficiency. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Male pseudohermaphroditism

 

Explanation: The 18-year-old girl with amenorrhea, normal external genitalia, normal breast development, and 5 alpha-reductase deficiency points towards male pseudohermaphroditism.

 

Pseudohermaphroditism:

  • Refers to a condition where the gonads and external genitalia are of opposite sexes.
  • Male pseudohermaphroditism (MPH):
    • 46XY karyotype with testes, but external genitalia may appear female or ambiguous.
    • Often caused by defects in testosterone biosynthetic enzymes, androgen receptors, or 5-alpha-reductase.
    • 5-alpha-reductase deficiency results in incomplete virilization and external genitalia resembling female phenotype, though male characteristics may develop at puberty.
    • Management focuses on gender role rehabilitation, typically in accordance with the sex of rearing.
  • Female pseudohermaphroditism: (Option C)
    • 46XX karyotype with ovaries, but external genitalia appear male or ambiguous.
    • Most commonly caused by congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), resulting in excess androgens and virilization of the female fetus.
    • Leads to clitoromegaly and fused labioscrotal folds resembling a scrotum.
    • Management includes steroid therapy, estrogen administration, and surgical reconstruction of external genitalia.

 

Concealed sex (Option A) refers to hiding one’s true sex (e.g., through clothing or deception), often for legal or social reasons. Physical examination typically reveals the true sex. This does not fit as the patient has normal genitalia and normal breast development, and the diagnosis is more likely related to 5-alpha-reductase deficiency.

 

True hermaphroditism (Option B) is a rare condition with both ovarian and testicular tissue. The patient has 46XY karyotype, no evidence of both gonads, and normal genitalia, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant female is carrying monochorionic diamniotic twins. On ultrasound examination, there is evidence of polyhydramnios in one twin and oligohydramnios in the other. What is the most likely complication?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Twin to twin transfusion syndrome

 

Explanation: Pregnant female having monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy with ultrasound showing polyhydramnios in one twin and oligohydramnios in the other, the most likely diagnosis is Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS).

 

Twin-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS):

  • TTTS in monochorionic-diamniotic twin pregnancies involves blood transfusion from a donor twin to the recipient, causing anemia and growth restriction in the donor, and polycythemia and heart failure in the recipient.
  • Presentation:
    • Donor twin: Smaller, pale, with oligohydramnios.
    • Recipient twin: Larger, with polyhydramnios and hyperviscosity.
  • Incidence: TTTS occurs in 10-15% of monochorionic twin pregnancies.
  • Pathophysiology: Unidirectional blood flow via deep arteriovenous anastomoses leads to volume depletion in the donor and excess in the recipient, causing growth restriction and hydrops.

Quintero Staging System:

  •  

Stage

Description

Stage I

Polyhydramnios in the recipient twin (deepest vertical pocket ≥8 cm) and oligohydramnios in the donor twin (deepest vertical pocket ≤2 cm), with a visible bladder in the donor twin.

Stage II

Severe oligohydramnios in the donor twin with no visible bladder.

Stage III

Critically abnormal Doppler findings, such as absent/reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery, reversed flow in the ductus venosus, or pulsatile flow in the umbilical vein in one or both twins.

Stage IV

Presence of hydrops fetalis in one or both twins, indicating severe fetal compromise.

Stage V

Demise of one or both twins.

 

  • Management:
    • Laser ablation: Targets placental anastomoses (16-26 weeks).
    • Solomon Technique: Coagulates the entire vascular equator.
    • Amnioreduction: Reduces amniotic fluid and prevents complications.
  • Complications: Preterm birth (before 34 weeks), procedure-related issues (e.g., ruptured membranes, placental abruption), and Twin Anemia-Polycythemia Sequence (TAPS).
  • Outcomes:
    • Without treatment, perinatal mortality is 70-100%.
    • After laser therapy, mortality is 30-50%, with 5-20% neurological impairment.
    • Double-twin survival is ~70%.

 

Selective Fetal Growth Restriction (sFGR) (Option A): While sFGR can occur in monochorionic twins, it doesn't typically cause the fluid imbalance (polyhydramnios in one twin and oligohydramnios in the other) seen in Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS). sFGR is more related to growth differences between twins, not amniotic fluid abnormalities.

 

Preterm Labor (Option B): Although monochorionic diamniotic pregnancies are at higher risk for preterm birth, preterm labor doesn't cause the specific fluid imbalance, characteristic of TTTS (polyhydramnios in one twin and oligohydramnios in the other).

 

Neural Tube Defects (Option D): Neural tube defects, such as spina bifida, are developmental anomalies that affect fetal development but do not cause the fluid imbalance observed in TTTS.

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality given below.
questions.solution:
Ultrasound imaging (USG) is characterised by grey-scale images formed by sound waves that interact with tissues and reflect based on differences in echogenicity.

The hallmark features of USG include:

  • Real-time imaging.
  • Presence of hypoechoic (dark) and hyperechoic (bright) areas based on tissue density.
  • Ability to show structures like fluid collections, solid masses, or blood flow using Doppler.

 

Ultrasound Gel

Purpose of Gel
  • Eliminates air pockets between probe and skin for effective sound transmission.
  • Serves as a medium for sound and lubricant.

Preferred Gel
  • Hydrogel is preferred over Lipogel for easier cleaning.

Ingredients
  • Distilled water, carbomer, ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), propylene glycol, glycerin, trolamine, and occasionally contains blue colorant.

Infection Control

Cover transducer and skin with plastic for patients with open wounds or skin issues.

↓

Apply gel on both sides of the plastic.

↓

Clean transducer after each use


Principle of USG: Ultrasound operates on the pulse-echo principle, utilizing piezoelectric materials found in the ultrasound probe's crystal.

Types of Ultrasound Transducers/ Probes

Linear
  • Shape: Rectangular/parallelogram image
  • Use: Vascular, high-resolution imaging

Convex
  • Shape: Sector image, curved top
  • Use: Abdominal, OBS/ GYN

Phased Array
  • Shape: Sector image, pointed top
  • Use: Cardiac (fits between ribs), endocavitary (like endovaginal), neonatal brain

Vector/ Trapezoidal
  • Shape: Trapezoidal image
  • Use: Abdominal, cardiac, Doppler
  • Features: Hybrid of linear & phased

 

Fluoroscopy (option B) produces real-time X-ray images, usually with dynamic motion, such as during barium studies or catheter placements. It does not resemble static grey-scale USG images.

 

X-Ray (option C): X-rays are static, high-contrast images displaying bones, air-filled spaces, or dense structures like metal. They do not provide grey-scale differentiation like USG.


MRI (option D) produces highly detailed cross-sectional images with various sequences (T1, T2, etc.). It is more advanced than USG, often showing clear demarcation of soft tissues, which is not typical of the image described.

questions.text:
Match the following disorders causing secondary amenorrhea with their respective lab findings:


	
		
			
			Condition
			
			
			Lab Markers
			
		
		
			
			1. Sheehan's syndrome
			
			
			A. Normal LH, Normal FSH, Normal estradiol
			
		
		
			
			2. Premature Ovarian Failure
			
			
			B. High LH, Low FSH, Normal estradiol
			
		
		
			
			3. PCOS
			
			
			C. Low LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
			
		
		
			
			4. Asherman's syndrome
			
			
			D. High LH, High FSH, Low estradiol
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

 

Explanation: The correct answer is 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A.

 

Condition

Lab Markers

1. Sheehan's syndrome

C. Low LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol

2. Premature Ovarian Failure

D. High LH, High FSH, Low estradiol

3. PCOS

B. High LH, Low FSH, Normal estradiol

4. Asherman's syndrome

A. Normal LH, Normal FSH, Normal estradiol

 

Secondary amenorrhea: Defined as the absence of menstrual periods for three consecutive months in a woman who previously had regular menstrual cycles, or for six months in a woman who had irregular cycles.

 

Sheehan’s Syndrome (1):

  • Pituitary ischemia due to postpartum hemorrhage leading to hypopituitarism.
  • Investigations:
    • FSH, LH, Estradiol: Low.
    • Other Hormones: Cortisol, TSH, prolactin levels to assess panhypopituitarism.
    • MRI of Pituitary: Evaluates ischemic damage.

 

Premature Ovarian Failure (POF) / Premature Menopause (2):

  • Menopause before the age of 40 years.
  • Investigations:
    • Both LH and FSH are high.
    • Estradiol: Low.
    • FSH/LH ratio: Elevated.

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) (3):

  • Metabolic and endocrine disorder in reproductive-age women.
  • Investigations:
    • LH: Elevated (LH > FSH).
    • FSH: Normal or low.
    • Estradiol: Normal or elevated.
    • Ultrasound: Polycystic ovaries with 12 or more follicles (2-9 mm diameter).

 

Asherman’s Syndrome (4):

  • Presence of uterine synechiae due to endometrial trauma, often post-pregnancy-related curettage.
  • Investigations:
    • FSH, LH, Estradiol: Normal.
    • Hysteroscopy: Gold standard for diagnosis.
    • Hysterosalpingography: Moth-eaten appearance of the uterine cavity.

questions.text:
Which of the following investigations is used to diagnose the unicornuate uterus?


	Falloposcopy
	Laparoscopy
	HSG
	X-ray
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) 2,3

 

Explanation: Laparoscopy and Hysterosalpingogram (HSG) can be used to diagnose the unicornuate uterus.

 

Unicornuate Uterus:

  • Results from the incomplete development of one Müllerian duct while the other duct develops normally, leading to a single functioning uterine cavity.
  • Diagnostic Evaluations:
    • Ultrasound (USG):
      • First-line imaging to detect uterine anomalies.
      • Can identify associated abnormalities like ipsilateral renal agenesis, present in about 40% of cases.
  • Saline Infusion Sonography (SIS): Enhances visualization of the uterine cavity for better evaluation of Müllerian anomalies.
  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG): (3)
    • Reveals a characteristic fusiform (banana-shaped) uterine cavity.
    • The cavity typically tapers at the apex and connects to a single fallopian tube.
    • The uterus may appear to be shifted from the midline.

 

  • MRI:
    • The preferred non-invasive modality for detailed assessment.
    • Provides precise preoperative evaluation.
  • Hysteroscopy/Laparoscopy: (2)
    • Reserved for patients with complex uterine anomalies or those undergoing infertility evaluation.
    • Allows direct visualization and confirmation of the diagnosis.

 

X-ray (Option A) lacks the resolution and specificity required to evaluate uterine anomalies or fallopian tube pathology effectively. It has been replaced by advanced imaging modalities like HSG and laparoscopy.

 

Falloposcopy (Option B & C) is a minimally invasive procedure that provides direct visualization of the fallopian tubes, particularly useful for identifying pathology at the cornual (proximal) and interstitial portions of the tube.

questions.text:
According to IADPSG, what is the cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus?

 

IADPSG: International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Group
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) > 92 mg/dL

 

Explanation: According to IADPSG, the cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus is > 92 mg/dL.

 

Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM) is a common pregnancy complication, defined as “any degree of glucose intolerance with onset or first recognition during pregnancy.”

 

IADPSG Criteria for GDM Diagnosis:

  • A 75-g glucose dose is used for an Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) in all clinical settings, including during pregnancy.
  • GDM is diagnosed if any one of the cut-offs is met:
    • Fasting Plasma Glucose (FPG): ≥ 92 mg/dL
    • 1-hour Plasma Glucose (1-h PG): ≥ 180 mg/dL
    • 2-hour Plasma Glucose (2-h PG): ≥ 153 mg/dL

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension came with post-menopausal bleeding. Which of the following will you do to evaluate the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Endometrial sampling

 

Explanation: Endometrial sampling is done to evaluate patients with post-menopausal bleeding.

 

Indications for Endometrial Biopsy:

  • Abnormal uterine bleeding
  • Atypical glandular or endometrial cells on cervical cytology
  • Cancer screening (e.g., hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer)
  • Follow-up and surveillance of previously diagnosed endometrial hyperplasia
  • Postmenopausal bleeding

 

Transvaginal ultrasonography (TVS) is the first-line investigation for evaluating postmenopausal bleeding. Since TVS is not among the available options, endometrial sampling becomes the best choice in this case.

 

Pap smear (Option A): Primarily used for cervical cancer screening in women over 21 who have been sexually active for at least three years. It does not assess the endometrium, making it unsuitable for postmenopausal bleeding.

 

Visual inspection with iodine (Option B), also called Schiller’s test, detects cervical abnormalities in facilities lacking Pap smear access. It evaluates the cervix and vagina as in cases of carcinoma cervix, not the endometrium, and is inappropriate for postmenopausal bleeding.

 

Colposcopy (Option C) examines the cervix, vagina, and vulva. It is challenging in postmenopausal women due to a narrowed vagina, senile vaginitis, poorly visible squamocolumnar junction, and atrophied cervix.

questions.text: Which of the following is recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) for the management of the second stage of labor?

choices.text: Manual perineal support and warm compresses
Maintain head in deflexion and deliver

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Manual perineal support and warm compresses

 

Explanation: Manual perineal support and warm compresses are recommended by the WHO for the management of the second stage of labor.

 

Second stage of labor: Refers to the time period from full cervical dilation to the delivery of the fetus.

During this stage, perineal massage with lubricants and warm compresses can help soften and stretch the perineum. This approach may reduce the risk of third- and fourth-degree perineal tears.

 

Mandatory episiotomy (Option A) is now discouraged by the WHO due to evidence showing it doesn’t prevent severe tears and may increase postnatal discomfort, sexual dysfunction, and complications. It is only recommended when medically indicated, such as in cases of shoulder dystocia, fetal macrosomia, breech delivery, operative vaginal delivery, or persistent OP positions.

 

Maintain head in deflexion and deliver (Option C): Keeping the fetal head in deflexion during delivery is not recommended as it can lead to complications like shoulder dystocia and neck or nerve damage.

 

Deliver in lithotomy position only (Option D): WHO does not recommend delivering exclusively in the lithotomy position. While common, it is not the only option. Women are encouraged to choose the most comfortable position, such as squatting or hands-and-knees, for a more natural and less interventionist birth.

questions.text: A couple presents to the infertility clinic with a normal hysterosalpingogram and a semen analysis report with azoospermia. Which of the following is the next best test to differentiate between an obstructive and a testicular cause of azoospermia?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Serum FSH levels

 

Explanation: Serum FSH level is the next best test to differentiate between an obstructive and a testicular cause of azoospermia.

Elevated FSH levels suggest a non-obstructive, testicular cause of azoospermia or primary gonadal failure.

Low FSH levels are observed in cases of pituitary or hypothalamic failure.

Normal FSH levels could be due to obstructive (post-testicular cause) or non-obstructive (testicular cause) azoospermia.

 

Azoospermia:

  • Refers to no sperm in semen.
  • Causes of Azoospermia:

 

1. Pre-testicular (central): endocrine disorders (low LH and FSH)
  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism/ Kallman syndrome
  • Endocrine: Hyperprolactinemia, obesity, thyroid disorder
  • Drugs: Antihypertensives, Antipsychotics

2. Testicular (peripheral): Intrinsic disorders (High FSH and LH)
  • Genetic disorders:
    • Klinefelter syndrome (Most common)
    • Immotile cilia (Kartagener) syndrome
  • Varicocele: Most common reversible cause
  • Undescended testes
  • Testicular torsion
  • Mumps orchitis
  • Heat exposure: Miners
  • Toxins: smoking, radiation, drug abuse
  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia

3. Post-testicular: (Normal LH and FSH)
  • Congenital: Absent vas deferens (cystic fibrosis), Young’s syndrome
  • Obstruction: Epididymal and Ejaculatory duct obstruction
  • Acquired: Genital TB, gonorrhoea
  • Surgical: herniorrhaphy, vasectomy, bladder neck surgery
  • Other: Retrograde ejaculation, hypospadias

 

Serum Testosterone Levels (Option B): Low testosterone levels might indicate a testicular cause of azoospermia but are not specific enough to differentiate between obstructive and non-obstructive azoospermia.


Testicular Biopsy (Option C): While this procedure is essential for confirming the exact cause, it is invasive and typically reserved for cases where non-invasive tests like serum FSH levels fail to provide clarity.

 

Serum LH Levels (Option D): Elevated LH levels may suggest a testicular cause of azoospermia, but like FSH, they cannot specifically distinguish between obstructive and non-obstructive azoospermia.

questions.text: What is the dose of dexamethasone given for fetal lung maturity?

choices.text: 2 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart
2 doses of 12 mg given 24 hours apart
4 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart
4 doses of 12 mg given 12 hours apart

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) 4 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart

 

Explanation: The dose of dexamethasone given for fetal lung maturity is 4 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart.

 

Dexamethasone in Fetal Lung Maturity:

  • Accelerates fetal lung maturation and reduces the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).
  • Improves survival and reduces morbidity in preterm neonates.
  • Recommended for pregnancies at less than 34 weeks of gestation, particularly between 31 and 34 weeks.
  • Administered as 4 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart.
  • Decreases the incidence of:
    • Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)
    • Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH)
    • Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC)

questions.text: Which of the following emergency contraceptives is used in India?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg

 

Explanation: Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is an emergency contraception used in India.

 

Emergency Contraceptives (EC):

  • Prevents unintended pregnancy after unprotected or inadequately protected intercourse.
  • It includes both emergency contraceptive pills (ECPs) and the insertion of an intrauterine device (IUD):
  1. Emergency Contraceptive Pills (ECPs):
  • Levonorgestrel (LNG):
    • Available as a single 1.5 mg pill.
    • Most effective within 72 hours but can be used up to 120 hours.
    • Commonly available in India.
  • Ulipristal Acetate (UPA): (Option C)
    • Single-dose pill containing 30 mg of ulipristal acetate.
    • Effective for up to 120 hours (5 days) post-intercourse.
    • Approved by US-FDA and European medicine agencies.
    • Not available in India.
  • Combined Hormonal Regimens (Yuzpe Method):
    • Involves taking 2 doses, 12 hours apart.
    • Each dose contains at least 100 micrograms of ethinyl estradiol and 500 micrograms of levonorgestrel.
  1. Intrauterine Device (IUD):
  • Copper IUD:
    • Most effective form of EC.
    • It can be inserted within 5 days of unprotected intercourse.

 

Misoprostol 400 mcg (Option A): Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analogue, is commonly used in combination with mifepristone for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). It induces uterine contractions to facilitate abortion and is not classified as an emergency contraceptive.


Ethinyl estradiol 600 mcg (Option B): High-dose ethinyl estradiol (EE) combined with levonorgestrel is used in the Yuzpe regimen for emergency contraception; EE alone at this dose does not function as an emergency contraceptive.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a young child who is experiencing mild intermittent upper abdominal pain and has an X-ray shown below?
questions.solution:
A Morgagni hernia is a rare type of diaphragmatic hernia where abdominal contents herniate into the thoracic cavity through the foramen of Morgagni (anterior defect of the diaphragm).

Clinical features: Often presents with mild, intermittent abdominal pain, respiratory symptoms, or may be asymptomatic.

X-ray findings: On a chest X-ray, the herniated bowel loops may appear as air-filled structures in the anterior mediastinum, often on the right side near the heart.

 

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH):

  1. CDH is the intrathoracic herniation of abdominal contents due to congenital defects in the diaphragm.
  2. Types of CDH:
    • Bochdalek Hernia: Occurs through the posterolateral pleuroperitoneal canal, most commonly on the left side.
    • Morgagni Hernia: Anterior hernia located at the right cardiophrenic angle.

Fig. Schematic representation of CDH

  1. Radiologic Features:
    • Chest Radiograph (CXR):
